PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I ask: what assessment has the government made of the impact on drought-affected farmers of its decision to raise official interest rates by one per cent?

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleague Senator McMullan for fundamentally answering the question for me with that interjection. It is simply not possible to make that kind of simplistic assessment for the simple reason that there are many farmers in the most drought-affected areas in Australia that are actually being subsidised on their interest rates. As a result of the very significant additional package that was provided in the last drought statement—I think in broad figures it was of the order of $50 million—a significant number of those farmers are now being assisted to the extent of receiving 100 per cent of those interest rates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. To help the minister, I refer to the assessment made by the New South Wales Farmers Association—which at least has had a go at something I would have thought was very important to drought-affected farmers—which said that farmers' debt stands at approximately $17 billion.
—Did they take the subsidy into account?

—Yes. It said very few have benefited by the special interest rate subsidy and that debt is at $17 billion. The increase is therefore expected to cost up to $170 million. Was that fact not acknowledged by the Treasurer, Mr Willis, who stated on 24 October:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we can't delay necessary monetary policy adjustments because one sector of the economy is hurting.

And is it not therefore true that because of the government's refusal to take urgent action on the deficit the majority of Australian farmers will be burdened with an increased interest rate bill which will in fact exceed the $165 million in the drought paper?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see those figures. I will be happy to provide Senator Hill with the analysis that was done of it by ABARE. Of course we examined it. The fact is that it is not as simplistic as Senator Hill is asserting. I want to respond to the last part of that nonsense from Senator Hill in respect of the government's deficit. The facts are that in respect of the drought or anything else the only suggestion that I am getting from any opposition politician, whether it is from the federal parliament—the House of Representatives or the Senate—or from New South Wales, is to increase government expenditure.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of a recent media campaign being conducted by the Leader of the National Party in the other house to have the Commonwealth appoint a drought aid ombudsman. Can the minister advise the Senate whether he has been approached directly on this matter and what action, if any, he has taken to consider the matter?

—As I have said in this chamber on a number of occasions, if the opposition comes up with any kind of decent policy proposal to help farming families then I will give it consideration. Sadly, however, this is just one more in a long line of failed proposals that in fact would not provide any kind of real assistance at all to farmers. I would assume that it is not actually coalition policy on the drought; it certainly was not mentioned by the shadow minister, but only by the Leader of the National Party to this point in time. The first time I heard of this proposal—and I suspect it was the first time that most coalition members heard of it—was when Mr Fischer was interviewed by Laurie Oakes—
—What has this got to do with the price of fish?

—Because I got a letter from Mr Fischer yesterday on this—that is why. It was when he raised it on Channel Nine's Sunday program nine days ago. Yesterday I received a letter dated the same day—that is, a `yesterday' letter nine days afterwards—from Mr Fischer proposing that we appoint a special ombudsman for drought. He ended the letter with a request to me to provide him with an early response.

PARA.TAB: The facts are that the appointment of a drought-aid ombudsman is not only unnecessary but also would be a gross waste of public money. Mr Fischer said that the ombudsman he is proposing should have four functions, all of which, I might add, are currently covered by various Commonwealth, state government and territory appeal mechanisms.

The government's preferred approach is to assist drought relief applicants at the point of contact. As I told the Senate yesterday, we have recently provided an additional $450,000 for the appointment of further counsellors to provide that kind of direct assistance. I have to say that I would much rather spend half a million dollars of public money on providing additional financial and family counsellors for farmers than have the unnecessary appointment of an ombudsman, whose job apparently it would be to go around supervising the people who were doing the job.

The Commonwealth currently funds over 90 financial counsellors across the country, at an annual cost of around $4 million. These services are provided completely free of charge to primary producers. As I said yesterday, we have just augmented that with another half a million dollars to fund new family counselling services. These services are delivered direct to farmers on the ground. If farming families do genuinely encounter red tape, there is a range of appeal avenues already available to them under both Commonwealth and state processes.

The figures I gave in the chamber yesterday on the uptake of the drought relief payment would suggest that there is not any real problem at all with the uptake; in fact, thousands of farming families have already made application for it. It is little wonder that the peak rural industry organisations in Australia at the moment are—and I assure the Senate that they are—shaking their heads in disbelief at the federal coalition's response on how to assist farmers during this drought. The facts are that those opposite have demonstrated once again that the coalition leadership of Mr Downer and Mr Fischer simply is not up to the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. There have been three reports in the past three months which are a damning indictment of the government's child-care program. Child care is not adequately meeting the needs of parents, with the high cost of care and lack of flexibility in operating hours cited as two of the major complaints. The greatest areas of unmet demand are in occasional care, baby care, before and after school care, and care in rural areas. When will the minister and the government stop being driven by the union movement and start taking parents' and children's interests into account?

—This is a remarkably cheeky question from the senator opposite, particularly in the light of what the opposition would do about child care. We have had a number of reports about child care, most of which we have asked for and all of which we welcome, pointing to ways in which we can improve child care. But Senator Troeth did not tell us in her question what all those reports say. For example, the Choice report today says that 91 per cent of people using child care are satisfied or more than satisfied with it and that 95 per cent of people using child care are pleased with the quality of the care.
—Just answer the question for a change.

—Senator Kemp should just wait; I have a message for him. The cost of care has been kept down remarkably. The latest CPI figures show that one thing keeping inflation low has been the reduction in the cost of child care, exactly due to this government's policies on affordability of child care. That does not mean we can rest; but it does mean we are acutely aware of the question of cost. It was that lot on the other side who rigorously opposed the introduction of the child-care cash rebate, which goes to helping keep down the cost of child care. Senator Minchin is one of the loudest of the people running around the country trying to cut out the child-care cash rebate. He is one of the people who joined Mrs Carroll to do away with what he voted for. He is one of those senators very close to Mr Downer who campaigned against Senator Hill; so Senator Minchin's place in the scheme of things is very interesting.

PARA.TAB: Is he committed to child care or is he committed to his leader—a leader who does not want to persist with the quality of care that we strongly support? The only policy that we are clear that Mr Downer wants is to make voluntary the accreditation program that we have established—to take away the accreditation that we have established and which is welcomed by the users. Mr Downer and the opposition would take away the accreditation and make it merely a voluntary program.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much will it cost?

—We are working that out right now. I am pleased that the honourable senator at last understands that we do not have a sufficient number of baby places. As for occasional care, we are actually moving occasional care places to where they are needed—from places where they are being used for work-related care to other places where they are wanted for occasional care.

PARA.TAB: As for the baby places, I have talked very often and at great length with the private sector to ask it to take up the baby places. It has not largely committed itself to baby places because that is the expensive end of town and it is not getting into it—yet.

But we are realising that we have an industry now employing some 70,000 people—a very significant industry, an industry that is actually in the process of maturing. The places are established, quality care is being set in train and we are keeping it affordable. Now it is time to turn to some finetuning and adjusting. I do not have any shame at all about our child care. I welcome the reports and I welcome recognition of just how good this government's child-care program is and how the opposition has fought it all the way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I hope that the minister also welcomes the comments of the former head of the Office of the Status of Women, Ms Sherry, who said, `If banks were treating consumers in the same way that a lot of consumers feel they are being treated by children's services, we would be out on the streets.' There was a budget blow-out of $37 million in the budget for child-care fee relief this year and still the needs of Australian parents are not being met. How can the minister claim, as she did in a letter to the editor in last Friday's Australian, that she supports genuine choice in child care when so many people do not have access to services?

—I support it because we are well on the way to giving those people those choices. If the honourable senator checks the surveys, she will find that 80 per cent of people are actually having their needs met. Twenty per cent are not—and I do not find that satisfactory.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators opposite can whinge and complain, but the government they left had 46,000 places; we now have 250,000. So there has been a dramatic increase in growth. Certainly, it is not sufficient but we are in the middle of a growth in child-care places.

PARA.TAB: As to the EPAC report and the quote from Ms Ann Sherry, most of those opposite carry on with the confusion that results from not understanding the points she was referring to—in particular, the confusion between state and Commonwealth child care, a point that must be recognised. I suggest they read the EPAC report, which gives this government's child care a very high tick, and appreciate that child care is not like banks. We are becoming much more sensitive to what consumers need. Why does the honourable senator suppose we have these reports? I will be listening to and acting on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I understand that the Australian Sports Drug Agency has recently signed an anti-doping agreement with China. Can the minister explain how this will assist China in the battle against drugs in sport and how it will affect Australian athletes in their preparation for the 2000 Olympics?

—Mr President, on 25 October the Australian Sports Drug Agency signed an anti-doping agreement with the Chinese Olympic Committee's anti-doping commission. The agreement was initiated at a meeting I held in Canberra with Chinese anti-doping authorities in July of this year. One of the reasons this very significant agreement was established is the concern of Australian sport with the issue of drugs in sport in China. Rather than be part of the worldwide finger-pointing exercise, it was decided that it would be more constructive to determine what is occurring in China and identify the best way to deal effectively with that situation.

PARA.TAB: After reciprocal visits between Australian and Chinese anti-doping authorities, officers of the Australian Sports Drug Agency reported to me that they felt that, rather than there being any systemised drug use in China, the problem was similar to all countries where sporting success is important. China has an anti-doping program; however, it does not have an independent agency, such as the Australian Sports Drug Agency, and it has not yet devoted enough resources to deal effectively with the drug use problem.

For example, in Australia in 1993-94, 2,800 tests were conducted, 52 per cent of which were out of competition tests. In China in 1993, 1,600 tests were conducted, but only 20 per cent were out of competition tests. It also appears that China has not yet developed an education program to support its testing program.

The anti-doping agreement between Australia and China will lead to the following initiatives. Firstly, ASDA will assist China to establish an independent agency based on our model, including a drug testing program with an increased emphasis on out of competition testing. Secondly, ASDA and the Chinese anti-doping agency will continue to work together to ensure the effectiveness of their domestic programs. As well as their strong domestic programs, China and Australia will encourage international federations to implement out of competition testing. Both Australia and China welcome testing conducted by international federations in their countries. In addition, to ensure a strong voice in world anti-doping initiatives, Australia and China will commence work on establishing an Asia and Oceania anti-doping forum.

Finally, ASDA and the Chinese anti-doping agency will continue to exchange expert resources to further advance these initiatives. The success of these initiatives will see Australian athletes competing on a fairer basis. They will be able to compete against Chinese athletes knowing that those athletes are exposed to a drug testing program similar to the stringent one in Australia.

I reiterate my statement to the Senate of two weeks ago. We will certainly take every opportunity to influence international sporting federations in other countries to take action on doping in sport. Australia has an outstanding record in this regard. We will be able to use the opportunity that the 2000 Olympics brings us to convince others that an out of competition testing program should be introduced internationally. We will be more active in a range of international forums that have a role in anti-doping matters. We will pursue further testing agreements with other countries, and we will keep the pressure on.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. On page 11 of the national forest policy, signed by the Commonwealth government and all state governments in December 1992, one of the key provisions states:

QUESTION.PARA: The Governments agree that, conditional on satisfactory agreement on criteria by the Commonwealth and the States, comprehensive, adequate and representative reservation systems to protect old growth forest and wilderness values will be in place by the end of 1995.

Now that the NFPS is almost two years old, and with only one year left to have in place this comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system, I ask Senator Collins to indicate the number of areas that have been reserved in the last two years as a result of the NFPS. I also ask the minister to demonstrate what there is of substance that can assure us that the December 1995 timetable will be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot respond to the last part of Senator Bell's question about the actual numbers of the areas that he has asked me about. I will take that part of the question on notice. The Minister for Resources has provided me with a response to the first part of Senator Bell's question.

PARA.TAB: Under the national forest policy statement governments have agreed that, conditional on satisfactory agreement on criteria by the Commonwealth and the states, a comprehensive, adequate and representative reservation system to protect old-growth forest and wilderness values will be in place on public lands by the end of next year. A joint Commonwealth and state technical working group is developing broad criteria on which to base reserve systems to protect the nature conservation values of forests. It is a fact that these criteria still need to be finalised. Accordingly, no additions to the forest reserve system have resulted from this work to date.

Meeting the timetable of 1995 for the establishment of the reserve system to protect old-growth forests and wilderness values will require a concerted effort over the next year, and we are well aware of that. While the Minister for Resources cannot give any firm guarantee that the timetable will be achieved, it is in the interests of all signatories—
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Kernot that this is an intergovernmental agreement; we do not have a unilateral role to play in this. It is in the interests of all signatory governments to the NFPS to work toward that end. I believe that the major degree of concern at the moment lies with the state of New South Wales.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the minister to a media release from the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Simon Crean, and the former Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Ross Free, dated 21 December 1992, in which they stated that the government was proposing to amend the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations to prohibit the import of high level radioactive waste of foreign origin. Firstly, has the government finalised these amendments in order to fulfil its commitment to ban the importation of high level radioactive waste of foreign origin, and if not, why not? Secondly, why does the original commitment refer only to high level radioactive waste and not to any form of radioactive waste of foreign origin?

—The government has not finalised this issue because of a definitional problem concerning radioactive waste, which is being addressed at the moment. But I make it absolutely clear quite simply that Australia has absolutely no intention at all of importing the radioactive wastes of other countries. This has been the clear position of successive Australian governments. Indeed, radioactive wastes remain a prohibited import under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations.

PARA.TAB: In the environment statement of December 1992, the government proposed an absolute legislative ban on the importation of high level radioactive wastes of foreign origin from other countries. There is no conspiracy theory, I can assure Senator Margetts, in respect of the reference to high level wastes. The reason that the proposal was couched in the terms of high level wastes was that lower level radioactive wastes are routinely disposed of in their countries of origin.

In considering implementation of the proposal, my department and Senator Cook's department at the time consulted the Australian Customs Service and other agencies which raised significant practical and definitional difficulties in implementing such a ban. I understand that the definitional issues concerning radioactive wastes are currently being addressed by a subcommittee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. I repeat that pending resolution of these issues, the Australian government has absolutely no intention of importing radioactive waste into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the admission by the government that these amendments to current legislation have not been effected, can the minister assure the people in the Goldfields region of Western Australia, who have recently expressed concern at the proposal by the Western Australian government to promote their region as the national waste repository, that current legislation and regulation will prevent ANSTO from importing foreign sourced radioactive waste? If, as the minister says, there are problems in implementing the promise of two years ago, can he give any idea when this might happen?

—As I just said, the matter is currently being considered by a subcommittee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. I will certainly be prepared to make an inquiry of that subcommittee as to how long it thinks it will take before it gets the definitional problem sorted out. In respect of the first part of the supplementary question, I simply reiterate that the current regulations prohibit such importations and the Australian government has no intention of doing it in any case.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to the recent comments by Merle Mitchell, the spokesperson for ACOSS, that the home child-care allowance discriminates against low income families. Under the current provisions, a family in which, for instance, the husband earns $100,000 a year and the wife stays at home to care for children who may be 16 or 17 years old, is eligible for this allowance. Why is this family more deserving of government assistance than a poor family with pre-school children in which the mother may work half an hour a week and thus become ineligible?
—One of the problems that we have with this legislation is trying to get the opposition to understand it.
—Ha, Ha! Try to get those people to understand it.
—Listen, Senator, do you want to know the facts here or not?
—Order! Address your comments through the chair, please, Senator Crowley, and do not be baited by comments from the opposition.
—It is tempting, Mr President. The examples cited by Senator Ferguson are no different from the current arrangements for the dependent spouse rebate, and that needs to be understood.
—Does that make it right?

—Senator Ferguson put a question to me and I am proceeding to answer it. Merle Mitchell has all the right in the world to make her comments, but Senator Ferguson is deliberately misunderstanding. Senator Ferguson claims that a person earning a small amount of money becomes ineligible for the HCCA. That is not true. That person is eligible for less than the full HCCA. Senator Ferguson knows that, but he goes out and misrepresents the facts. People can earn quite an amount before they lose the full HCCA.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—How much?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a small amount; it is about $1,000. It is no different from the arrangement under the dependent spouse rebate. In fact, it is a little more than it was before because people are now getting $30 a week instead of the previous $28.20. Senator Ferguson knows the answer as well as I do. He does not want to know the facts. Everybody who is eligible for the full HCCA is better off, comparing like with like, because the $28.20 is now $30 and because many of those low income people who were never eligible for full dependent spouse rebate because they paid too little tax—an estimated 50,000 of them—are now eligible for full HCCA. Do we hear Merle Mitchell and Senator Ferguson talking about that? That is something that the government has done to make people on low incomes, who were previously not eligible for the DSR, eligible for HCCA.

PARA.TAB: I would urge caution in spouting off about HCCA because it very much represents the understanding that existed previously with the dependent spouse rebate, but it increases the payment to everybody who is eligible. It certainly increases the payment to 50,000 families at the low end of the income scale who were not previously eligible for DSR but who are now eligible for full HCCA. As it is prospective, it also means that some 120,000 families, whatever the working spouse's income, are eligible for the home child-care allowance immediately they cease work if they are not earning in the following fortnight.

I understand that a few examples have been raised of the way income is treated differently by social security compared with the tax system, and that that has led to a few families—modest numbers and, on my advice, not the numbers that Senator Lees has indicated—not being eligible for either full or part HCCA where they were previously eligible for DSR. But the example given by Senator Ferguson is misrepresentative, and he knows that. Those people are not eligible for full HCCA, but they are eligible for some.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When will the government allow low income families real choices in determining the priorities of care for their children and attempting to redeem a desperate economic position by working as little as one hour a fortnight? The home child-care allowance is lost once a parent earns more than $242 a year. Is the discrimination inherent in the home child-care allowance yet another example of the government's prevailing scattergun approach of indiscriminate targeting of funds and no real choice?

—It is very difficult to persist with trying to make sense of this when Senator Ferguson repeats that basic flaw in what he is saying. People do not lose HCCA when they earn $242 a year—and Senator Ferguson knows that.
—Start losing it!

—He did not say `start'; he said they become ineligible. And that is the sort of difficulty we are dealing with. That is an outrageous misrepresentation of the facts, and it is no different from what it was under the DSR, as Senator Ferguson well knows. So if he wants to start arguing the facts on these things, he should argue the facts. But, at the moment, we have to once again face the fact that Senator Ferguson would rather go and cause anxiety and confusion out in the community by misrepresenting what this government is doing and not telling the truth. Senator Ferguson knows that. He said it in his supplementary question—directly misrepresenting the facts again. Once non-working spouses earn $242 per year, they begin to lose their full HCCA at four to one withdrawal. Senator Ferguson knows that and he should stick to the facts. (Time expired)

—I address my question to the Minister for Trade. The minister would be aware of highly critical comments by Professor Helen Hughes to the effect that Australia is less internationally competitive now than 10 years ago. In fact, Professor Hughes even suggested that Australian business people travelling in Asia are more interested in having a good time than doing business. Is this assessment of Australia's participation in the Asia-Pacific market consistent with trade performance indicators and with his understanding of Australian business endeavour, particularly in regard to export performance?

—It is rather sad, actually, because I have had a very high regard for Professor Hughes over the years. She has made a very substantial contribution to public debate and to international analysis of economic issues. But I have to say that the current views she is espousing—they have been recently espoused in Brisbane; and I am sure in that way they came to Senator Reynolds's attention—are not new; she has espoused them a few times recently.

PARA.TAB: They seem to have no general acceptance or support. I am pleased about that because they really reflect what I think would probably be an accurate reflection of her experiences in the 1970s and the analysis she did in the 1980s. It may well have been true in those days because our trade performance was not what it should have been. But the reality is that the Australian export caravan has moved on, leaving a long way behind the views which she is reflecting. Australian exports to Asia—and she says we are not being competitive—have grown at an average of 12 per cent over the last decade. Over the 10 years of this government, they have increased at an average of 12 per cent per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —But from a very low base.

—Yes, that is what those opposite left us; but we have grown very quickly since. Thank you; I was waiting for that interjection. Thank you very much. Can I hire Senator Kemp to make interjections all the time? Thank you very much. It was perfect. Thank you. It was a low base, but we have built on it very substantially over the 10 years of this government.

PARA.TAB: Manufactured exports from Australia to Asia have become more diversified—from pharmaceuticals to telecommunications, to catamarans—and, particularly, the growth has been evident in telecommunications. Nobody can say that therefore we should be complacent. But what we can say is that Australian business is very assiduously pursuing its responsibility of exporting into Asia and that the individual men and women who are doing it are working very hard on behalf of their corporations and, as a by-product, serving Australia's interests well.

There are thousands of men and women in employment in factories and in offices around Australia as a result of the export performance of Australian companies, particularly in the area of manufactures where the performance of Australian business is being slighted and it is said we are uncompetitive, in that the export of elaborately transformed manufactures has grown over the last 10 years by over 23 per cent.

I say to Senator Kemp that it is true that those opposite left us with a low base of that also, but it has increased very substantially in the decade since that time and our competitiveness, as a result of the policies of this government, has increased by 30 per cent. By all the different measures, the competitiveness of Australian exports has increased by 30 per cent in real terms over the last decade and the export base is diversifying. So, on the export side, a lot of very good performance is being done and nothing is being done very helpfully—
Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kemp!

—Thank you for calling him to order, Mr President, but he has actually been very helpful. I do not think Australia is helped by people giving 1970s analyses of the performance of Australian business. We have problems now. There is a need for us to do much more. There is a need for our economic performance and our trade performance to improve. But it is not helped by old-fashioned critiques, by people saying that our business people who go overseas are not working assiduously. I do not want to give a rolled-gold guarantee for 100 per cent of them—any more than I would for 100 per cent of members of parliament travelling, I might say. But, in the main, they work hard on behalf of Australia.

I quote the minister's response to this month's Choice article that found that six per cent of parents are forced to send their children to unsafe and unhygienic child-care centres because they do not have access to other centres. The AAP wire this morning reported that the minister dismissed these parents' concerns as a `beat up'. In recent months there have been scathing criticisms of the very few child-care options available to parents by Ms Ann Sherry, former head of the Office of the Status of Women, by the June Auditor-General's report Mind the children, as well as in comments made by participants at the EPAC conference. Is the minister seriously telling the Senate that these authoritative sources are also `beat ups'? Has the minister read the EPAC child-care report herself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very aware of the article by Choice and I am very aware that I also made it clear that I thought its findings were a `beat up'. And I will explain that to Senator Herron. After turning through three pages of criticism, one finds that Choice is fairly praiseworthy and supportive of child care, pointing out that 91 per cent of respondents, as I said, are satisfied and that 95 per cent are satisfied that the people caring for their children are well trained and that the care is adequate.

Senator Herron's question picks up on child care as though it were in total disarray or ruination.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.

—What about the EPAC?
—I will tell you what EPAC says, since you press me. I also point honourable senators to the statement on page seven in a recent EPAC report on child care:

ANSWER.PARA: The child-care industry of today can be praised for the accomplishments it has made over recent years. When we compare our child-care system with others around the world, we rank amongst the best.

None of the opposition senators wants to tell us about EPAC's good report for child care. All they are doing is what the Choice press release did—beating it up. They just want to ignore the fact that it is the government that has instigated these reviews because I am very concerned that we keep on building on what is very good and making it even better, or the best. I do not rest; I am not complacent about child care. We have the places. We have the affordability and we have the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order, the questions asked by Senator Herron were very specific, including the one particular question: `Have you read the EPAC report?' The minister is repeatedly avoiding answering that question. Perhaps you could direct her to answer it.
—The minister is answering the question. I have no way of knowing what she is going to say before she has finished her answer.

—The Australian Law Reform Commission report on the review of child care was released today. I welcome that report and the further recommendations, particularly because the commission so extensively consulted with not only the providers but also very much with the consumers of child care in this country. There were a very broad series of consultations across the country. This very useful report points to areas where we could legislate. Anyone who is seriously interested in child care might like to read it.

PARA.TAB: One of the other things we have done, as I said, is kept child care affordable.

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll send you a copy of the EPAC report.
—It is all right. Those opposite can be smart arses, but I am much more interested in this.
—Oh!
—You have been digging for it Amanda, so you have copped it.
—Mr President, on a point of order: that has to be unparliamentary language. You might suggest that the senator withdraws it.
—It is certainly inappropriate language and I ask the minister to withdraw it. But it is not made any easier, I must say, by the incessant interjections on my left.

—I do withdraw it, Mr President. They are much more likely described as clever cloacas. We have kept child care affordable and, indeed, that is quite contrary to what Dr Kemp, the shadow spokesperson for family services, has to say. He has got his facts wrong, as has Mr Downer, who wants to dismantle child care, or the voluntary accreditation—make it voluntary; take away the compulsory—(Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When is the minister going to take notice of these serious deficiencies instead of erecting this fog of gabbling sound that we get to try to confuse and obstruct us? She did not answer my question. My question was specific: has she read the EPAC report?

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Were any guarantees given in response to representations on behalf of Mr James Peng?

As I said yesterday, I met the chairman of the National People's Congress yesterday morning for quite substantive discussions, where I raised with him Australia's concerns about human rights in China and the need to continue the existing dialogue we have with the Chinese government on human rights. I also urged China to give more weight to the rights of individuals against the state as distinct from the converse in the further development of the legal system for which, of course, Mr Qiao Shi has overall responsibility.

PARA.TAB: On the question of Tibet, I did have, as I foreshadowed yesterday I would, a really rather substantial discussion with Mr Qiao Shi over dinner last night, in the course of which I certainly made clear my view, the Australian government's view, among other things, that it would be extremely desirable for there to be a dialogue between China and the Dalai Lama without restrictive conditions of the kind that Senator Bourne mentioned in her question. TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

—Because that is the way things are done, as Senator Fudd would not understand, with his extensive experience in these matters, I well appreciate. On the subject of China's treatment of Mr Peng, I indicated to the Senate yesterday—but maybe it was only in passing and I should say a little bit more—that I did very firmly reiterate in my discussions with the NPC chairman our long-standing concern about that detention, and in particular our concern that now that he has been charged he be allowed access to the legal counsel of his choice, that he have adequate time to prepare his defence and, of course, that he receive a fair trial in accordance not only with Chinese law but with internationally accepted principles of justice.

PARA.TAB: I further made the point that I foreshadowed that in the event that Mr Peng is convicted we would be requesting clemency on the basis in particular of the length of time for which Mr Peng was detained without charges being laid as well as the circumstances, which were unsatisfactory in many respects, of his detention during that particular period.

I did not get any specific guarantees—I did not expect to—in relation to those particular representations, but there is no doubt whatsoever that yet again at an extremely high level—Mr Qiao Shi being number three in the Chinese hierarchy at the moment—that China has been made acutely aware of the sensitivities which exist on this issue both in Australia and in Hong Kong, and the very strong concerns that we continue to have about this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the minister aware of the concerns raised by the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference, Anglican Archbishop Peter Hollingworth and the Churches of Christ in Queensland conference executive about the wider ramifications of the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill? In the absence of precise definitions and legal precedents and knowing that the court interpretations change over time, I ask: what confidence can the leaders of our largest religious communities have that the sexual conduct bill will not be used in the courts in the future as a mini bill of rights on sexual matters? Can the minister give a guarantee that the churches' concerns are groundless? And has the Attorney-General written back to the Catholic bishops as he promised in his media release dated 27 October?

—I do have some information about this. I cannot say whether the Attorney-General has in fact written back to the bishops but I can find out for Senator Boswell. I am informed that he may have. My advice is that Senator Boswell really has nothing to worry about.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike his other opposition colleague in this place, he probably does not have as much to worry about. But the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill is, as we know, designed to protect the right of adult Australians to make their own choices about sexual practices within the privacy of their own homes. It has been carefully drafted to achieve that purpose. The terms in the bill such as `in private' and `sexual conduct' will be given their ordinary and natural meanings by the courts. In this context, this bill, these terms, are clearly limited to private sexual relations between consenting adults.

PARA.TAB: Laws, for instance, that regulate the termination of pregnancy or the production and distribution of pornographic publications do not fall within the definition of `sexual conduct' in the context of this bill. The bill will only affect arbitrary interferences with privacy. The term `arbitrary' has a well understood meaning in international law. Laws which are reasonable and for legitimate purposes are not arbitrary and will not be affected by the bill.

It is obvious that laws against incest, for example, are simply not an arbitrary interference with privacy. All jurisdictions make incest a criminal offence. Such laws are justified on medical and other grounds. They draw an appropriate balance between the needs of the community and the rights of the individual. Each of these terms, I am assured by the Attorney-General, has been carefully examined by experts in international, constitutional and criminal law. We on this side of the parliament are satisfied that the bill would not have the wide and indiscriminate impact that is being feared by the Catholic bishops. So Senator Boswell can sleep safely at night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now I am really worried! Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Parliamentary Library has advised me that there are no useful definitions in High Court and Federal Court decisions on `sexual conduct', `arbitrary' and `interference with privacy'. Will the minister procure and table existing precedents for interpreting these terms so that the Senate will know what it is voting on when the bill is introduced?

—We can always get advice from lawyers, we can always get advice from the Parliamentary Library, but we have to be able to read it, understand it and apply it to the particular bill before us. We would like to see the advice Senator Boswell has from the Parliamentary Library and the context in which that advice was given. As I said, the advice that we have is that the Catholic bishops have nothing to worry about. I will pass on Senator Boswell's request to the Attorney-General and see what advice he can give him. What does Senator O'Chee want?
—Table the advice.
—I have just answered that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. This time last year the parliament had before it a package of legislation which completely restructured the government's approach to the management and sale of the 3.9 million bale wool stockpile which had accumulated under the reserve price scheme. I note media reports today that the National Council of Wool Selling Brokers is now critical of the approach that has been taken and is calling for changes to the legislation relating to the management of the wool stockpile. Can the minister advise the Senate of the government's approach to this matter?

—In November last year the government put into place new arrangements for the management of the wool stockpile. Those arrangements will see over the period of the next four years a reduction in the stockpile to commercial levels and the effective removal of all government involvement in wool industry matters. I would add that the government's decisions were fully supported by the wool industry and, indeed, by the federal opposition.

PARA.TAB: The most fundamental change was the introduction of a fixed schedule for the sale of the stockpile. The key reason for that change was to bring certainty into the wool market regarding the availability of stockpile wool. That decision removed any overhanging effect of the stockpile on the wool market. Since these new arrangements were put into place there has been a remarkable improvement in the wool market. Undoubtedly the fundamental reason for that recovery has been the increased demand for wool as the international recovery has grown.

I have no doubt that the certainty that now exists in the marketplace about the sales of stockpile wool has also been an important contributing factor in the building up of that market confidence. The government has absolutely no intention of revisiting the question of the stockpile disposal policy. Any such move would undermine the confidence that is now central to the future of the wool industry.

I acknowledge that there is likely to be some tightening in wool supply. Based on the current estimates of production for 1994-95 of 735 million kilograms, plus the stockpile sales of 96 million kilograms for the same period, the total supply is well within the normal 800 million to 850 million range. The tightest part of the market will be in the finer wools, and those are wools that are almost non-existent in the stockpile. These circumstances provide a stimulus to the development of more market and commercially based tools for risk management. This has been recognised by woolgrowers, and I commend the efforts of the Wool Council of Australia in actively taking up these issues. The growth in futures trading and forward buying and selling requires a transparent and predictable stockpile disposal policy. I reiterate that the government will not contemplate any changes to this policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Troeth this day, relating to child care.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crowley said that she welcomed the reports and comments that have been made over the last few months. I would like to draw some of the salient features of those reports and comments to her attention and then ask her if she still welcomes them. For instance, an article in this month's issue of Choice magazine made the point that, although the percentage of unhappy parents was small, their concerns were quite serious. I say to Senator Crowley that if even a very small percentage of parents find child-care arrangements unsatisfactory or a shortfall in conditions that should be regarded as serious by her and her department. The Choice comments also went on to say that the industry is at best fragmented and at worst in an absolute mess.

PARA.TAB: We all know that a loving and caring environment is the most important question looked at by parents when they go to select a child-care venue for their child. We are all conscious that a certain minimum standard type regime as well as constant improvement of the child-care industry should occur. Unfortunately, under the present system quality improvement and accreditation of whatever sort that may be applies only to long day care centres. Those parents who are seeking occasional day care, before or after school hours care or other sorts of care simply do not find that accreditation applies to those centres.

Similarly, the Australian Law Reform Commission and the National Council for the International Year of the Family said that services were not catering for the growing army of part time, casual and shift workers. We all hope that the present, fairly ironclad industrial relations clauses applying to the work force will one day be deregulated and most economic forecasters point to a loosening up of the work force so that there will be far more opportunity for changing work patterns, part-time work, shift work and casual work, especially for parents.

Both these bodies, the Australian Law Reform Commission and the International Year of the Family national council, reported in the Age on 23 August last that they were surprised by the depth of community discontent. I wonder whether Senator Crowley has taken note of this. In Australia today, there are 490,000 under 12-year-old children who need formal care. Of these, 74.4 per cent are not getting any formal care. They are cared for by friends, relatives or neighbours if their parents cannot undertake their care. The rest—that is, something like 25 per cent of under 12-year-olds—receive some formal care but they need more.

The government stresses its commitment to women and to families, and yet it produces the same old, tired statistics to try to cover up the inadequacies of the present system. The economic regime of the present government means that, in many families, both parents are forced to work for financial survival. Those parents depend on affordable, accessible child care. This should be possible, but it is not being provided under the present system.

Briefly encapsulating the many complaints that have been made: there is a significant number of complaints about lack of places, long waiting lists—the average wait is 4 1/2 months according to the Choice survey—little or no access in country areas, unsuitable opening hours and, again, little or no access or very poor access in poorer suburbs and inner city areas. Senator Crowley correctly pointed out that child care is a burgeoning industry. It will receive $1.4 billion in government funding in the next financial year. Senator Crowley's government has had 11 years in which to formulate an accessible, affordable and flexible child-care policy, and it should be doing a lot better.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of child care was dealt with at some length today. Senator Troeth has drawn attention to a number of matters raised in a Choice article. Certainly, it is good to see that this sort of issue is now being given the attention that it should have been given for a very long period and was not. This is largely due to a change of community focus—a change of community focus which has been brought about by the leadership of this government.

PARA.TAB: This government has given child care a priority which has never been seen before. Senator Troeth referred to a Choice article. Though it draws attention to complaints that parents have—I am sure those complaints are valid, and I am sure they can be utilised to make changes which will be advantageous in the future—the reality is that 91 per cent of the parents surveyed indicated that they are either very satisfied or fairly satisfied; that is, only nine per cent of parents were not satisfied. It would be preferable to have 100 per cent satisfaction, but I would be very surprised if it could be said there was 100 per cent satisfaction with many government services provided or many areas of government policy. I will go further and say that it is unlikely that that has ever occurred in the entire history of Australian government.

Only six per cent of the parents surveyed indicated that they were extremely critical of child care. I think it is advantageous to examine the difference in priority given to child care by the previous coalition government and the present government. In 1983, when the Labor Party formed a government, there were 46,000 child-care places in Australia. That compares rather unfavourably with the present position, where there are 247,000 places. We might also look at the allocation of financial resources. It gives a reasonably fair indication of the priority that has been given to child care.

In 1983 the federal government allocated $63 million to this area. That figure has now increased $960 million. Those opposite need to re-examine their view of reality if they complain that that indicates that this government is not giving a proper priority to child care. This government has done more for child care, more for parents, and more for children in need of child care than any previous government, and far and away a great deal more than the opposition has ever considered doing about child care—if it ever considered it at all.

The issue of quality has been addressed by the introduction of the accreditation system; a system which now applies to day care and has, with no assistance from the coalition, developed to a stage where it is working extremely well. The coalition's energies might be more constructively used in indicating areas of improvement rather than trying to say that increasing places fivefold is insufficient and that there are major problems with the policy. Maybe the opposition should be a little bit fair and a little bit realistic about its view of child care and accept that this government has done a great deal.

Obviously there is always room for improvement, but it does not mean that child care is inadequate simply because 75 per cent of people have informal care. The fact that a lot of people avail themselves of informal care is an indication that in some cases that is what is best suited to their situation. The tendency to make that choice, and the need to support that choice financially, has been recognised and acted upon by the introduction of the child-care rebate which provided care, whether formal or informal. I feel very strongly that things can always be improved—and they will be improved in the area of child care. The government has done very well to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —The embattled Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, in her completely inadequate answer to Senator Troeth's question on the cost of child care, referred to me as someone running around the country calling for the abolition of the child-care rebate. Obviously this minister subscribes to the Richardson doctrine of ministerial responsibility: that ministers are responsible for lying. She has completely and utterly misrepresented my position and the position of the coalition on this issue.

—In deference to you, Mr Deputy President, I withdraw. I accuse the minister of grossly misrepresenting my position and the coalition's position on this matter. The coalition made it quite clear in the debate on the child-care rebate that we believe it should be means tested. We are unequivocal and unapologetic about that. The government itself knows that its policy on this matter is wrong and that the child-care rebate should be means tested. There were motions at the minister's own state council of the Labor Party calling for it to be means tested.

PARA.TAB: The community believes that it is wrong for very wealthy women earning high salaries to receive $60 a week from the taxpayers to pay for their child care. It is the minister who has been dividing mothers of young children in this country. She has been running around the country attacking mothers like Carole Carroll, from Senator Crowley's state of South Australia, who have pointed out the inequity and unfairness of the government's policies. Senator Crowley is the one driving a wedge between those mothers who sacrifice an income to stay at home and care for their children and those mothers who put their children in child care.

All we are after in the government's policy is freedom of choice, a fair choice—a regime of policy which assists mothers with the costs of bringing up children, whether they are bringing them up in their own home or whether they are bringing them up in child care of whatever kind. We want fairness and equity between mothers, whether they are bringing up their children at home or whether they are bringing them up in a child-care centre. It is about time the minister and the government stopped trying to divide these mothers and driving a wedge between them and stopped attacking people such as Carole Carroll and her organisation. Her organisation has spread like a bushfire around this country because of the concern about the government's policies.

Much of the debate today has been about the government's accreditation guidelines. Again, we are unapologetic about our concern about the way in which these accreditation guidelines have been implemented, about some of the contents of those accreditation guidelines, about the fact that they are compulsory and about the fact that, if people do not comply, they will lose their fee relief as a result of this government's policies. The government is going to take away fee relief if the centre that the children are at does not comply with this government's regime. A lot of child-care centres have grave concerns about some of the contents of these compulsory accreditation guidelines, which many people have pointed out will grossly inflate the cost of child care and make child care more expensive.

We believe that mothers with young children should be assisted with the costs of bringing up children. We have made that quite clear. We do not oppose that; we just believe that it should be fair. We do not believe the government should be introducing policies which, of themselves, will increase the costs of providing child care. All the private child-care centres have said that accreditation will increase the cost of child care for the parents who place their children in those centres.

The minister is presiding over one of the most unholy messes in this area. The government keeps adding to the mess. It has an unnamed list of policies. We have family allowance, family allowance supplement, child-care relief, child-care fee rebates and the home child-care allowance. Now we are getting the parent allowance. I do not think the government understands it. I know from government backbenchers that they do not understand it. Their constituents do not understand it. The voters do not understand it. This minister is presiding over one of the most unholy messes in social welfare in this country's history. It is about time she sorted it out.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 6 of 1994-95—Efficiency Audit—Australian Taxation Office—Information Technology Security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak very briefly to the report because the Australian National Audit Office concluded in this report entitled Australian Taxation Office—information technology security that overall the Australian Taxation Office is a good custodian of the personal and company information it receives and retains in its computer systems. However, the Auditor-General did make some strong points that, I must say, I am glad to see the Taxation Office has accepted. In fact, it has accepted all of the National Audit Office's recommendations and generally has moved to implement changes during the progress of the audit.

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting that there were some quite serious matters that the National Audit Office drew to the Taxation Office's attention. This is where the improvements have been made. The Taxation Office has mainframe-to-mainframe links to other Commonwealth agencies and operates the child support computer system on a computer belonging to the Department of Social Security. The National Audit Office advised the Taxation Office that it believed the existence of this physical link meant that there was a real possibility of breaches of security occurring, although steps had been taken to limit the potential for such breaches.

The major issues arising from the audit included the fact that bulk taxpayer data was held on computers located in branch offices in breach of ATO security policies which required that all taxpayer data should be held on the mainframe production domain. More importantly, data held on network systems is more widely available and less secure than data held on the mainframe. The ATO was increasingly using equipment based on the UNIX operating system, but had no guidelines or standards for security on UNIX.

Also, special access to production data and programs, termed `firecall', was available too widely and used too frequently. The National Audit Office determined that there were 26,000 uses in two months examined. Change management procedures were deficient and resources used in making system changes were not measured. The present automated tool for tracking system changes, a derivation of an asset management system, is unsatisfactory and the proposal to include change management in a request for tender for a new asset management system is unlikely to produce a suitable solution.

Other issues were that the most senior security body, the National Security Committee, did not meet for almost two years after being formed, and the ATO had no current approved IT strategic plan, although it took steps during the audit to advance the preparation of a new plan. The last ITSP was published in 1988, before the bulk of the modernisation project was commenced.

All this dramatises what a vital job the Australian National Audit Office does. Even where it says, in this case, that the Australian Taxation Office is a good custodian, there are still examples of unnecessary risks being taken. It requires a body like the National Audit Office to have this kind of examination to ensure that these risks are minimised and that there is proper conduct of the affairs of offices, particularly relating to the privacy of Australian citizens.

It is bad enough, many people think, to have to pay tax, without running the risk that one's private affairs may well be available for the information of others if appropriate security is not maintained. We have seen instances in recent times of some public servants and some state bodies having been prosecuted for the release of information which is of a private nature. I commend the Auditor-General for his report and encourage him to maintain the high standard of these reports.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Regulations and Ordinances Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994. I seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Attorney-General
The Hon. Michael Lavarch M.P.
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Senator M Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

I am writing in response to your letter of 10 October, and to the Committee's report on the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994, tabled in the Senate on 17 October. I would like to thank the Committee for its detailed consideration of the Bill, and for its helpful suggestions for amendment.

I note that the Committee engaged the services of drafting counsel, and has attached to its report draft amendments which reflect its recommendations. The drafting of amendments to be moved by the Government is, of course, a matter for the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, which has been provided with a copy of the Report.

Recommendation: "The Committee considers, however, that certificates issued in respect of subclause 7(2) which determine that an instrument is not legislative should be expressly deemed to be disallowable instruments. . . . The Committee also considers that if a subclause 7(2) certificate determining that an instrument is not legislative is disallowed, such instruments should be deemed to be legislative. The Committee did not consider that certificates issued in respect of subclause 7(1), which applies to individual instruments made before commencement day, should be disallowable." (page 4)

The Government accepts this recommendation, and Government amendments to the bill will be moved to give it effect. I note that the draft amendment in relation to this recommendation does not address the position of any instruments which may have been made in the period between the issue of a certificate, and its disallowance. In keeping with the Committee's recommendation, any such instruments should also be deemed to be legislative instruments, and Government amendments to the bill will provide for a short time limit in which they must be registered.

In view of the Committee's concern about the issue of these certificates, a Government amendment will also be moved to ensure that the function of issuing certificates is performed by the Attorney-General personally, and cannot be delegated.

Recommendation: "The Committee would expect . . . that the Government give every assistance to enable the ARC to play a central part in the proposed evaluation of the backcapturing program." (page 4) "The Committee supports the ARC review of [the consultation] aspect of the legislation after three years of operation." (page 5)

The Government will be requesting the ARC to evaluate the operation of the legislation after it has been in operation for 3 years. In particular, it is expected that the ARC will evaluate the backcapturing program which will then have been completed, and will undertake an evaluation of the benefits of sunsetting regimes in practice. The consultation requirements and procedures are an important aspect of the bill's contribution to increasing access to justice, and it is expected that the ARC will give detailed consideration to the effectiveness of consultation, and whether the requirement should be extended.

Recommendation: "The Committee recommends that the bill be amended to provide that the regulations may not modify Part 5 of the bill—Parliamentary Scrutiny of Legislative Instruments, in its application to rules of court." (page 5)
The Government accepts this recommendation and will be moving amendments to the bill to this effect.
Recommendation: "The Committee recommends that the bill provide that the decisions [provided for in clause 17, and subclauses 19(1) and 19(2)] must be contained in the explanatory statement.

The Government accepts this recommendation and will be moving amendments to the bill to this effect. I note that a failure to comply with the requirement will not have an automatic effect upon the validity of the relevant instrument, but will be a matter for the Parliament to consider in its scrutiny of the instrument.

Recommendation: "The bill does not provide for an annual report to Parliament on the operation of the scheme which it proposes. The Committee understands, however, that such a report will be included in the annual report of the Attorney-General's Department. The Committee supports this." (page 6)
The Government accepts the importance of reporting to Parliament upon the operation of the legislation.
Recommendation: "The Committee accepts that [university legislation which affects the content of academic courses] should be excluded from the general terms of the bill and so recommends." (page 6-7)

The Government does not accept this recommendation. The Government considers that university legislation, which affects the rights and interests of many thousands of students and staff of the universities, should, if it is within the definition of a legislative instrument contained in the bill, be covered by the bill.

The draft amendment attached to the Committee's report to reflect this recommendation removes "instruments under section 50 Australian National University Act 1991 relating to the content of academic courses" entirely from the operation of the bill. Section 50 specifies a range of matters which may be contained in delegated legislation made by the Australian National University. The "content of academic courses" is not specifically referred to, nor is it clear from the Committee's report precisely what is envisaged by the term.

I would have great concern that were such an amendment to be made, there would be uncertainty regarding a range of instruments made by the University, which relate in some way to academic courses, as to the requirements for publication and parliamentary scrutiny. Such a level of uncertainty would be disadvantageous to the operation of the University, as it would require an individual decision to be made in the case of every instrument made under section 50, as to whether it would or would not be covered by the exemption, which would delay the process and could leave many instruments vulnerable to challenge, if they are not lodged for registration in the Federal Register of Legislative Instruments.

The Government does not consider that coverage of university legislation by the bill will in any way challenge academic independence. In particular, I note that in most cases matters of the actual content of academic courses would appear to be dealt with by means other than university statutes or rules. I also note that whilst an amendment is proposed by the Committee in relation to legislation of the ANU, the Committee does not recommend a similar exemption for university legislation under the University of Canberra Act 1989, which provides in a similar fashion for statutes, rules and orders to be made by the Council and officers of the University of Canberra, and to which the same considerations would apply.

Recommendation: "The Committee recommends that the bill be amended to extend [clause 27, dealing with the status of the Register and judicial notice of legislative instruments] to include documents printed with the authority of the Principal Legislative Counsel." (page 7)

The Government does not accept this recommendation at this time. I support the widest possible access to the Register, and my Department is currently investigating a number of possible avenues to provide further access to the Register, in addition to the Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops, and on-line electronic access from personal computers.

The issue of the provision of authoritative prints of legislative instruments is, however, a different issue to that of access to the Register itself. Clause 27 is an evidentiary provision, which allows for judicial notice to be taken of the content and coming into operation of a legislative instrument that is printed by the Government Printer. Such prints are necessary for use only in proceedings, and even then, there are many occasions where courts are happy to take notice of legislation on the basis of unauthorised versions, such as those provided to practitioners in loose leaf form by legal publishers. Should a court so require, however, it is vital that there be a definitive printed copy of an instrument.

The AGPS has in place a printing and distribution system for the provision of prints of primary and delegated legislation. It has a network of bookshops, and various subscription series already in operation, and officers of my Department are discussing with the AGPS the modifications to these subscriptions which the bill will require. Many instruments are currently not published at all, or if so, are available only through the relevant Department. Access to the authoritative prints of any registered legislative instrument through the Government Printer, which has a Charter from the Government to publish legislation, will therefore be a vast improvement on the current situation. It is expected that future review of the AGPS Charter will include consideration of how access to printed material such as legislation could be further improved.

Recommendation: "As presently drafted, clause 28, dealing with rectification of the Register, may not permit rectification of a registered copy of a document. The Committee recommends that the bill be amended to avoid this." (page 7)

The Government accepts this recommendation, and will move Government amendments to provide that a discrepancy between an entry on the Register, and the copy of an instrument lodged for registration may be rectified.

Recommendation: "As presently drafted, clause 41, which requires a rule-maker to inform the Principal Legislative Counsel if an instrument was not validly made, would operate so narrowly as to have little meaning. The Committee recommends that the bill be amended to avoid this." (page 7)

The Government accepts that the clause is too narrow in effect. It proposes to move an amendment so that a rule maker will be obliged to inform the Principal Legislative Counsel on becoming aware that an instrument or a provision of an instrument was not validly made. The clause will then operate so that where an instrument or provision of an instrument has been held to be invalid, and the Principal Legislative Counsel is advised of this, whether by the rule maker or otherwise, the Register will be annotated to that effect.

I note that the draft amendment attached to the Committee's report would extend the operation of the provision so that it was triggered by the rule maker's opinion that an instrument was not validly made. This opinion, however, cannot and should not invalidate an instrument, which is a matter for the courts. In my view, it would not be appropriate for the Register to be annotated on the basis of an opinion formed by a rule maker, which has no legal effect. If a rule maker considers that there is a defect in a registered instrument, which has not been held invalid, then the appropriate method of curing the defect is not for an administrative entry on the Register, but rather for the rule maker to revoke and remake the instrument, as is currently the case.

Recommendation: "As presently drafted, proposed section 46B of the Acts Interpretation Act, dealing with disallowable non-legislative instruments, provided for in Schedule 4, would require complex and repetitive provisions to ensure full parliamentary scrutiny of such instruments. The Committee recommends that the bill be amended to avoid this consequence." (page 7)

The Government accepts this recommendation, and will move Government amendments to give effect to it, so that a single provision of enabling legislation may provide that instruments made under various provisions are disallowable under the section.

There are two further matters that I should mention. The first is that the Government will also be moving amendments which exempt Proclamations which commence an Act or provisions of an Act from the disallowance provisions of Part 5 of the bill. The Committee was informed of this in evidence from Mr Morgan of my Department.

Secondly, the subject matter and nature of this bill are such that it should have the fullest possible Parliamentary consideration. I will therefore be seeking to have the bill referred to a House of Representatives committee for consideration after its introduction into that place. In order to allow for such consideration, the Government will be moving amendments in the Senate to defer the commencement date for the bill until 1 July 1995. Each of the cut-off dates in clause 37 of the bill for registration of existing instruments will also be deferred by 6 months.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL LAVARCH
