TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the 6th report of 1994 relating to the upgrade of the transonic wind tunnel at DSTO Fishermens Bend, Victoria, and the 8th report of 1994 relating to construction of a new chancery at Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea. I seek leave to move a motion and make a short statement about these reports.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The first report which I have tabled deals with the proposed upgrade of the transonic wind tunnel at the Defence Science and Technology Organisation's Aeronautical and Maritime Research Laboratory, Fishermens Bend, Melbourne, Victoria. The proposal which the committee examined involved the replacement of a range of components to the transonic wind tunnel, including the compressor system and, most importantly, the tunnel test section. The estimated out-turn cost of the proposed work is $12.7 million at December 1993 prices. The committee has recommended that the upgrade should proceed.

PARA.TAB: The committee sought to establish why Australia needs a modern transonic wind tunnel. The need is based on Australia's self-reliant defence policy. The committee concluded that for Australia to continue this self-reliant defence policy it is necessary for capabilities which depend on aircraft and related airborne ordnance to be maintained and further developed. In this general context, it is essential for Australia to have a modern transonic wind tunnel to provide data on aerodynamic loads of aircraft and stores, such as missiles, to permit their more efficient deployment and life extension.

The committee heard evidence and confirmed that the existing transonic wind tunnel at Fishermens Bend suffers from small test section dimensions and inadequate compressor capacity. Studies undertaken over a number of years revealed that it would be very expensive to construct a new and much larger wind tunnel to replace the existing facility. The alternative proposal, involving the upgrading of the tunnel and using advances in computing, would reduce cost and at the same time provide a facility which will be adequate for our purposes.

Before embarking on the development of the proposed upgrading, DSTO obtained expert advice on its feasibility. The advice confirmed the feasibility and practicalities of upgrading the transonic wind tunnel at Fishermens Bend. Furthermore, the extent of the upgrading of various components of the wind tunnel has been the subject of extensive studies and consultation by DSTO. For these reasons, DSTO is confident that the enhanced capabilities which the upgraded transonic wind tunnel will achieve are adequate for the longer term. The proposal also has the strong support of the Australian aerospace industry and the Australian division of the Royal Aeronautical Society.

A proposed consequence of the upgrade of the Fishermens Bend wind tunnel is the eventual closure of a smaller but, from the evidence presented, very effective wind tunnel at Salisbury. The committee received strong arguments for and against the closure of this facility from the Department of Defence and staff associations representing members at Salisbury. On the basis of the evidence presented to it, the committee is unable to endorse the deactivation of the Salisbury wind tunnel, nor is it convinced that it should continue to operate.

For these reasons, the committee has recommended that an independent study of the desirability of deactivating the Salisbury S-1 wind tunnel should be carried out under the auspices of the Australian Science and Technology Council. The committee has also recommended that the membership of the study panel should include experts in the fields of aerodynamics, engineering and financial analysis.

The second report involves the construction of a new Australian chancery complex in Port Moresby at an estimated cost of $22.26 million at February 1994 prices. The committee again draws attention to the continuing difficulty it faces in assessing overseas projects, as under current legislation it is unable to meet outside Australia or its external territories. Until this legislation is amended to enable site inspections to be carried out overseas, the committee continues to reluctantly give approval for construction of projects which, in its view, it has been unable to properly assess.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pull the other leg.

—I went and looked at the project, using my own travel allowance, as Senator Ray would be pleased to know. I fully endorse the recommendations of those who are putting forward their concerns about the old building. As was seen in Rabaul, there is always the possibility of an earthquake, and the old building is certainly not up to that. In fact, the structure of the present chancery does not conform to the current design codes for seismic performance. That is what I went there to look at.

PARA.TAB: The building requires a major overhaul refurbishment. It does not meet the latest security requirements and was not planned to cater for the present staffing levels and functions of the High Commission. A need therefore exists to provide a new chancery in Port Moresby which will provide a safe working environment. The proposed chancery will comprise the following elements: a new five-level purpose-built chancery; office spaces, display spaces, workshop, storage areas, staff amenities, external plant facilities and services building; a grassed playing area with associated facilities including toilets, showers and change room; staff and visitor car parking; associated site works, services and landscaping.

The committee was advised by the Commonwealth Fire Board that it considered a risk analysis/cost benefit study should be undertaken with regard to fire protection in the new chancery. The committee therefore recommends that such a study be carried out and that the Commonwealth Fire Board and the committee be kept informed of the results.

The Overseas Property Group advised the committee that, although it did not consider an environmental impact study of the site necessary, it will conduct a review of past uses of the site as well as a munitions search. The committee has recommended that it be advised of the results of this survey.

At the public hearing, the Community and Public Sector Union stressed that it would like to continue to be involved in planning of the chancery to the stage where the building becomes operational. The committee commends the Overseas Property Group on its willingness to continue consultations with the Community and Public Sector Union during the planning and construction phases of the project.

I hope that the security arrangements are up to scratch. As we know, the security problem in Port Moresby is rather horrific. That was one of the points that was made to me when I was there. I commend the reports to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: VETERANS' AFFAIRS (1994-95 BUDGET MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: This bill presents amendments necessary to implement the remaining part of the Budget package for the Veterans' Affairs portfolio. You will recall that the first part of the package was dealt with by the Parliament in the Winter Sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: In developing this package extensive, constructive and valuable consultations with the ex-service community were held by me and my predecessor, Senator Faulkner. These consultations were welcomed by both the Government and the ex-service community and it is my hope that we may continue to work together in the future to provide the best possible care and recognition for veterans and their dependants.

The Budget package was developed to address the most pressing needs of ex-servicemen and women, war widows and widowers and their dependants. It responded to issues raised by the Hon Professor Peter Baume, Air Vice-Marshal Richard Bomball, and Ms Robyn Layton in their report entitled `A Fair Go'. It also responded to issues raised by other groups in respect of the ageing of veterans of the World Wars, and the different set of difficulties facing younger veterans.
Mr President, I will now turn to the specific measures included in this bill.

The first initiative will affect service pensioners and income support supplement recipients. The treatment of their compensation payments, such as accident, sickness and worker's compensation payments, will be aligned with the way in which compensation payments received by recipients of comparable social security payments are treated under the Social Security Act. This will ensure equitable assessment of income support payments made by both Departments.
Without going into detail receipt of compensation payments may affect the rate and payability of service pension and income support supplement.

The purpose of these provisions is to prevent double dipping. They only apply where a person receives a compensation payment which includes a component for loss of earnings or loss of the capacity to earn and then only if the service pension or income support supplement recipient is under pension age. The new arrangements will only apply to compensation payments received on or after 1 January 1995.

Pensions that are not for income support are not included in these new arrangements. Already a person in receipt of disability pension or war widows or widowers pension may have the rate of that pension reduced if the compensation payments are paid in respect of the same injury or disease for which the pension is being paid.

Thus, in the case of a person who receives both a disability pension and service pension, any compensation payments which have been used to reduce the payment of the disability pension will not be taken into account again to affect the payment of a person's service pension. Similar arrangements will also apply to a person in receipt of both a war widows or widowers pension and income support supplement.

The next initiative provides automatic eligibility for a funeral benefit to be paid to the estate of a veteran who, at the time of death, was receiving extreme disablement adjustment or was a former prisoner of war.
In a large percentage of such cases a funeral benefit would be paid under the existing rules, but not automatically.

In many cases these veterans leave behind a grieving partner, who will no longer need to forward an application in that time of grief, nor will the partner suffer any anxiety about the availability of the benefit.

Automatic eligibility for funeral benefit already applies to certain other groups of pensioners. The addition of these new groups will provide uniformity by granting a funeral benefit in all cases in which an automatic grant of war widows or widowers pension applies.

Another initiative in this bill will be of benefit to applicants to the Veterans' Review Board. Until now they may have had to meet certain costs of obtaining medical evidence to submit to the Board out of their own pocket. Now they will be reimbursed those costs. They will be entitled to payment of an amount up to $425 for each condition subject to review, as well as an allowance for associated travelling expenses.
Already the cost of certain medical evidence obtained by at the primary determining level may be reimbursed.

The introduction of this change is in response to a recommendation of the Baume Committee. I expect that it will encourage applicants to present their supporting evidence as soon as they can. Currently some applicants appear to withhold evidence until it can be presented at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal because in some cases such costs can be met through Legal Aid grants. By meeting some or all of the costs involved in obtaining this evidence at an earlier stage, it is possible that a decision in favour of the applicant may be recorded earlier. This would avoid the need for many applicants to pursue an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

A further initiative will allow for the payment of an education entry payment to partner and carer service pensioners and to income support supplement recipients. Education entry payments are paid annually to meet some of the costs of enrolling in a course of study. They assist pensioners under pension age to further their education, thereby improving their employment prospects.

The next initiative is of particular benefit to refugees. It will remove the waiting period for service pension for those Commonwealth veterans, allied veterans and allied mariners who were given permanent resident status as refugees. They will no longer need to have been Australian residents for a continuous period of 10 years, nor meet the rules for non continuous periods.

These requirements are being eased because refugees, unlike other migrants, do not have a choice when leaving their home countries. They also experience greater resettlement difficulties and are less likely to obtain a pension from their countries of origin.
Mr President, I am informed that this initiative has been warmly received within those segments of our multicultural society where refugees are represented.
Another initiative will mean that pharmaceutical allowance will only be paid to a person who is in Australia. Short term absences, however, will not be taken into account.

Pharmaceutical allowance was introduced in 1990 to compensate pensioners for the cost of prescription items supplied under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and later the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. These prescription items had previously been free of charge.

A further proposal in this bill affects membership of the Veterans' Review Board. The requirement that a proportion of the members of the Veterans' Review Board be registered or licensed medical practitioners will be removed. This is consequential upon the establishment of the Repatriation Medical Authority and the Specialist Medical Review Council under the first part of the Budget Measures package.

The Repatriation Medical Authority determines questions of medical causation and prepares statements of principle. These are based on sound medical scientific evidence and exclusively state what factors related to service must exist to establish a causal connection between particular diseases, injuries or death and service. A right of appeal against certain determinations of the Repatriation Medical Authority is available to the Specialist Medical Review Council.

The proposal does not affect the terms of appointment of the current medical members nor will it alter the total number of members. Persons with medical qualifications could still be appointed as ordinary members.
Mr President, this bill also contains consequential amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act and other Acts relating to matters dealt with in the first Act of the package.

The consequential amendments relate to the payment of income support supplement, the payment of `single' rate service pension to widows, widowers and non-illness separated spouses and the integration of Australian mariners with veterans under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

In summary, I believe that the measures presented in this bill represent major initiatives which will help to ensure the fair and equitable delivery of repatriation benefits to veterans and their dependants.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994
This small portfolio bill contains three amendments to Veterans' Affairs benefits.
Its major purpose is to increase the age at which female veterans can qualify for age service pension.

The bill also contains two other minor measures—an increase in the maximum rate of the dependent child add-on which is payable to service pensioners for children under the age of 16 years, and the reintroduction of advance pharmaceutical allowance.

The decision to increase the qualifying age for women receiving age pension from the Department of Social Security and age service pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs was part of the Government's 1993 Budget.
Legislation giving effect to this proposal for Social Security age pensions has already been passed.
The increase in the qualifying age will be slowly phased in with the first adjustment occurring on 1 July 1995.

This bill proposes that from 1 July 1995 the qualifying age for age service pension for female veterans will be 55 1/2 years. Thereafter, the qualifying age will increase by six months every two years. It will not be until the year 2014 that the age service pension age for women will be 60 years.
The qualifying age for women will then be the same as the existing qualifying age for men.
The second initiative is also part of the 1993 Budget.

The maximum rate of additional family payment paid by Social Security was increased by $1.00 per week for each child under 16 years of age. This decision was part of a package to assist low income earners and unemployed persons to offset increases in the wholesale tax announced in that year.

Child related payments paid to service pensioners are matched to the rate of Social Security additional family payment. This measure will ensure that the rates continue to be matched by providing that a similar increase will apply to service pensioners with dependent children.
The final initiative relates to the reinstatement of the payment of advance pharmaceutical allowance.

Advance pharmaceutical allowance was paid to chronically-ill pensioners with a high volume of prescription drug use. The advance payment was made from 1991 to 1993. Payments ceased from 1 January 1994 as a result of the operation of a sunset clause.

A proposal was included in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 to extend the sunset clause for a further year. This bill failed to become operative due to the Senate's refusal to pass the bill in its original form. The disagreement of the Senate was not related to advance pharmaceutical allowance.

The initiative in the current bill is to re-introduce advance pharmaceutical allowance payments from 1 January 1995 without the inclusion of a sunset clause. This will ensure that the availability of the advance will be an on-going benefit to veterans and their dependants.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
AEROSPACE TECHNOLOGIES OF AUSTRALIA LIMITED SALE BILL 1994
Mr President, the planned sale of AeroSpace Technologies of Australia Limited (ASTA) is a unique step in the Government's micro-economic reform program.

The process of reform in this case commenced in 1986 when, as the Minister for Defence, I approved the formation of ASTA under the then Companies Code. This started the transition of the Government Aircraft Factories (GAF) from an organisation with a narrow defence focus to an internationally competitive company whose prime interest is in the civil aerospace industry.

ASTA's productivity improvements have been brought about largely by improved work practices and in this regard the Government would like to acknowledge the commitment of the employees of the Company in this transition and the initiative of the new management for its vision and implementation of these important changes.

ASTA has long term contracts to manufacture important components for the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group and Aerospatiale, a member of the Airbus Consortium. It also has a long term relationship with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation through the F/A-18 aircraft program.

The quality of the work carried out by ASTA has been recognised in two ways. Firstly, through ASTA winning awards from the world's prime aerospace companies, such as the President's Award for Excellence from Boeing and by achieving the McDonnell Douglas "Silver" Preferred Supplier Status. Secondly, by being the sole world-wide manufacturer of specific key components for both of these companies.

It needs to be recognised that ASTA operates in industries that have shown distinct cycles of activity. Both the airline industry and the aerospace industry have been in a trough which has slowed orders for the components that ASTA manufactures and that has seen demand for heavy aircraft maintenance decline as airlines defer this type of work. As these industries come out of the trough there should be significant opportunities for ASTA and its new owner.
ASTA currently has an order from the UK Ministry of Defence for 18 Jindivick unmanned jet aircraft—an aircraft originally designed by ASTA's predecessor, the Government Aircraft Factories.

ASTA will work with the preferred tenderer, E-Systems, in the refurbishment of the RAAF's fleet of P-3C Orion maritime surveillance and anti-submarine aircraft. This is a long term project that will bring additional work to ASTA at Avalon and employment to the Geelong region.

Since the formation of ASTA, the Company has established a major subsidiary at Avalon, Victoria. ASTA Aircraft Services Pty Ltd (ASTAAS) was formed in 1988 to conduct major maintenance of wide bodied civil aircraft, such as the Boeing 747.
However, heavy maintenance is a demanding industry which is highly competitive. There are significant challenges ahead for ASTAAS as it seeks to capture work emerging from any growth in the market.

The Government wishes to sell all the Commonwealth's equity in ASTA. Its preference is to maintain ASTA in majority Australian ownership. It wishes to find a buyer, or buyers, able to demonstrate a capacity to provide synergistic benefits to ASTA and able to commit to the ongoing development of a strong, export oriented, domestic aerospace industry.
Passage of this bill will provide certainty for both current employees of ASTA and for bidders in relation to a number of issues that are important in the sale process.

The main purpose of the bill is to ensure that existing Commonwealth legislation applying to ASTA because of its status as a Commonwealth owned entity will cease to apply to ASTA from the sale day. After the sale, ASTA will not, as far as practicable, be subject to Commonwealth legislation which does not govern the activities of private sector companies.

In addition, there are saving provisions to preserve certain pre-sale rights or obligations, for example in relation to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983 for acts or omissions that occurred before the sale day.
The bill makes provision for a separate sale of a subsidiary before the sale of the Company itself should this be necessary to achieve the objectives of the sale.

Employee entitlements, such as long service leave and maternity leave, are covered by awards and enterprise agreements that apply to ASTA and ASTA Aircraft Services Pty Ltd. As with any change of ownership these agreements will continue after the sale.

A major part of the bill applies to superannuation arrangements to ensure that no employee is disadvantaged by the sale if they are relying on service with ASTA to qualify for deferred superannuation benefits. After the sale day, the service of employees of ASTA or its subsidiaries, even if sold separately, will continue to be recognised as public employment for the purposes of qualifying for certain deferred superannuation benefits.

For those employees who transferred to ASTA from the Government Aircraft Factories in 1987 and 1988, the right to apply for jobs in the Commonwealth Public Service as an alternative to taking a redundancy package will cease from the sale day. This is standard practice applied to all Government Business Enterprises when they move into private sector ownership.
The bill makes a consequential amendment to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987 so that no levy will be imposed on ASTA's borrowings after the ASTA sale day.

The primary financial impacts of the sale of ASTA will be the offset to outlays occurring when the sale receipts are credited to the Commonwealth Public Account and the return of any surplus in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Additional Contributions Trust Fund to the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

In relation to employees, no further employer contributions will be received by the Commonwealth from ASTA in relation to those employees who are currently members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. It should be noted that employee superannuation contributions are classified as financing transactions and do not affect the Budget outcome.

In addition, the cost of monitoring ASTA currently met by the portfolio department (the Department of Defence) and the Department of Finance will cease following the sale and the need for any future call on the Commonwealth, such as for capital, will be eliminated.

Mr resident, this bill puts in place the necessary legislative framework to enable the sale of ASTA to be completed once an acceptable sale agreement has been agreed. It will remove ASTA from the remaining Commonwealth accountability arrangements other than those of a normal company and allow the Company to develop with a new owner committed to ensuring that ASTA continues to play an important role in the Australian aerospace industry.
I commend the bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, acknowledging the desirability of avoiding any potential for conflict of interest between the private interests and public duty of Prime Ministers of Australia, the following matter be referred to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee for inquiry and report by 1 December 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether existing disclosure provisions for Prime Ministers are credible and whether Prime Ministers should be accountable for their acquisitions of assets and liabilities while in office, and, if so, to whom, and whether the details to be revealed should be similar to those required of ministers under existing Cabinet rules.

I move this motion because it is now evident that matters of significant principle emerge from controversies that are often wrongly regarded as no more than base political battles. It is not a coincidence that a code of conduct working group set up under the Presiding Officers has been in operation for some time. Members of that working group come from all sides of parliament. Under the chairmanship of Speaker Martin and President Beahan, the working group was constituted to consider whether new codes of conduct should be adopted by each house for senators, members, ministers and office holders.

PARA.TAB: While it is evident that honesty cannot be prescribed, there is no doubt that recent instances of abuse of parliamentary standards by parliamentarians in several state legislatures have contributed to public disquiet about the integrity of politicians. This disquiet has not been eased by observations in the book released recently by Graham Richardson.

The proposal to establish codes of conduct—which I understand will come before the chamber in the near future—quite properly examines questions which have caused concern to the public. While it is evident that it relates to senators, members and ministers, it does not specifically relate to prime ministers. I do not think there is any intention for this, and this is the problem that has emerged.

There is no specific requirement for prime ministers to meet the standards that are required of ministers. Ministers and prime ministers have an additional duty of care to the public of Australia: they exercise considerable power. While this code of conduct working group obviously directs its attention to the proper requirements of ministers, it does not deal with the one loophole that has existed for many years but which has not been a matter of concern because of the way prime ministers have generally conducted themselves.

I will indicate the way ministers are accountable to someone for their interests. It is not just a question of their word being taken. They must reveal to their Prime Minister details of their financial situation—their assets and liabilities. It is quite proper that they should, because when cabinet discusses matters affecting a whole range of areas in which ministers may have, even peripherally, the prospect of getting some benefit, it is vitally important that they be accountable to somebody. That somebody is the Prime Minister. The latest edition of the Cabinet Handbook mentions those requirements. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers in the House of Representatives and in the Senate are required to notify the Prime Minister of their private interests (using the House of Representatives form) on an annual basis. The Prime Minister writes to them with forms and explanatory notes each year. This information is tabled in the Parliament and any substantial alterations should be notified to the Prime Minister as soon as they occur.
And this is the important additional bit:
Ministers also submit a supplementary form to the Prime Minister providing him—
I think it should be him or her in the circumstances—

with more detailed information, including monetary values of interests. This information, which is not made public, is updated at the same time as notification is given of alterations to the primary form.
It goes on:

Apart from these formal declarations, Ministers at meetings of the Ministry, Cabinet and committees must declare any private interests, pecuniary or non-pecuniary, held by themselves or members of their immediate families in matters under discussion, where those interests conflict or might conflict with their public duty as Ministers. Any other matter which may give rise to a conflict between duty and interest must also be declared.
It continues:
. . . declarations should be made in all cases where an interest exists which could not be said to be shared with the rest of the community.
They are pretty wide-ranging requirements. It concludes with:
. . . should any particular conflict between duty and interest arise during the course of their administration of their departments,—
ministers are required—
to inform the Prime Minister so that it can be decided how the particular matter is to be handled.

These are clear requirements for ministers to be accountable. We should recognise that the formal documents provided to these two chambers under the declaration of interests legislation can often be meaningless. No amount is indicated. For example, as far as anyone is concerned, holding BHP shares can be equated to a half interest in a public company. No-one could tell the difference by looking at the declaration of interest form. As a result, as I have said here often, the forms are more misleading than informative.

PARA.TAB: However, the requirement for ministers to reveal all to their Prime Minister means that they are accountable—and it seems to me properly accountable—in a forum where serious decisions involving the exercise of power take place. We have seen how ministers must follow those rules, although the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did not meet those rules when he failed to advise the former Prime Minister of a specific interest in which he invested $430,000 while Treasurer. The fact that those rules can apparently be broken is not cheering, but at least the rules exist, even if they exist only to be broken. The fact is that ministers are obliged to be accountable to somebody.

To whom is the Prime Minister accountable? Himself. Prime ministers have traditionally not taken on additional interests after they have become Prime Minister—or even Treasurer—but they have certainly continued with their existing interests. For example, it was always known that Mr Fraser had pastoral interests, and Nareen was bandied around in the other place quite often. It was known that Mr Anthony had had a piggery for many years before coming into parliament. These things were all known.

The question is: to whom does a prime minister reveal that something has been acquired? The prime minister may have exposed himself or herself to risk and created a situation where there is a potential for a conflict of interests, as indicated in the Cabinet Handbook. The cabinet rules specifically say that these matters have to be revealed because they could create a conflict. Do honourable senators notice the word `may' used continually? `May give rise', `which could not be said' and so on.

It is all conditional. Nothing is proven. It is not a question of whether someone has done right or wrong. The question clearly established in these rules is that, where there is potential for a conflict of interest, that potential must involve the person with that potential being accountable to someone so that that is revealed to someone. In the case of ministers, it is the Prime Minister; in the case of the Prime Minister, it is himself.

This creates a real problem in a situation where the Prime Minister failed in his former role as Treasurer to reveal to his Prime Minister the fact that he had made a major investment. His failure to meet those rules undermines the fact that there is a problem. There is the potential for a problem: when in fact is the Prime Minister himself requiring himself to tell himself what he has done and how exposed he is? As I said, this loophole, this situation which has never in the past really come up because it never appeared to be a situation where this problem emerged, has now been demonstrated to be one where a problem has emerged. It has the potential to emerge.

My concerns are that a Prime Minister should be no less accountable to someone than any of his ministers. Frankly, I do not know whom that someone should be. There have been suggestions that maybe it should be to the Governor-General. Maybe it should be to the Deputy Prime Minister. In fact, I am very attracted to that concept because it would mean that the Prime Minister would be accountable to someone within the political environment, just as ministers within that political environment must reveal their interests to the Prime Minister. Clearly, we cannot legislate for integrity. We can try to limit the capacity for people to behave dishonestly, but we cannot legislate for it. But, if the cabinet rules required the same level of accountability as those ministers have to meet, I believe we would be at least making it fair.

I understand the code of conduct working group, which believes this is a sufficient problem to have been meeting for some time on the matter, is aware of the fact that declarations of interest are the subject of procedures laid down by successive governments and guidance to ministers on administrative procedures and requirements pertaining to the cabinet is provided in the Cabinet Handbook. It is the Prime Minister who enunciates standards and determines the penalty for any failings of his ministers. Who determines the penalty for any failings by the Prime Minister? There must be sanctions in this sense, and that is one of the reasons there is a need for the Prime Minister to be just as accountable to somebody as his ministers are to him.

I recognise that, when we say that ministers must conform to a set of ethical standards more stringent than those required of members and senators as the justification for these additional requirements, it is clear that prime ministers must also conform to a set of ethical standards more stringent than those required of members and senators, and they must be seen to conform to them. There must be a procedure which applies the same sanctions, the same obligations, the same accountability, to a Prime Minister.

This matter of clear principle has emerged not simply from concerns that some of us may have had about the Prime Minister but also from the various concerns that have emerged from state parliaments where various ministers and even premiers—or at least a premier—have shown themselves to be not meeting these specific and high ethical standards that are required of people in public office.

This has not been an issue in the past. It has become an issue. There is a clear gap in the requirements. That is the reason I believe it would be in the best interests of this parliament and of the standing and status of politicians in general that we follow this course of action and ask the committee to look into the best way of handling what is clearly a matter that merits the attention of the committee and action by this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is just a further manifestation of Senator Michael Baume trying to ferret out, by one means or another, information which is none of his business and which is not a matter of legitimate public interest because it is not based on any reasonable ground for concern. This has not been an issue in the past, as Senator Baume rightly says, but nor is it an issue now. It has not been made an issue as a result of Senator Baume's fruitless meanderings over so many months on the subject of prime ministers, piggeries, St Kevins and anything else that he has turned his lascivious attention to. He has not come up with any grounds for concern in the context of any of these matters that he has been trying to hang around the neck of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and there is no larger issue of concern which, as a result, demands, requires or needs attention by this parliament.

PARA.TAB: The motion before us completely misunderstands the basic concepts—no doubt wilfully—and purposes of the system that we now have for the registration of interests. Of course it is appropriate that the Prime Minister and every other minister, and now senators as well as members, should publicly register their interests as required by the resolutions of each house. Those requirements for public registration of course do not go to quantitative detail, but they do require the nature of the interest to be identified—the name of the company in which one has shares and so on. It is sufficient to raise questions of conflict of interest and the potential for conflict of interest if there is any real basis for those concerns. But the detail that is required on the public register has not been thought to be necessarily something that should go further than that.

If there is any question about the adequacy of the details that have been disclosed on the public register, whether it is by the Prime Minister or anyone else, that is a matter for the relevant house of parliament. In the case of the Prime Minister, it is a matter for the House of Representatives; it is not a matter for the Senate.

The more quantitatively detailed disclosure that ministers are required to provide to the Prime Minister is part of the internal processes of the executive government. They are not transparent processes so far as the houses of the parliament or the public are concerned. They are internal processes of the executive government. It is, as a result, entirely a matter for decision by the executive government as to how much detailed information is required to be supplied by whom.

It is entirely appropriate that the Prime Minister, as the leader of the executive government, should require more detailed information of a quantitative kind in order to assist him in particular to make judgments about the proper conduct of executive business, which he of course supervises on behalf of the executive as a whole. That is his job; that is his responsibility.

In determining how cabinets operate, who is appointed to what jobs, and how people should be expected to behave when particular matters come up for discussion in the cabinet room, it is obviously important that the Prime Minister has at his fingertips a degree of detail which it might be necessary for him to have to avoid potential embarrassment for the government. It does not follow that because ministers provide more detailed information to the Prime Minister through these internal executive processes to give the Prime Minister that extra degree of confidence and assurance that he needs in running the government, the Prime Minister himself should be required to disclose that level of detail to anyone else in the system. That misunderstands the nature of the processes that we are talking about here.

I must admit I am very surprised that a motion of this kind, trying to treat the Prime Minister in this way, should come from the other side of the parliament because the Liberal Party has always worked on the Fuhrer principle when it comes to leadership of its own parliamentary party and its role in government. The Fuhrer is identified, for better or worse, and the Fuhrer is then entitled to behave like a Fuhrer, exercising all sorts of divine right until such time, of course, as he is knocked off and the next Fuhrer is installed. That has been perfectly well understood. It has been taken to much further extremes in terms of the allocation of cabinet portfolios and so on than we have ever accommodated or been prepared to think about in the Labor Party.

In this particular instance what we are saying is that it is entirely reasonable and understandable, given the nature of the system we are talking about—which is not a publicly transparent system; it is an executive process system—that the Prime Minister should be able to be treated in a different way. The Prime Minister, moreover, is entitled to a reasonable level of privacy in his own affairs; particularly, I might say again, when the track record of the mover of this motion is not such as to suggest that this is an argument being pursued in good faith on its inherent merits.

If there is any prima facie reason to believe that the Prime Minister is somehow involved in a conflict of interest, of course it is the case—and I have said this on many occasions—that nobody can deny any parliamentarian the right to raise the matter in the parliament or elsewhere to seek an explanation. We are acutely conscious of the need for potential conflicts of interest to be explained and justified, and real conflicts of interest avoided.

We are the ones, after all, who have made so much of the whole business of this register, against the tooth and nail objections of Senator Baume's side of politics and which the opposition has been resisting for years. Again we have a particularly salty brand of crocodile tears being witnessed on this occasion, flowing down the cheeks of those on the other side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Saltwater or freshwater?

—I do not want to get caught up in Senator Panizza's obsession with freshwater crocodiles, but the analogy holds. There is nothing on the recent parliamentary record, public record, or any credible private record for one to believe that there is any legitimacy or seriousness of purpose about this motion. It really is—and I have to say it—just another example of Senator Baume at work with his snout in the slime trough, grovelling and grubbing around down at the bottom of the barrel hoping that something will turn up which he can use to his political advantage. It is what he has been doing for months in this place; in fact, it is what he has been doing for years in this place. Well, it has not turned up, and it will not turn up.

PARA.TAB: Whatever procedural nonsense Senator Baume, the opposition, the Greens, and anyone else in this place who might be minded to support them, feel inclined to get up to, they still will not have anything turning up. The government opposes this motion as the piece of self-evident nonsense that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support this reference because it is an important reference which addresses the question of whether disclosure provisions for Prime Ministers are adequate. It goes to the very heart of the integrity of our political system. We all agree that the political process has to be above suspicion for all politicians. We must all act freely and in the interests of our constituents and the electorate without any pursuit of self-interest or, perhaps just as importantly, without giving the impression or the apparent possibility of being seen to pursue our own self-interest. There should be no conflict whatsoever with our public duties.

PARA.TAB: It is this sentiment which every member of the Senate must support—and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) has just supported it—that led to the setting up in New South Wales of the Independent Commission Against Corruption, ICAC, which has been such an important part of public life since the Greiner government took over in 1988. It is this sort of philosophy—which we all support—that has led to the introduction of disclosure laws at the initiative of the current government.

It is the importance of the transparency of the political process which we all support: that justice must not only be done but be seen to be done, and that lack of self-interest must not only be there but be seen to be there. If this is true of members and senators at large, how much more true is it of ministers who have greater relevance in terms of their extra powers, financial and otherwise.

Indeed, I am delighted that ministers of the Crown are required to conform to higher standards. Ministers are required to inform the Prime Minister of any interests, business or otherwise, which might be of relevance. This is on top of the general statement in which they annually notify the Prime Minister of their private interests. The information which is publicly tabled in that statement is supplemented by more detailed information about their monetary interests, but that is not made public. The details of the ministers' holdings and interests are made available, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate put it, to the executive government for executive government purposes. We support this and we are trying to make sure this applies to the whole of the government.

The issue here is that ministers have a much greater opportunity to disburse financial amounts to various groups and bodies; thus it is very important that they be exposed to absolute complete scrutiny. The fact that this is so important is re-emphasised by the fact that gifts above a certain value—if I remember rightly, a value of $200—received on overseas trips have to be declared. Every senator in this chamber must join with me in applauding these requirements. Certainly the Labor Party seems to applaud them, as do the Liberals. I am sure the Democrats and the Greens would support them; I know that Senator Harradine, a man of such integrity, would certainly support them. These are good and required standards and they are entirely appropriate.

The question we have to face here is: what about the Prime Minister of the day? Contrary to what Senator Gareth Evans has said, this is not an issue of piggeries or snouts in the trough or some of the other activities which he raised. Those are absolutely irrelevant to the question here, which is one of broad principle. Trying to dirty the issue by going into a particular senator's behaviour gets past the whole point, which is that we have to make sure that we have the highest possible standards from every member of this parliament.

The question here is: what about the Prime Minister of the day? Does he or she, as the case may be, have the same requirements placed upon him or her as ministers of the Crown? If not, are the requirements placed upon the Prime Minister appropriate, or should they be altered? I have some very clear views about this. I believe that the whole thing should be at arms-length; that there should be independent trustees to manage the assets and business dealings of ministers and, indeed, prime ministers. This is the case in many overseas countries. It has recently been an issue in the United States where President Clinton has been facing the handling of his affairs with some difficulty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blind trust.

—Blind trust, as Senator Baume interjects. It is an important way of making sure there is no conflict of interest. Indeed, I am delighted to see that the Cabinet Handbook indicates that this is an official view, and I quote section 2.17 as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers are to derive no income through personal exertion other than as Ministers or members of the Parliament and to divest themselves of shares or similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities; and, should any particular conflict. . . arise. . . to inform the Prime Minister.

The question here is: what is the portfolio responsibility of the Prime Minister? As Senator Evans mentioned a few moments ago, the Prime Minister covers absolutely everything. The phrase which Senator Evans used escapes me, but he indicated that the Prime Minister was an overseer of all policy areas. It is very clear that it is important for a Prime Minister to at least make his colleagues aware of any particular interest which he might have which might reflect upon any of the matters being discussed either in cabinet or during any other procedures of government.

PARA.TAB: This is something which we must surely support. We are not necessarily saying that this should be a public document. It may well be—indeed it would seem more appropriate—that it should not necessarily be tabled. I am suggesting that this should be reviewed by the committee so that the committee can make recommendations as to the appropriate procedure; what degree of transparency is needed for the Prime Minister. This is something which surely we must all support.

The broad responsibilities of the Prime Minister mean that the degree of scrutiny placed upon him must be greater than that placed upon individual ministers. The Prime Minister of the day should remove himself from these dealings. What we have to ask now is: What mechanism should be in place to ensure that any particular Prime Minister has no conflict of interest, and is the current mechanism appropriate? Currently, the Prime Minister reports to himself. So, on the face of it, that is entirely unacceptable.

There are a number of other options. He could report to the Governor-General. He could report to an independent ombudsman of some sort or to his deputy. There is a whole range of different options. I do not wish to put forward a preferred option, but simply say that there must be a defined option so we know that what is happening to the Prime Minister is appropriate and that the scrutiny is of a similar degree of intensity as that which is imposed upon his ministers.

We believe this reference will ensure that this Prime Minister and, indeed, all future Prime Ministers will be above any criticism of pushing their own self-interests. If we are to improve the standards of this place, to raise the level of integrity and to raise the perception of that integrity, then this surely must be supported by every member of this parliament, not just the Senate.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate raised whether this was an issue. He mentioned that it had not been an issue in the past and he claimed that it was not an issue. There are certain differences, because the divestment of business interest was a tradition of Prime Ministers in the past. For example, it is probably common knowledge here that when Menzies retired he had so few business interests and so few assets that his business friends had to club together to buy him a house. He had nowhere to live when he left this place. That is an indication of the lack of business dealings of the Prime Minister of the day.

Things have changed since then, and I am not necessarily being critical of those changes. But it is now an issue because Prime Ministers who wish to involve themselves in various business dealings have to make sure not only that there is no conflict of interest, but also that there is none perceived. This is a very important issue for the general electorate—to make sure that there is no cloud hanging over any given Prime Minister at any time.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate said earlier that this is part of the internal processes of executive government—implying that we want to move to some public disclosure of every detail of every asset owned by the Prime Minister of the day. That is not what we are seeking. We are simply seeking for the Prime Minister at least the same treatment that his ministers have to undergo, and have to undergo entirely appropriately. We are not necessarily saying that it should be a public document. My preference is that it probably should not be a public document, but that is something which the committee can decide and report on. As I said, it is not necessarily an important facet of this reference that a public disclosure be made at the end of it.

Senator Evans raised the question of why the Prime Minister of the day should be exposed to this—indicating that he should have more privacy than his ministers. I would take exactly the opposite point of view. The leader of this nation surely must be exposed to genuine scrutiny—scrutiny perhaps by the public, but certainly by his own government and colleagues. If we say to the contrary, then we are simply saying that the Prime Minister has one law for himself and a separate law for everybody else in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Caesar judging Caesar.

—As Senator Michael Baume points out, it is Caesar judging Caesar. Nobody can seriously suggest that this is appropriate. Nobody wants to indulge in a witch-hunt here; we simply want to pursue the matter of integrity of every member of this parliament. It is very important that we try to improve the perception of our standards as politicians. It is very important that we maintain those standards at the very highest level and, in terms of public answerability, make ourselves as answerable as possible. This reference seeks to improve those aspects of our political life. It is one step—perhaps a small one, but nonetheless a very real step—to raising the standards in this parliament. Surely that is something we should all aspire to and, indeed, something we should all support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that, if the Senate is to refer this matter to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee, there is another special case which should also be scrutinised at the same time as the Prime Minister, that is, leaders of the opposition—any one of whom may become the Prime Minister in a very short space of time. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: Insert `and Leaders of the Opposition' after `Prime Ministers' second and third occurring.
The first part of the motion would remain the same. The second part of the motion would then read:

Whether existing disclosure provisions for Prime Ministers and Leaders of the Opposition are credible and whether Prime Ministers and Leaders of the Opposition should be accountable for their acquisitions of assets and liabilities while in office and if so, to whom, and whether the details to be revealed should be similar to those required of ministers under existing Cabinet rules.
If this amendment is agreed to, the committee, following its inquiry, may decide that the words `Leaders of the Opposition' should not even be in there; but it may decide that they should.

PARA.TAB: I will be very brief in my remarks. This motion raises conflicting topics. Accountability is very important and we have always said that; but so, too, is not using a thing such as this reference, especially in the current climate, to achieve a political end. I hope that will not happen. I am not quite sure yet—and I will listen to the further debates in this chamber—whether I am convinced that that would not happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to briefly indicate that the Greens (WA) are supporting this motion. We disagree with the position that Senator Gareth Evans presented, which is that it is not an issue and that it is none of our business. It is quite correct that Senator Evans acknowledged that at any point in time it is the right of parliament to raise questions about the Prime Minister. But it is much better for the parliament to have an appropriate measure of accountability that will prevent allegations and questions without foundation being raised in this place and becoming political.

PARA.TAB: The government is in a difficult position, having argued strongly for disclosure and a register of interests of senators and members, which is quite appropriate in my view, when it has then to argue that it is only members and senators who have to disclose their interests and that the higher degrees of disclosure of ministers to the Prime Minister are also appropriate for accountability reasons, but that there is nobody to whom the Prime Minister is accountable.

Independent accountability measures are important. There is grave criticism when the police are seen to be investigating the police. In all other areas, we view with suspicion the accountability measures that are designed internally. The Prime Minister's office is one where those kinds of suspicions are not productive or in the public or national interest. If the Prime Minister needs greater detail of his ministers for his accountability and responsibility reasons, then there is as great a reason for him to have some kind of mechanism.

It is difficult to address that problem. I am part of a working group which is working in a similar direction. It is trying to devise a code of conduct for members, senators and office-holders. While I do not want to pre-empt the debate that will come up when the results of that committee's operation are debated in the Senate, my experience in working on that committee is that it does not overlap the need for this reference. It is doing a very constructive and helpful job of assembling some guiding principles that are applicable to everybody. My understanding is that they are also applicable to the Prime Minister because they deal with office-holders of every kind, including party leaders.

The limitations of that committee, which have been noted, are the ones that become relevant when we consider the reference of this topic to a parliamentary committee. In relation to the code of conduct of members of parliament, because it is a parliamentary meeting, it is clear that it is not a parliamentary committee. There are no public hearings. There is no parliamentary privilege which applies to submissions and the inquiry is not able to respond to individual and specific issues. So there is a good case for saying that, to complete the picture and to remove any grounds for concern about conflict of interest, it is appropriate to have measures of accountability that we can apply to the highest office in the land. I support Senator Bourne's amendment because I agree that, within a very short time frame, if an election occurs, a leader of the opposition may become the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not this one.

—Not necessarily but it is possible. There is another reason why it is valuable to have it in the terms of reference and that is to address the understandable concern expressed by Senator Gareth Evans that this could become a witch-hunt, a trawling exercise, which the opposition refuted.

PARA.TAB: If the opposition is acting in good faith, which I believe it is, then it will be quite happy to accept the amendment relating to the Leader of the Opposition as well. That will prevent any one-sided mechanism being decided upon by this committee that may have a political overtone. If it has to apply equally to the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Opposition in the light of that possibility, that should reassure the government that any measure will be designed on a balance and not on a party political basis. I certainly do not support anything that would be on a party political basis; but I do support something that assures the wider community of Australia that no-one in this country is unaccountable and that, certainly, the highest office-holder in the land does not escape from that degree of scrutiny and accountability that he gives within his own cabinet to his own ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really do not know what the problem is about this particular motion. I heard what Senator Michael Baume and Senator Gareth Evans had to say. The motion that is before us acknowledges, or attempts to get the Senate to acknowledge, the desirability of avoiding any potential for conflict of interest between the private interests and public duty of Prime Ministers. I would only vote for this motion if it was entirely de-linked from any allegations that may have been made in respect of an individual.

PARA.TAB: Thus, I find myself able to vote to acknowledge the desirability of avoiding any potential for conflict of interest—and I would have thought everybody would vote for that. It is just referring a matter to the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee for inquiry and report. What is that matter? It is whether existing disclosure provisions for Prime Ministers are credible and whether Prime Ministers should be accountable for their acquisitions of assets and liabilities whilst in office and, if so, to whom and whether the details to be revealed should be similar to those required of ministers under existing cabinet rules.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, on behalf of the government, raised the question of whether the mover of the motion actually realised what was behind the disclosure provisions for cabinet ministers to the Prime Minister. I doubt he won that case at all. In fact, if there was a problem in regard to that matter then it could be discussed at the hearings and discussions of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee which in turn could present its findings to the Senate. So, really, I do not think there should have been such an enormous debate about this particular matter.

As to the amendment proposed by Senator Bourne, again, on the face of it I cannot see any problem with that. It is in a different ballpark, I suppose, but then no doubt the committee will consider that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the amendment moved by Senator Bourne because I am quite prepared to accept it as part of the motion. I am not at all fazed by it. We have nothing to hide. I would just point out, though, that it indicates a total lack of understanding of the thrust and purpose of the motion because it is the exercise of power that provides the potential for conflicts of interest, not the hope that one can exercise power. In fact, the Leader of the Opposition is someone who simply hopes to do so.

PARA.TAB: However, that irrational and absurd part of the amendment—I am quite happy to incorporate it in the motion—will be dealt with by the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee, and it can determine whether it regards it as irrational and absurd. It was open to me, for example, to insert, `and the Leader of the Australian Democrats, so long as they maintain their status as a party' after the words, `Leader of the Opposition'. That would be equally absurd. I am not going to do it. The Australian Democrats, I presume, will not have the opportunity of exercising their power in an executive sense; but they certainly do have the opportunity to exercise their power in a parliamentary sense, as both the government and the opposition know only too well. The point is that it is the exercise of power in an executive sense that creates the potentials for conflict of interest, particularly when there is a lack of accountability.

I take the points made by Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine; they are very much to the point in general. But I would like to conclude by expressing my great disappointment not simply at the position Senator Gareth Evans has taken on this matter but the manner in which he dealt with it. It is, I believe, a reflection on himself that he dealt with this matter of principle by accusing me, for example, of trying to `ferret out' information through this motion to which I am not entitled. There is no suggestion that I would be the recipient of information, unless I were to be the person to whom the Prime Minister reported his or her interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fascinating.

—As my colleague Senator Woods says, that might be a very good idea. And I must say, if there is a job opportunity in that direction, it would probably be better than an opposition backbencher. But the fact is that Senator Evans chose to respond to this matter of principle by the perpetual personal abuse of me that has been a feature of his conduct ever since I began raising various questions which, the Senate will note, I have not discussed in this debate. I had hoped that this debate might be above the political point scoring and personal abuse that Senator Evans revels in. I am disappointed that Senator Evans, once again, is incapable of discovering a matter of principle, and I would underline this matter.

PARA.TAB: The members of the New South Wales right wing of the Australian Labor Party have a capacity for what is loosely described now as `doing a Richo'. Quite frankly, there are many members of the right wing of the New South Wales Labor Party around this place and I would think that, if there is anything that requires this parliament to make certain it increases the standards of behaviour and the accountability of members, it is the revelations of Richo about the extent to which he was `doing a Richo', and the extent to which that was known by his colleagues in the New South Wales right wing of the Labor Party who are members of this government's cabinet.

If Senator Evans wants to give me a little backhander, all I can say is I think it is unwise and unbecoming of him. The fact is there is a need for us to ensure that public awareness of accountability of parliamentarians is enhanced and the reality of public accountability is enhanced. That is why I am certainly prepared to incorporate in the motion, if that form is acceptable, the moderately unwise, but nonetheless acceptable, amendment by the Democrats. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 11 October, on motion by Senator Margetts:

That the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No. 259 and made under the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act 1987, be disallowed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is an agreement between the government and the opposition, and we will be opposing Senator Margetts's motion of disallowance. The government will be introducing a further amendment over the next couple of weeks to deal with the specific issue of the movement of waste material located at the St Marys site to the Lucas Heights research laboratories. We believe that the new amendment will be an appropriate way of dealing with this issue.

—The Australian Democrats will be supporting the disallowance motion moved by Senator Margetts. As I have outlined in my dissenting report to the report of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, it is not sufficient for the government simply to draft these revised regulations as outlined in the report.

PARA.TAB: The most important point is that by section 7A—which was placed in the act in 1992 against the objections of the Australian Democrats—ANSTO has been given immunity from relevant state laws governing land use, planning, the conduct of hazardous activities and the protection of workers' public health and environmental safety. That means that the treatment and transporting of nuclear waste is done in a way which could put at risk members of the community at and near St Marys and on the way when the material is being transported. I think it is totally inadequate to allow this work to proceed without providing the community with the protection that it deserves.We are not talking here about a couple of boxes of matches, we are talking about nuclear radioactive material.

It is also quite wrong to state, as was stated during the inquiry by one of the witnesses, that the New South Wales Environmental Protection Authority could be relied upon to assist in supervising these transactions. What is quite clear is that section 7A of the act excludes the EPA from doing precisely that. The EPA has no role in supervising what happens to the nuclear waste. It is on that basis that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the disallowance motion.

We believe there is absolutely no reason why the government cannot overcome this particular difficulty by an amendment to the principal act. If all parties agree—and I find it difficult to believe that any party in this house would be sanguine about depriving the community of these safeguards—an amendment to the act could be passed within 24 hours. So why not proceed on that basis instead of going through all the contortions and arguments about the legality or otherwise of a regulation, and whether the power of the act provides a basis for these regulations.

There is some doubt about one of the other regulations which the government is now prepared to draft even though the government strenuously opposed it during the committee hearings. There is clearly no possibility of drafting a regulation as I have suggested to suspend for this operation the immunity of ANSTO from state safety and health regulations. But as I said, there is no reason whatsoever why the act cannot be amended so that the immunity is lifted just for this operation. If that were done, the Australian Democrats would not support the disallowance motion. But since no move has been made by the government, and following inquiries to the minister's office which I made earlier today there was a very clear statement that the government would at this stage anyway not consider such a move, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The referral to the Senate committee seems to have served a very useful purpose. Mr Deputy President, you will recall that when the matter was last before the Senate there were differing views as to whether or not the regulation could be drafted in a more restricted form. We had expressed concerns on that occasion that the regulation that we were being asked to support would in fact allow ANSTO and the government much greater discretion in relation to treatment and transport of nuclear waste than what the government said was the purpose of the regulation. In particular, the government claimed that the purpose of the regulation was to allow it to remove waste from St Marys in Sydney to Woomera for temporary storage and, if it proved necessary, to transport some of that waste from St Marys to Lucas Heights to be put in a safer form for transport across Australia to Woomera.

PARA.TAB: The regulation that we had before us, it seemed to us, would enable the government to transfer any waste to Lucas Heights, which is something that we thought would be undesirable. Certainly at the beginning of this negotiating period it was unlimited in time—so this was an ongoing facility that was being sought by the government when in fact that was not what was being claimed was wanted—and it could relate to other than St Marys waste.

Our position was that we accepted that the material that is at St Marys should be removed from the suburbs of Sydney, and we have reluctantly accepted that it be stored temporarily at Woomera. You will recall, Mr Deputy President, that our argument has been that the government should provide the permanent facility repository that it has been promising for a long period, and that is where the waste should be headed. But it has not kept that promise, and such a facility does not yet exist, and there is urgent need to remove it from St Marys.

We were concerned about the need to transport it to Lucas Heights for further conditioning. We had trouble with the government's argument that it might be unsafe to transport it from Sydney to Woomera, but it is apparently safe to transport it from St Marys to Lucas Heights for further conditioning, the argument being that the facility for processing or in some way making that waste safe for a longer journey is only located at Lucas Heights. But we do recognise that there is a problem here. We said from the start that if the government were to be cooperative and drafted this regulation in a form that met our concerns—in other words, the government would be restricted to the purpose for which it claimed it wanted the extra regulatory power—then we would support it.

Before the Senate committee Professor Pearce gave helpful evidence which in the end, it seems, was accepted by the majority of the committee, although Senator Spindler is saying that during the course of the inquiry the government representatives may have argued against its acceptance. Nevertheless, that advice was accepted. The effect was that the regulations could be redrafted to define the radioactive waste that can be conditioned, managed and stored by ANSTO as the waste that is stored at St Marys on 1 November 1994. I understand that the government now accepts that and by its letter dated 8 November, under the signature of Senator Cook, has said that it is prepared to introduce an amending regulation if the Senate votes against the motion of disallowance:

SPEECH.PARA: It is proposed that the amending regulation which will cease on 31 December 1995 will be restricted to conditioning of the waste material located at the St Marys site as of 1 November 1994.
Therefore, the government has accepted that it is valid to draft a regulation with that restriction and has given an undertaking to do so.

PARA.TAB: The government has further said in the letter that it will continue the promise that it had given earlier—namely, to accept a sunset clause which means that waste must be treated and dealt with by 31 December 1995. We think that is in the interests of Sydneysiders. Although Professor Pearce advised that it would not be possible by regulation to deal with the issue of the transfer to Lucas Heights, the government has said that it would be prepared to give notice to the relevant local government authorities and to us—in other words, to the parliament—of its intention to transport the material to Lucas Heights, if it turns out that such transport is necessary. We think that is a not unreasonable compromise in circumstances where we also want to get the material out of St Marys to Woomera as soon as possible.

The only reservation that we have concerns the issue of transporting the material from St Marys to Lucas Heights. We would prefer that that not occur. There is, however, a dilemma that we accept. If the material can only be made safe for the long journey by a process that is available only in Lucas Heights, we accept that it will have to be transferred to Lucas Heights for that purpose. We have undertakings that that option will be adopted only if there is no other alternative—in other words, that material will not be transferred to Lucas Heights if there is another alternative. The preferable alternative clearly is that it be made safe for transport at St Marys.

We could have supported the motion for disallowance and therefore stopped ANSTO from having that option to transfer the material to Lucas Heights, but it seemed to us that was rather futile because the government could by a private contractor transport the material to Lucas Heights where ANSTO would be able to deal with it. There did not seem to be much point in continuing to pursue that argument. So the compromise whereby the local communities will be advised of any intention and have time to take such action as they might think appropriate—which presumably in the case of the local authorities includes political action—we think is a quite positive achievement out of what has been a relatively long and difficult negotiating process with the government. Certainly the people of Sydney will have the advantage of getting this material out; they will not suffer the risk of further material being brought in. They know that ANSTO will be limited to dealing with the material at St Marys, and that if it has to be transported to Lucas Heights they will have notice of such intention to transport. In all those circumstances we are now prepared to allow this regulation to stand and will not be supporting the motion of disallowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —For similar reasons I do not feel disposed to continue my support for the disallowance motion. It is indicative of the merits of the committee system that these matters were able to be discussed in such detail. One thing that concerns me is that the government has not acted to bring in an amending regulation. However, no doubt if it does not do so forthwith, the Senate can revisit this matter in a substantive manner.

PARA.TAB: So far as poor old Woomera is concerned, about the time of the atomic tests I was working on the railways to Alice Springs and to Kalgoorlie and a relative of mine lived near Woomera. He has in his possession details of the way the wind was blowing and also a note that the radio bulletin said with great confidence that the wind was blowing in a certain way, when in fact it was blowing in another way. I have had a great deal of suspicion ever since in regard to these matters, which are matters of life or death.

In talking of life or death issues I am also conscious of the importance of nuclear medicine in various areas. I am diverting a little from the matter at issue, but I raise that matter because the government has not determined on a permanent site for this waste material. We should keep on the government's hammer in regard to that. Who knows—there may be somebody who is yet to be born or somebody now who will come up with an invention that will ensure the most effective means of disposing of this waste that has not yet come about. When I say `most effective', I mean most permanent and in the safest manner. No disposition of this material will be entirely safe as the state of technology now is. I urge the government to attend to that matter and keep reporting to the Senate on how it is going with the task of finding a permanent position for the disposal of this waste in the most effective manner that is available.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

CANBERRA ACT 2600

Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
