SENATOR THE HON. CHRIS SCHACHT
MINISTER FOR SMALL BUSINESS, CUSTOMS AND CONSTRUCTION
21 September 1994
Senator Robert Hill
Shadow Spokesman on Science and Technology
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator Hill
I am writing to you on behalf of the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology who, as you are aware, is ill.

Senator Margetts has given Notice of Motion to disallow the Regulations under the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) Act 1987 presently before the Parliament. I trust that the Opposition would support the Regulations as gazetted, should Senator Margetts not withdraw her Motion.

I wish to confirm that the intention of the Regulations is to enable ANSTO, as the Commonwealth's specialist nuclear technology arm, to undertake the work of conditioning a quantity of radioactive wastes presently stored at the site of the former St Marys Munitions Factory in western Sydney. The wastes arise from various past activities of the Commonwealth and are managed by Australian Defence Industries (ADI) on behalf of the Department of Defence. The wastes must be moved to allow ADI to clear and redevelop the site as it proposes to consolidate its operations elsewhere. Conditioning will immobilise the wastes to make them safer for transportation and ANSTO is the appropriate body to undertake the conditioning. It is intended that the wastes will be conditioned at St Marys.

I am advised that you may have some reservations that the Regulations, as gazetted, do not restrict ANSTO to this specific waste. The ANSTO Act requires that the Regulations specify persons on whose behalf ANSTO may undertake the conditioning, management and storage of radioactive materials and radioactive waste. The Regulations are necessary if ANSTO is to be permitted to undertake any of these activities in respect of the waste at St Marys, irrespective of the radioactive materials or wastes concerned, their origin, or the site at which the activities are to occur. The Act contains no provisions to limit the application of the Regulations to particular activities, materials, wastes or sites. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that the present form of the Regulations is correct, given the requirements of the Act.

An effect of the present Regulations would be to permit ANSTO to undertake similar work on behalf of the Commonwealth should such a need arise in the future. A list and description of Commonwealth/State radioactive waste holdings is attached. This list is taken from the National Resource Information Centre's Phase 1 Report on A National Radioactive Waste Repository for Australia (1992).

You will note that, apart from the waste at St Marys (which amounts to approximately 10 cubic metres by volume), the only other Commonwealth waste to which this Regulation could be applied is the remainder of the Defence waste (about 50 cubic metres).

I wish to confirm the assurance I gave you earlier today that the current Regulation is not intended to authorise conditioning of the remaining Defence waste, but should a need arise—for example, for transport to the proposed national low-level radioactive waste repository when it is established—then the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology will consult with the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate prior to any action.
Of course, separate regulations will be needed if ANSTO were to undertake such work on behalf of other legal entities, such as Commonwealth statutory authorities or State government bodies.

It is possible that some of the waste at St Marys will need to be transferred to ANSTO's Lucas Heights Research Laboratories (LHRL) for treatment in the specialised facilities at that site, although I am advised that this is considered highly unlikely. Nevertheless, you have my assurance that should this happen, the wastes will be held at LHRL only for the time necessary for conditioning and will be returned to St Marys as soon as possible. Similarly, should any of the remaining Defence waste require conditioning at LHRL in the future, we would ensure that it will only remain there for the time necessary for conditioning. As you would be aware, it is proposed to move the St Marys waste to the Woomera Rangehead for interim storage, a move which on present indications is likely to be completed by the middle of 1995.

Your endorsement of the Regulations would be appreciated, as ANSTO will be unable to undertake any action in respect of the waste at St Marys if the Regulations are disallowed. It would be a perverse approach to the safe management of the waste if action is taken by the Senate to disallow the Regulations.
Yours sincerely
CHRIS SCHACHT

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will not speak for long on this matter, but I want to mention that I had heard there was some kind of implied or specific threat from the government in relation to bringing in a private contractor if the government did not get its way in this regard. I would like to express my horror at that method of negotiation because the level of accountability in relation to such things as the transport of nuclear material was being very deeply discussed. We discussed in detail the fact that ANSTO and ADI through this process, because they could not reach the standards that had been set or promised, were given exemption from the normal rules, regulations and laws of the states so that they could continue their operations.

PARA.TAB: If there were a private contractor, what kind of scrutiny would there be? Would that contractor also be exempted? Perhaps we should have let it go ahead. Perhaps a private contractor would have been subject to the kind of public environmental scrutiny that is missing from this process. That is something I would like to throw into the ring on behalf of the public. Those exemptions remove bodies further from public accountability. What kind of built-in safeguards do the public have and what kinds of responsibilities does this show the government is enacting on this kind of serious matter?

I would also like to express my surprise that the first recommendation of the committee is contrary to recent precedent in this place with respect to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. I remind committee members that on 17 October 1994 the Senate passed a motion that rescinded a disallowance of regulations under the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993 `to allow a new regulation to be made which would be the same in substance as the disallowed regulation'. I can only wonder whether there is another reason for not wanting these regulations disallowed.

I would like to acknowledge the work of the committee in coming up with a proposal to amend the current regulations to at least partly address the concerns of the community in relation to the proposal to condition the waste at St Marys and transport it to Woomera. I must say, however, that the amended regulations will not be sufficient to satisfy the concern of the Greens.

There remains a fundamental concern about the increased risks associated with the handling and transport of nuclear waste at St Marys. There is no question that, from a risk management perspective, this increased risk is not offset by any lessening risk at the ultimate destination at Woomera.

The St Marys site, to my understanding, is well protected and the waste is securely stored in above-ground concrete bunkers. The Woomera site, to my knowledge, is not acknowledged by the government as the site for a permanent nuclear waste repository. I can therefore see no logical reason why the waste at St Marys should be moved at this time, when the government is supposedly moving towards the establishment of a permanent nuclear waste repository site. The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Let me outline to the Senate the history of this very tragic incident and the chronology of events that followed.
On 12 March 1990 RAAF Nomad A18-401 crashed near Mallala in South Australia, tragically killing its only occupant, the pilot, Flight Lieutenant Glenn Donovan.
This Nomad was one of the last 14 Nomads transferred to the Australian defence force in late 1987 from stock held by the former Government Aircraft Factory (GAF)

PARA.TAB: now the wholly owned government business enterprise, Aerospace Technologies of Australia (ASTA).

SPEECH.PARA: It was one of two used Nomads which was assigned to the Aircraft Research and Development Unit (ARDU) at Edinburgh in South Australia.

At the time of this transfer decision, the two used aircraft were being operated by ASTA in product improvement trials. The aircraft that subsequently crashed, had been built in 1982 and used by GAF for various trials, accumulating just a few hundred hours in flight.
However, unusually, that aircraft had undergone extensive ground running of the engines, perhaps accumulating as much as half again the number of flying hours.

ASTA requested a loan back from the RAAF of the two used aircraft to continue the trials program. This was agreed and ASTA maintained the aircraft as though they were civil aircraft throughout these trials.
Defence took deliver of the older aircraft in March 1989 and subsequently the accident aircraft in August 1989. Both were flown from the factory at Avalon direct to Edinburgh as military aircraft.

It should be noted that military Nomads are maintained differently to civil Nomads, generally by inspecting and replacing components more frequently because of the more severe usage associated with military operations.

On arrival at Edinburgh the first aircraft was serviced and because of the large number of flying hours, the cost of restoring this aircraft to RAAF standards was judged to be prohibitive. It was not flown again, and has since been written off.

The apparent condition of Nomad 401 was much better. The aircraft and engine log books revealed the relatively low number of flying hours and that the aircraft had completed a major servicing at ASTA just 11 flying hours before RAAF acceptance.

The aircraft was flown by ARDU pilots between August 1989 and March 1990 on familiarisation flights. It accumulated just nine more flying hours but a propeller unserviceability required nearly six more hours of ground running.

Under the RAAF maintenance system, if a Nomad has not had a major inspection within the last 12 months, a special servicing is required to check for deterioration. On the 6 March 1990 Nomad—401 became due for that special servicing.

Because of a misunderstanding by maintenance staff, the servicing was not carried out. Two RAAF pilots flew the aircraft on the morning of 12 March and reported no problems. Flight Lieutenant Donovan then continued to fly the aircraft alone until the tailplane failed in flight and the aircraft crashed.

After the crash an RAAF accident investigation team (AIT) was appointed within hours of the crash to investigate the wreckage and determine quickly whether any endemic airworthiness problem existed. The investigation team included a professionally trained RAAF aircraft accident investigator and a Bureau of Air Safety investigation inspector.

It was immediately apparent that the aircraft tail section had broken away in flight. Within 24 hours all Nomads, both civil and military, were grounded. The AIT concluded its investigation 15 days later, finding, amongst other things, that:

PARA.TAB: neither the pilot nor environmental factors such as the weather were causal factors in the accident;
the obvious cause of the accident was the separation of the empennage (that is, the tail section) from the aircraft, caused by structural failure of the horizontal stabiliser carry-through box; and
there was no evidence that the structural failure was caused by exceedance of the aircraft's design limits during the final flight.

SPEECH.PARA: The investigation team concluded that the tailplane spar assembly of Nomad 401 had been extensively cracked before the last flight, and that these cracks would have reduced the strength of the tailplane sufficiently to cause failure under normal operating loads.

Extensive ground running by ASTA was carried out prior to handover of the aircraft to ARDU. In the absence of any other unusual event, the accident investigation team speculated that the cracking of the carry through box was exacerbated by the extensive ground running, but recognised that further testing would be necessary to check this hypothesis.

It was found that the handling of the aircraft's documentation, including its servicings, modifications and special technical instructions by ASTA and the RAAF during the transfer of ownership and subsequently loan back to ASTA was less than satisfactory.
The effect of this, coupled with less than adequate direction from higher command, culminated in ARDU operating Nomad 401 without the extensive cracking in the tailplane being detected.

The accident investigation team recommended that the air force be tasked to initiate testing to establish the loads experienced by the Nomad tailplane during engine ground runs, and that the data derived be used to ascertain the speed of propagation of cracks in the tailplane. As well, the AIT recommended that, if that testing so indicated, a policy regarding the ground running of Nomad aircraft be formulated.
There were other recommendations to establish the history of all Australian defence force Nomads and audit all relevant documentation for errors, omissions and anomalies.
The day after the crash a RAAF Board of Inquiry (BOI) was convened to look into all aspects of the accident. It took evidence from 49 witnesses, including the investigation team members.

The BOI was given 32 terms of reference, covering the primary and contributory causes of the accident and any aggravating conditions. The board was also required to report whether any person involved was guilty of negligence or in any other way to blame, or made an error of judgement, or contravened any order or instruction.

The original board president appointed on 13 March, a squadron leader, soon identified that there were implications for persons above his rank and so, in accordance with RAAF legal procedures, a new board president at group captain rank took over. Within a month, the board had taken evidence, not only from the RAAF but also from ASTA personnel, regarding the accident and the treatment of the aircraft during its life.
The president presented to the Air Commander of Australia, a 48 page report which analysed the evidence and provided the reasoning for the board's findings and recommendations.

The report stated that the primary cause of the accident was the aircraft commencing the flight with extensive cracking in the horizontal stabiliser box beam. This cracking weakened the box beam to the point where it could not sustain normal inflight loads. As a result, the box beam failed in normal flight. The resultant rapid fracturing allowed the whole tailplane to separate from the aircraft.
A list of possible aggravating conditions and comments on the blameworthiness or otherwise of individuals were contained in the statement by the board and its conclusions.

This report was passed to the Air Commander on 12 April 1990, just a month after the accident. Apart from the legal aspects of the report, clearly the Commander had some major technical and procedural engineering problems to grapple with.

At the Air Commander's request, the Chief of the Air Staff directed an independent assessment of the engineering circumstances, which was completed in May 1990. This further substantial report confirmed the primary cause of the accident and noted some shortcomings in the RAAF policy and procedures for acquisition of used aircraft.

It also confirmed that there were individual errors which may have led to opportunities to detect the unairworthy condition of the aircraft being missed. At that time the reason why the tailplane had cracked in the way it did could not be positively ascertained, as extensive testing of an instrumented tailplane was yet to yield results.
The recommendations by the Board of Inquiry and the independent assessment were generally accepted by the Chief of the Air Staff who directed remedial action.

That action has been completed except for the formal issue of RAAF's airworthiness manual, publication of which is imminent. This manual provides guidance for the certification and release of aircraft new or used into service, and for action needed to ensure continuity of airworthiness requirements when ADF aircraft are loaned out.

I think that it is important to note at this point that some cracking in Nomad tailplanes was a well known characteristic which was controlled by periodic inspections and replacement of horizontal stabilisers. Experience had shown that inspections were sufficient if performed every 100 flying hours or so, and typically an aircraft flew many thousands of hours before the horizontal stabiliser had to be replaced.

What was incredible to airworthiness experts was that the tailplane on NOMAD 401 had failed completely just 20 flying hours since it was last inspected, and after only a total of 433 flying hours since manufacture. Only later testing of the ground running loads revealed how severe this mode was in damaging the Nomad horizontal stabiliser.

Testing of the Nomad structure is continuing, but the propensity of the original design to crack as a result of fatigue has been confirmed, and a much improved design has been developed. The modification has been issued at no cost to all Nomad operators worldwide. Testing of the improved tailplane has proven the durability of the modification, although regular inspections are still required by the civil and military airworthiness authorities.

These actions were well in hand when the Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman was, in 1991, requested by Mr Philip Donovan, the brother of the pilot, and my office to investigate the adequacy of the RAAF response to the loss of Nomad A18-401.

The Ombudsman's draft report was distributed in 1993 to all organisations and individuals criticised, directly or impliedly, for comment in person or writing, before finalising the report. GAF, ASTA, CAA and RAAF employees were implicated. My department gave all of those defence employees, whether still serving or not, the opportunity to respond through the defence submission. Most did and a consolidated reply was sent to the Ombudsman.
I think it would be fair to say that the replied materially assisted the Ombudsman, who acknowledged the contributions in subsequent correspondence.

Defence addressed numerous technical details and accepted the recommendation to review the legal implications for some defence employees. Many of the department's comments were adopted in the final report.

On the other hand the Ombudsman's draft report was the first opportunity for most to see all of the information obtained from ASTA and the CAA: these organisations were also criticised. In summary, the overall defence reaction was one of satisfaction that the Ombudsman had confirmed most of the findings of the accident investigation team, the Board of Inquiry and the independent engineering assessment.

However, there was, and still is, a difference in views about the judgement of culpability of defence employees, the need for disciplinary or administrative action, and the practicability of pursuing such matters beyond that already undertaken.

The Board, which was responsible for recommending any disciplinary action concluded that such action was not warranted. Nevertheless, the Air Commander paid particular attention to this aspect and formed his own conclusions which, ultimately accorded with those of the board.

He fully understood that grounds existed for charges under the Defence Force Disciplinary Act to be laid against the two ARDU personnel whose actions led to the scheduled special servicing not being undertaken. However, he concluded that those actions were not negligent but, instead, were honest human errors of judgement.

Moreover, the appointing authority was also cognisant that, while the errors of judgement of the ARDU personnel caused the last opportunity to discover the unairworthy state of the aircraft to be missed, the causal chain for that unairworthy state, however, extended back through much higher levels of defence and to others responsible for the design of the aircraft and the management of its use; and that effective pursuit of disciplinary action against such less obvious and organisationally more remote persons was likely to be both extremely difficult and legally nugatory.

For both reasons, therefore, the Air Commander agreed with the recommendation of the Board of Inquiry in concluding that action under the Defence Force Disciplinary Act was not warranted in the case of the ARDU personnel, was impracticable for others within the defence force, and not legally possible for those outside the defence force.

The final report by the Ombudsman confirmed that the RAAF investigations were well conducted and that there was no attempt to cover up anything. Although the Ombudsman did not change her view about the existence of justification for disciplinary action, and she named and criticised individuals who had no formal opportunity to defend themselves, the Ombudsman's report has been acknowledged as a comprehensive and objective judgement, and a valuable contribution to the pursuit of air safety.

I want to stress the thoroughness of the RAAF investigations, and the timely action by civil and military airworthiness authorities to safeguard further Nomad operations. Furthermore, the wider scope of the Ombudsman's final report in dealing in detail with matters beyond the defence force needs to be recognised.
In summary, therefore, there were essentially three phases of inquiry into this unfortunate accident.

Firstly, the accident produced an extensive technical investigation which led to modification of all Nomads worldwide and alerted airworthiness authorities to the importance of monitoring ground running in setting structural lives.

Secondly, the management and individual performance of all organisations involved from design and manufacture, through acquisition and airworthiness surveillance, and, finally, to maintenance, revealed deficiencies which separately were perhaps not significant at the time but collectively led to a tragic end.

Finally, the third and most comprehensive phase in this investigation process has been the report by the Ombudsman, following the lengthy and detailed examination of all aspects of the relevant actions of the ADF, GAF/ASTA and the CAA which in all took more than three years.

That wide-ranging independent review confirmed the positive action taken by the ADF to prevent a recurrence, and drew attention to CAA and manufacturer actions which will improve the control of aircraft development testing and on-going airworthiness of all aircraft, possibly worldwide.

None of this exhaustive investigation and inquiry will bring back FltLt Donovan. Undoubtedly his tragic death resulted from a series of seemingly unrelated events, decisions, actions and omissions which culminated in an innocent pilot unknowingly flying an unairworthy aircraft which failed him.

In such circumstances, therefore, the natural desire to sheet home the blame is understandable. However, I suggest to honourable senators that all these events have been thoroughly and comprehensively investigated and reported upon, by both the technical professionals within the ADF and the independent and objective staff of the Ombudsman.

—The minister is a teensy weensy bit pathetic on occasions, too. But that is beside the point. It is a sad reality of Australian politics that we do not have the numbers in this place. The team on the other side, including the Democrats, has the numbers. We will lose, and the government will never be brought to show any discipline in proper programming at all.

—I was not going to speak on this matter, but I feel moved to do so because I think what the government has proposed is a retrograde step. If the government is suggesting that it wants to extend the sittings until 10.30 tonight and tomorrow night, it should come clean with us and say why. What is on the program listed until the end of this session that is so urgent as to require us to be here until 10.30 p.m. tonight and tomorrow night?

PARA.TAB: Many of us will have to be here throughout most, if not all, of that time, listening to the debate, listening to the points that are being put forward, and considering them, as we should, as members of parliament.

It is all right for people in the government who are going to vote for this measure and who will not be here between now and half past 10 tonight, or between now and half past 10 tomorrow night. It is all right for them to come in here and vote to force those of us who are interested in the land fund legislation to sit here tonight and tomorrow night instead of being able to debate these matters sensibly in reasonable and civilised hours.

We have had this debate time and time again. It gets a bit much, quite frankly, when many of us have to be in here early in the morning. Tomorrow morning many of us have a committee meeting at 8.30. Prior to that we have to get our own places in order. The government has not explained why it is requiring us to do this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because Senator Evans is going overseas.

—Oh, is that what it is? He is going overseas. That is excellent. He is not going overseas tomorrow; he is going overseas on Thursday, as I understand the situation. Why can we not deal with this matter tomorrow in the normal course of the day? We would probably be able to deal with it then. Why do we have to sit tonight? Is it because of the pressure of other business? What other business? The PLO has thoughtfully given us some documents, and I am grateful for the information. But I notice that the racial vilification bill is listed and I would have thought that would take an enormous amount of time.
—Oh, we don't have to deal with that this time.
—Are we not dealing with it?
—Perhaps they could tell us.

—Perhaps the government could tell us whether we are dealing with it; I would like to know. It is set down for the last week. That legislation deals with many important matters. I do not suppose many of us would support the concept that there is a place for racial vilification in Australia. I believe that there is no place for it.

PARA.TAB: In the words of one human rights commentator, we have to look at whether we have the concept of thought police in Australia. I was very interested in Frank Brennan's article in the Age recently about that matter. His credentials on human rights are unquestioned. I would need to give a great deal of consideration to that matter both prior to and during the debate.

I would like the government to tell us whether that is one of the reasons why we have to sit tonight and tomorrow night, or is the racial vilification bill not supposed to be in week nine? Did not Senator Evans, on behalf of the government, give us some sort of undertaking that, as far as possible, the government would not insist upon concluding a debate on a bill in the session in which it was introduced in the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—I hear the Opposition Whip say yes. I thought I heard Senator Evans say that in this chamber. Senator Chamarette heard him as well. Is he going to honour that undertaking in so far as that bill is concerned? What about other pieces of legislation on this list; how many of those were introduced in this session? Are we expected to debate them also this session?

PARA.TAB: The government should take us into its confidence and tell us these sorts of things. We deserve to have that sort of information before we vote on the proposal that we extend the sittings until half past 10 tonight and half past 10 tomorrow night.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not go over matters that have already been raised by Senator Harradine and Senator Hill, apart from inviting you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to examine the programs and the Hansard for the last few weeks to discover the number of matters that we have not pursued that we had an entitlement to pursue. We have kept up with the government's program. We have given up general business, MPIs and other matters to keep up with the program.

PARA.TAB: We must remember that earlier in the session there was very little work available for the Senate to proceed with. That was welcome because we had an opportunity to pursue matters in which we had an interest. But the government certainly has not had its business before the Senate.

I find it incredibly disappointing that, after all the effort and discussion that we had with the Greens, the Democrats and Senator Harradine about getting reasonable and sensible sitting hours, we have before us today a motion for which not one explanation—not even an attempt at an explanation—has been given to the Senate or to any senators as to why we should have to sit late tonight and tomorrow night and why the program cannot proceed in an orderly fashion as was laid out at the beginning of the session. We have not been told, but the government may have told some of its friends. There has not been a suggestion. It is the mere whim of somebody that we will sit late tonight and tomorrow night.

Perhaps people might have agreed to one night; but two nights? When we think of the hours we are sitting and see how tired some people around here look—and I am particularly thinking of the minister at the table, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans)—we realise that this proposal is an absurd and an absolute abuse of honourable senators. The fact is that even now we are not reverting to the sitting hours that we abandoned earlier this year. Then, we sat at 10 o'clock in the morning. To be ready at 10 a.m. and to deal with the committee work that all of us had, it was necessary to be here between 8 and 8.30 a.m. We still have to be here no later than 8 a.m. and we start at 9.30 a.m. So it is not the same as it was; it is worse.

Under the old sitting arrangements we had a luncheon adjournment of 1 1/4 hours. A lot of committees met during that time, but the chamber did not meet. Now there is no luncheon adjournment on a Wednesday; we sit through. Clearly, the manager of this place has no regard whatever for the impact of these changes not only on honourable senators but also on the staff and everyone else who has to run the place in and out of the chamber. The absence of a luncheon adjournment is not reasonable. I cannot think of any doctor or nutritionist in the country who would think that was a sensible, worthwhile situation. When I was elected to this place there was a two-hour dinner adjournment. It was then whittled away to 1 1/2 hours. Now it is a one-hour dinner adjournment.

The government was prepared to say that the Senate would sit until the legislation was finished. It now at least has put in a cut-off time of 10.30 p.m. for both tonight and tomorrow night. We will then have the adjournment debate. So there are some very significant differences between what we used to do and what we are now being required to do by adding these night sitting times.

As I said, we might have agreed to one extra night had we been given notice of it. But honourable senators are entitled to make arrangements for other things consistent with the sitting pattern that was presented to us at the beginning of the year—knowing that in the last week or so we may have to give up a night or two. People at that stage keep the time free because they know that will happen. We are four weeks from the end of the session and no reason has been given as to why we all should have our lives disrupted in this fashion. People make commitments to do other things, to go to meetings and to speak at functions. They then have to ring up and say, `Sorry, the government is so disorganised with its sitting pattern that we are now sitting tonight and I cannot keep my commitment to you.'

At least under the old arrangement, when we sat from 8 p.m. to 10.30 p.m., one could say, `No, I cannot do it; the Senate is sitting.' Unless senators are given leave from this place they will have to pull out of the commitments they have made to attend meetings in their electorates and other places. Since we came to this arrangement, Wednesday nights have almost been regarded as sacred—as a night when the Senate will rise and give people an opportunity to have an early night, to go and do something else, to catch up with work. That is not the case now—Wednesday has also been taken away.

I know of a lot of honourable senators on both sides of the chamber who have legitimate, reasonable commitments for tomorrow night. Perhaps the government could put the motion in two parts—one part concerning Tuesday night and the other concerning Wednesday night. Perhaps that would be one proposition. But to persist with the Wednesday night as well as Tuesday night and to disrupt so many people's arrangements is outrageous, inconsiderate and the sort of thing that only Senator Evans would do when he is hell-bent on achieving something that he wants, no matter what the impact on other people around him. I suggest to him that the government should not persist with the proposal for tomorrow night.

I make a plea to those who earlier this year negotiated the sensible sitting hours. The Democrats and the Greens were a part of that. I recall them saying that they were opposed to the sort of arrangement that we had imposed on ourselves; and that they wanted sensible sitting hours. The adjournment debate ought to conclude at 8 p.m tomorrow night. At least there would be some reason for reaching such a compromise. But to demand—having been here early this morning for meetings—that we sit late tonight and then tomorrow with no luncheon adjournment and a truncated dinner adjournment ought to be abandoned here and now. I hope the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) does exactly that.

The Democrats always have a little bit of trouble sticking to what they agree to, because sometimes they get a whim to change from one thing to the other. Basically, I cannot understand why they are doing it at this stage. As I said, it is bad people management. It is bad management of the chamber. It is bad for people's health. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate. This is not an unusual procedure in the Australian Senate. We have for year after year after year, for decade after decade after decade, concluded our business well after—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: the minister is now obviously closing the debate. Did you not see—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—No, the minister is not closing the debate because he did not move the original motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —For decade after decade we have had a situation where the Senate has gone into the ungodly hours of the morning. We have had a routine of business that in large measure has prevented that occurring. The program that we have has been responsibly and sensibly managed by the government.

PARA.TAB: We do seek late sittings tonight and tomorrow night. We do that for good reasons. After five sitting weeks the Senate has passed only 25 packages out of a legislation program totalling nearly 70 packages. With over half of the sittings gone, the Senate has considered less than 40 per cent of the legislation program. Senators would be aware that in the next period of sitting weeks four days of government business time will be effectively lost to estimates committee hearings.

Only because of a 15-hour burst on legislation, which was helped by a late sitting last week, the average time spent on legislation reached just over nine hours a week. Before that, time on legislation was well short of the 10 hours a week the government considers it should expect, including only two hours and 15 minutes spent on legislation in week three of these sittings.

Time has been spent on a lot of other matters: on the Procedure Committee report; on debates on committee references—desertification is one, and the ABC is another that come to mind; on disallowance motions; and on frequent and, I might say, very flimsy matters of public importance that have been promoted by the opposition. The legislation program has also been disrupted by the number of references of bills to committees. Of 37 bills introduced in the winter sittings, 12 were referred to committees in the first two sittings weeks of spring.

Obviously this type of scrutiny has its place. The government accepts that this type of scrutiny has its place. But we do not deserve any criticism at all for the management of government business in this place. Already we have spent some six hours in the committee stage of the particular bill for which these two negations are proposed. The late nights being proposed do give the Senate an opportunity to conclude its consideration of this bill. It will also give us time to deal with the remainder of our program.

Considerable progress has been made in the way this chamber operates. There has always been a situation where urgent bills and budget bills have been identified and special arrangements put in place to deal with them. We do have on our program at the moment a proposal to deal with the racial hatred bill in week nine and, of course, we also have a proposal at this stage to deal with the sexual conduct bill in week eight. What is being proposed by the government here is sensible; it is good management.

I want to see a situation where senators know, at the conclusion of the next four sittings weeks, that they can effectively go home for Christmas; they effectively can make the sorts of arrangements which senators have been talking about. There is some certainty in the process. There is some certainty in the program. That is what we are proposing in this particular suggestion that we negate tonight and on Wednesday night. It means a couple of late night sittings: no longer than—in fact, shorter than—the sitting hours we have had historically in this chamber now for a long period of time. That is the situation, and I suggest to senators that this is responsible. This is a sensible way of proceeding. This gives senators an opportunity to get some certainty into our program.

If there are senators, either tonight or Wednesday night, as Senator Reid said in her contribution, who have particular problems, the government certainly will be very reasonable with any pairing arrangements that the opposition cares to propose to the government. This is the only way in which effectively we can get through the balance of our business program. Senators have some certainty and can be confident that they will get home for Christmas. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to this chamber a very serious matter that has developed with regard to the presentation of documents to the Senate. Today, 11 documents have been presented to this chamber in the one day from the Department of Communications and the Arts. If we look at the actual dates that are contained within the documents when they were finally presented, we see that they range from 16 September to 18 October. Having been presented over that range of almost a month, miraculously they have all arrived in this chamber on exactly the same day.

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators are aware, we have six speakers who have five minutes each in which to speak. If I wanted to speak in the area of communications on these 11 documents, I would not get through all 11. I would not have the opportunity to speak on any other matters and not one other senator would be able to speak on any other matter. This is an abuse of the processes of the Senate.

The whole idea of having these documents come into the Senate is that senators can give these matters proper scrutiny. Yet the Department of Communications and the Arts has abused this process by, on one day, bringing in the reports of the Special Broadcasting Service Corporation, the matter before us at the moment; of the Australian Broadcasting Commission; of the Australian Broadcasting Authority; of the National Museum of Australia; of the Australia Council; of the Australian Film Commission; of the Australian Film Finance Corporation Ltd; of the National Library of Australia; of the National Film and Sound Archive; of Film Australia; and the annual report on public lending rights—11 documents in all.

A similar thing happened two years ago with the Department of Employment, Education and Training. It was trying the same trick. At that time we wrote to the department and asked it to desist from that practice and to spread the documents through a proper time span so that members of the Senate would have time to properly scrutinise these documents. Obviously, the Department of Communications and the Arts has decided the same trick would avoid scrutiny.

I request the President of the Senate to write to the minister, Mr Lee, to ask the department to desist from this practice and, if they receive the 11 documents over a period of one month, as the inside cover indicates, that they be presented over a period of one month and not on one day. We will be taking this matter further with a notice of motion tomorrow because we think it is a very serious abuse of the parliamentary system.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, before the suspension of the sitting, I was speaking about the Special Broadcasting Service Corporation annual report and following remarks made by Senator Tierney about the unsatisfactory manner in which these reports have been lumped together for treatment today. There are in fact 44 annual reports on today's Notice Paper to be dealt with in half an hour with speeches of five minutes each. Obviously only six reports can be dealt with out of the 44.

PARA.TAB: Many of these reports are quite important. I suppose that we should be grateful at least that these reports have come down before next week because next week is taken up by Senate estimates committee hearings. We are supposed to have had access to these reports to give us detailed knowledge of their content, but this will not occur before we are involved in Senate estimates committee hearings.

I am interested that the Special Broadcasting Service Corporation annual report was delivered to the Minister on 17 October and in fact received by him on 18 October. I imagine it would have been a bit much to have expected the report to have come into this chamber in one day because we sat on 19 and 20 October. Such a procedure might have been asking for miracles. Nonetheless we were here yesterday, although we now face the ludicrous situation that reports that come in on a Monday are not dealt with, or apparently not dealt with, because we had a whole swag of reports that were submitted during the break and subjected to a different system of handling. Yesterday, as I recall, there was no attachment whatever of documents to the Notice Paper for order of business for yesterday.

It is not simply a matter of our not being given time to deal with these reports properly but, as Senator Tierney pointed out, many associated annual reports from the Department of Communications and the Arts such as those from the Australian National Maritime Museum, the National Library of Australia, the Australia Council and so on, have all come in in one lump today; even though the report of the Australia Council, according to a document that I have in my hands, was submitted to the minister on 5 October, but also was only received by the minister on 19 October. What was the report doing for those 14 days until, magically, it appeared to have been received by the minister?

Obviously the present system is not working properly. We experienced this problem towards the end of last year. I have now been handed a copy of yesterday's Order of Business and I see that not one report is attached to it. I do not know whether it has been agreed that we are not to deal with these reports under the new funny arrangements that we seem to have, which appear to limit our dealing to reports to a period of only four days.

All these documents will be deferred to Thursday when we will have to sit for extra time and they will be dealt with under general business. Once again this will give honourable senators very little opportunity to deal with reports. For example, the annual report of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is item No 22 on the Order of Business for today. There are multi millions of dollars involved in that corporation. We have also experienced the resignation of the corporation's chief executive, and yet we are supposed to deal adequately with item No 22 in a list of 44 such items. If that is regarded as an adequate way of handling such matters, I feel the situation is quite ludicrous.

I join with Senator Tierney in his protests. I would point out that in terms of the Special Broadcasting Service, the item with which we are now dealing, we know that there will have to be changes in the leadership of that organisation following changes at the ABC. Surely this parliament should be entitled to discuss these matters. There are many reports on this list that I would like to have the opportunity of dealing with. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 7 November.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—The committee is considering clause 3, as amended. The question is that clause 3, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 4, at end of proposed section 191D, add the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(4)Except where under this Part it acquires an interest in land:

TAB.TAB: (a)as office accommodation from which to discharge its functions; or
(b)as a result of the investment of Land Fund monies;

SPEECH.PARA: where the Indigenous Land Corporation acquires an interest in land it must grant that interest, as soon as practicable after its acquisition, to:

TAB.TAB: (c)an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(d)Aboriginal persons; or
(e)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(f)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts.".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 7, proposed subsection 191G(3), line 24, omit "Subsections 191D(3) and 191E(3)", substitute "Subsections 191D(3), 191D(4) and 191E(3)".

These amendments insert a new subsection at the end of proposed section 191D and make a consequential amendment to proposed section 191G(3). While the objective of the legislation is to acquire land for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, no clause ensures that the interest is actually granted. The bill also implies that the ILC may acquire land for other purposes. The Greens (WA) are concerned that any organisation that is set up to acquire land for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders should actually deliver that land to our indigenous people.

PARA.TAB: We also believe that the ILC should primarily remain a land acquisition agency and not become a major land-holder itself. Therefore, these two amendments build into the proposed legislation an imperative for the ILC to grant land to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander persons or corporations, or trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts `as soon as practicable' after that acquisition.

We believe that three conditions may underlie the purchase of land by the ILC. One is office accommodation, which is perfectly appropriate; the second is investment; and the third is a grant. It is in relation to that third condition that we want a clause put in to say that it will be made as soon as practicable after it is acquired rather than held.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support these amendments. We do not see them as providing any real additional benefit, while at the same time they reduce the flexibility that would otherwise be available to the ILC.

PARA.TAB: It is the intention of the bill, as spelt out in 191D(3)(b), that land be granted as soon as practicable after acquisition. However, in its present form, the bill provides additional flexibility in situations where, for example, the ILC purchases an area of land only part of which is required for granting to indigenous people and the remainder is to be disposed of at a later date.

The ILC also needs this flexibility in situations where, for example, there is a dispute within the community about who is entitled to holdings in the land in question. The ILC needs to be able to delay transfer until such disputes are resolved. Senator O'Chee has already argued in the Senate that this situation would be prevalent throughout Australia. It may be that that is a situation requiring action as soon as practicable; nonetheless, we think that the extra flexibility in the bill as presently drafted is preferable.

As drafted, the Greens' amendments would require the ILC to always make a grant, even in circumstances where the land is not acquired for that purpose—for example, where the land is acquired by gift or bequest. I am advised that it also creates a potential problem of inconsistency with section 191J, which allows disposal of land to non-indigenous persons or bodies in circumstances where the land is no longer required for granting to indigenous interests. As we see it, the amendments would remove the capacity of the ILC to exercise its independent judgment on the appropriate time for granting interests in land.

We are advised that this question of practicality is justiciable. Accordingly, this drafting opens up further opportunities for challenges to be made which would, at the very least, delay matters and, at the worst, damage the credibility of the organisation. The consequential amendments, which are part of the Greens' proposal, provide a similar stricture on ILC subsidiaries, and the same points apply to those.

So there a number of reasons, all essentially technical in character. There is no fundamental point of principle involved in this particular exchange. But, as I have said, we think that the extra flexibility afforded by the bill in the way it is drafted at the moment, which is important for practical and effective operation, would be denied with the Greens' amendment. For that reason, we do not support the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address the government's concern that the ILC might need time to consider the situation before granting the land. The first of these amendments put forward by the Greens does say `as soon as practicable'. I would have thought that envisages the ILC going through its usual functions accommodated by that phrase. It says `as soon as practicable'; it does not say `as soon as possible'. Quite frankly, I think it is a good amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—We now move to opposition amendment No. 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 4, proposed lines 1 to 10, omit the paragraph, proposed paragraph 191D (3)(a), substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(a)pursuing a policy of:
(i)acquiring interests in land and granting the interests to:
(A)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(B)Aboriginal persons; or
(C)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(D)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts;
(ii)in cases where the Indigenous Land Corporation grants money to:
(A)Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(B)Aboriginal persons; or
(C)Torres Strait Islanders; or

(D)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts; for the acquisition of interests in land—acting as the agent of the relevant corporations or persons in connection with those acquisitions; (except where the circumstances make the pursuit of such a policy impracticable or inadvisable) with regard, at all times, to the need to improve the viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, including by addressing their health, housing, educational, economic, social and cultural needs, as a result of the acquisition of land or interests in land to which those persons may have access;.".

SPEECH.PARA: Coalition amendment No. 7 again goes to the principles of the policies of land acquisition. From the very outset of its consideration of the land fund bill, the coalition wanted to ensure that the direction of the bill and the policy of land acquisition addressed the very serious needs of Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, by passing an amendment on the last day of the last sitting fortnight, adding a preamble which ensured that the land fund would be directed towards affecting those who are most severely dispossessed, the Senate has agreed to give this land fund a clear direction. In similar terms, from the very outset, the coalition has been set on ensuring that when the ILC goes about seeking to purchase land for and on behalf of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians it bears in mind some of the very serious disadvantage suffered by many of them.

I do not need to remind the Senate that Aboriginal Australians suffer significant disadvantage in health, housing and education, economically and, in some cases, socially and culturally. The coalition believes that the ILC should bear in mind those significant disadvantages when considering its purchase of land.

The coalition has heard the government—including the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner)—and the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, say that this is some sort of perversion of the land fund and that it seeks to send the land fund in a direction in which it was not intended to go. Indeed, they have gone on to say, `We know there are problems with health, housing and education, but don't worry about that, we'll fix it later with another package of legislation and through other programs.'

The coalition does not believe that the principles of the land fund and the ILC are affected by ensuring that, in seeking to purchase land for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, members of the board of the ILC and its operatives have in mind the very important areas of health, housing and education and economic, social and cultural needs when making those sorts of decisions.

We know from personal experience that there have been widespread land acquisitions for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that have done nothing whatsoever to assist them in these fundamental areas of disadvantage. This amendment gives some direction. It creates a principle that needs to be abided by, particularly when a decision is being made between one piece of land and another. This is a direction that we believe all Australian citizens would share when contemplating the proposal to commit an extra $21 million a year to set up this $1.4 billion fund. We should ensure that the ILC takes into account these fundamental areas of disadvantage and need.

It is not good enough for the government to say, `We will fix these problems with another package of bills. We will address this with our social justice package.' Who knows when that is going to turn up? It is simply not good enough for the government to use this as an excuse for opposing what is a very principled amendment. This amendment seeks to implant in the bill a principle that I think just about every Australian would share; that is, when we address land acquisition for Aboriginal people, we bear in mind the fundamental objective of overcoming these disadvantages.

The suggestion that some principles about redressing Aboriginal disadvantages would be put into the bill but other principles—such as health and fundamental standards of living—would be ignored could not be taken seriously. When the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration dealt with this bill in the Friday committee, we heard—particularly from Senator Kernot—that these should be fundamental human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Citizenship rights.

—Citizenship rights. Thank you for correcting me, Senator Kernot. She said that they should be the rights of all citizens, and indeed they should be. We now live in a nation where, for 30 or 40 years, well-intentioned governments have been pumping billions upon billions of dollars into Aboriginal programs, yet we still have as a national disgrace thousands of Aboriginals living in circumstances where their fundamental health, education and housing needs are not met. Many of them live in circumstances where their communities have no potential for economic viability.

PARA.TAB: It is quite ludicrous to say, `These are fundamental rights, so you should not enshrine them in a program that is specifically designed to overcome Aboriginal disadvantage and dispossession.' That is wrong. We all admit that there is a fundamental disadvantage suffered by many of these Aboriginal people. Sure, they are citizenship rights, but the Aboriginals whom we are thinking about and seeking to introduce special measures for to overcome these disadvantages do not enjoy these citizenship rights.

When the government introduces these special programs, it should give very special consideration to overcoming this form of disadvantage. It is simply not acceptable to the coalition for the government to say, `It is okay. We will address these in a social justice package or through other programs.' They have not been addressed. We have had a Labor government for 11 years, with a series of very well-intentioned ministers for Aboriginal affairs over the years. Most of them came into the job with starry eyes and good intentions, and most of them left bitter and dejected because they were not able to achieve things.

We suggest that when these sorts of measures are brought in to overcome disadvantage—particularly in relation to access to land—there should be a coordinated strategy that looks at all of the areas of disadvantage. That is why these sorts of objectives should be put into the policy of land acquisition.

The government and the Democrats have said that we are seeking to redirect the fund and make it unworkable. They would have honourable senators believe that we require land acquisition officers to have a check list when they go around to look at the land so they could tick health, education, economic viability and housing. That is a straw man. It is a furphy. It is an argument that simply does not hold water.

Honourable senators need only read the words of the amendment to understand that these are objectives. Of course, land acquisition officers do not have to go around and tick a check list before they buy land. They are things that must be borne in mind when pursuing land acquisition activities. That is the effect of the amendment.

The government would seek to build this up as some sort of fundamental undermining of the principles of the land acquisition bill. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) knows in his own heart that that is absolute rubbish. Mr Keating and Mr Tickner set out on a course to basically say no to all of the opposition amendments. They picked on one or two that they found objectionable. This was the first one that they picked out.

I have to tell the government that this does not go down very well in the community. People in the community—whether at a barbecue, a bar or wherever we talk to people outside Canberra—know that Aboriginals suffer these disadvantages. They know that we have been spending billions of dollars over the years and not making a significant impact on many of these problems. They know that there should be a coordinated strategy, a bipartisan effort, towards ensuring that we overcome these things.

It is absolutely unreal to suggest that, by putting these objectives in the strategies that should be applied to land acquisition, it will not assist quite specifically to overcome some of these disadvantages. Quite clearly, the government is seeking to build up some sort of artificial objection to this amendment, because no sensible human being could oppose this amendment on any logical ground.

Honourable senators need only read the words of the amendment to know that the intention is absolutely honourable. It is an honourable intention not just on the part of this Senate. It should be the honourable intention of all Australians to seek to assist those who suffer this disadvantage. We should not seek to do so through a promised social justice package that may appear in here in some future period or by ATSIC saying that it will address it through its existing programs. Those programs are not working. A coordinated strategy is needed, and this amendment seeks to achieve that.

I urge the Senate to overcome the cheap, political partisanship that the government has displayed in the early weeks of this debate. We should say, `This is fair dinkum. We can go forward together and ensure that the land fund upholds these very important principles.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell is accurate in saying that this is perhaps the initial issue which went to the heart of the political debate on this legislation, although there have been a number of other dimensions to that political debate since. I would not want him to leave anyone with the impression that there is a political objection only to this particular opposition amendment, that this is simply a matter of empty posturing without substance and that there are no problems with the way in which the opposition amendment is cast, because there are such problems. The coalition amendment, as will be seen, proposes to make the ILC have regard at all times to Aboriginals' needs. It would do this by having regard to the following:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . addressing their health, housing, educational, economic, social and cultural needs, as a result of the acquisition of land. . .
The amendment, however, does not specify how the needs might be assessed, nor how to quantify the difference any land acquisition would make. That leaves a two-horned dilemma to confront.

PARA.TAB: On the one hand, the needs must be assessed and the benefits quantified; in which case, this undermines the whole philosophy behind the bill, which is one of addressing the dispossession through access to land, the focus being on land. I will come back to this point later. Alternatively, the words of this amendment do not require any assessment of needs and benefits; in which case, one is left with the only possible conclusion that this is essentially meaningless window-dressing. Either it means something or it means nothing.

The trouble is that, if it means something, it means it is not only something at odds with the basic philosophy of this legislation—as I would suggest—but it is something that once again is potentially damaging to the practical effectiveness and workability of the legislation. Then we have to ask, `If there is some test that is capable of justiciable action in the courts, how do you start addressing the question as to whether particular purchases would meet the various other objectives that are spelt out? What tests would be applied? Who would sit in judgment?' Here we go again opening up the ILC's decisions to legal challenge and argument. At the very least, it is time consuming and disruptive, even if at the end of the day there proved to be no substance in the challenge being mounted.

This again is the problem with this sort of clause. It may be well intentioned. I am not going to make assumptions about the motive for all aspects of the opposition's amendments. I have indicated a willingness throughout this debate to consider these amendments as they come individually on their merits, and to give rational arguments—not just political fusillades—in response to each amendment and to explain why it is we have difficulty with them. I am doing that again now. I am not making any assumptions for the sake of this debate now, whatever might have been the case in the past, that there is something sort of intentionally wrong-headed or disruptive about this. I am just saying that that is its effect. It is either going to have that effect if we give it content, if we give it applicability, if we try to give it meaning, or else it is going to have no effect at all.

We might say that, even if it does not have any effect at all, nonetheless it is still a virtuous proposition because it draws attention to what we all acknowledge to be continuing needs of Aboriginal people in the areas of health, housing, education and so on. This is where I think it is important to focus again on the basic objects of this bill and what this bill is seeking to distinctively add to the store of legislative and other weapons we have available to us in addressing the problems of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

The bill already provides that the purposes of the ILC are to assist indigenous people to acquire and manage land, to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits. There is some overlap to the extent there is an emphasis here on economic, social and environmental benefits.

I think the amendment demonstrates that the coalition really still has not come to grips with the fundamental point of establishing a land fund and has still not really, even perhaps with good intentions, understood the centrality of land as land—land by itself; land as distinct from other programs, other objectives, other ends; land as a central aspect of all aspects of indigenous people's lives.

The amendment demonstrates what, I have to say, is essentially a welfarist approach to indigenous affairs. There is scope for a welfare policy, scope for huge dollops of money going into a welfare based policy. But there has to be something more to that. What this legislation is trying to do is add that something more. What this bill is trying to do is give indigenous people the opportunity essentially for self-determination and economic independence through land and enterprise ownership. Both a spiritual need and an economic need are here being satisfied.

If those opposite look at what indigenous people say, they will find, every time they ask them, that they will say that the first and most important way—not the only important way, but the first and most important way—to improve the viability of indigenous communities is to have access to land. From that access to land, there is a flow-on of benefits to all aspects of community life. Tracker Tilmouth, in his evidence to the committee on 21 September, put this graphically in one aspect of his evidence. As reported at page 94 of Hansard, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I simply urge that this committee pass the legislation as quickly as possible so that we can get on with the job of meeting the land needs of Aboriginal people who live in appalling conditions on small matchbox type excisions on pastoral properties and get on with the job of providing them with decent housing, decent health and decent employment, which are their rights under the current laws of this country. We need the land. You can have all the theories about health and housing stuck up there on the board, but they will not mean diddly-squat unless you have the land to put the bloody things on. The land not only provides that but also provides alternative economic opportunities which are not available to Aboriginal communities.

This has come graphically, effectively, from the mouth of someone who knows what this debate is about, knows what this argument is about and knows what the added value is that this legislation is offering to all the other ways of addressing Aboriginal needs that are already on the board. This is why this is such a substantial initiative on the part of the government—because it recognises for the first time in a substantial way that dispossession is really the central issue that the government needs to address in indigenous affairs and certainly is an issue that needs to be addressed in a sharply focused way to the extent that that has not been the case before.

PARA.TAB: What we see this proposal as really in a sense doing—and I am not putting this in any condemnatory way but as a practical reading of the implications of it—is effectively subverting the intention of the land fund by requiring the land fund essentially to meet the objectives of other programs. If we implement it and, again, if we give weight and substance to it and do not treat it as just a bit of cosmetic add-on, we will have a situation where the corporation will effectively become a second ATSIC with a whole range of functions, responsibilities and things it has to take into account rather than being able to focus simply on this question of land. That kind of duplication seems to us to be unnecessary, counterproductive and creative, as I have said, of potential for confusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that why you're setting up two land funds—one in ATSIC and one in here?

—That is only a transitional mechanism, as Senator Campbell knows perfectly well. The ATSIC capacity to spend money on land will in fact be phased out over the next three years, and we will not have any duplication. Those opposite can argue about that to their hearts' content when we get to that particular clause. That is not what is on the table before us.

PARA.TAB: Coalition members have commented that the government is providing at the moment only an additional $24 million annually for land. But if this money were used to meet the objectives of other programs as well—as is really implicit in this amendment, if not explicit—effectively we would be reducing the capacity to use this money, limited as it is, for this sole purpose of land for which this legislation is intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the word `viability' for? You have not addressed the question of viability.

—Let me just finish what I am saying. The point here is that there are other programs. We can argue about their adequacy and we can argue about their impact but, through ATSIC itself, just under a billion dollars is being spent, essentially on the whole range of other program areas that are identified in this legislation, and another half a billion dollars is being spent through DEET and other agencies separate from ATSIC, again for these purposes. It is only a relatively small amount of money that we are talking about here, as no doubt Senator Chamarette will tell us at nauseous length in due course, but it is money that is devoted for a specific purpose in the ways that I have described. If those opposite seek to dilute it in this particular fashion, they will not serve the purposes of this legislation and they will not meet the real needs of Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with a great deal of interest to what Senator Gareth Evans had to say. I assume that it was not deliberate, but it was quite apparent to me that he had not bothered to focus on the words of the amendment. When Senator Harradine interrupted and referred to viability, Senator Evans was completely thrown, simply because it was not in his brief.
—He's reading it now.

—What he read out was something to the effect that our amendment requires the ILC to have regard to the need to address health, housing, et cetera. It does not say that at all. It simply does not say that. I invite Senator Evans to confirm that either he has a truncated and misleading brief note in front of him or he deliberately went out of his way to telescope the wording of our amendment to the point where it gives a very unreal and unhelpful assessment. Our amendment states—again, the words in brackets are important—that the requirement is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . (except where the circumstances make the pursuit of such a policy impracticable or inadvisable) to have regard, at all times, to the need to improve the viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities . . .

Those opposite should ask themselves the question: what if we transferred land and it did not improve the viability of those communities? What have we achieved? In other words, if those communities remain unviable, are going backwards or are simply wallowing in squalor and lack all of the basic human rights that we all regard as essential, what has been achieved by transferring the land? `Not by bread alone' is probably what it amounts to. People simply cannot say, `I've got a spiritual attachment to the land, and that will get me through this life.' Once they have the land, they have to do something with it and something with their lives. The land is necessary, but it is not sufficient to achieve any meaningful improvement in the quality of life of those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

PARA.TAB: What is the object of the exercise? If we look at the bill itself, it is very significant that the purpose of the fund is not simply to assist Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to acquire land. What Senator Evans has just said would infer that that is what this is all about: to give people land because they have such a strong spiritual attachment to it—we should not worry about anything beyond that; we simply give them the land and, if we want to deal with any of the other material deficiencies, we do that by specific projects and programs. But that is not what his own bill says. It says that the purpose is to assist in the acquisition and management of land so as to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits. In other words, it is what flows from acquiring the land that is vitally important. That is what we are trying to achieve: a measurable benefit in their quality of life.

The person whom Senator Evans quoted said that land provides alternative economic opportunities. He was not saying, `Land per se is all we want.' He did not want to just sit under a tree and say, `Thank you very much. You have delivered. You have recognised the spiritual significance of the land, so we have got it. So how do we fill in the next 40 years?' He was looking ahead and saying, `We need it because it provides an economic base; it gives us the opportunity to re-establish our lives, to gain rising morale and self-respect.' In that way they can achieve all the things that we take for granted, such as health, housing, educational, economic, social and cultural benefits. In a sense, those are only examples. They are a subset of the paramount requirement, which is the need to improve the viability of those communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subset still has to be addressed, the way this is drafted.
—What has to be addressed is whether it improves the viability of those communities.
—`Including by'.

—I know that Senator Evans spent only six months at the bar, but I also know that in that time, even when he had briefs other than those from the union organisations, he actually looked at how to interpret words. He knows that `including' is simply in many senses an example. The test to be applied is whether it improves the viability of the communities. It might improve viability by addressing health, housing and other needs. It might improve the viability by other means. This is simply one aspect of the crucial test, which is the need to improve the viability of those communities. If Senator Evans denies that that is relevant to the whole object of the exercise, then he is denying the purpose of his land corporation, which is to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans cannot have it both ways. He cannot say to us, `Look, don't worry about anything else but the land. This is just about land, full stop. We are not interested in what happens after that. Come back with another package,' when his own bill does not say that. The purpose of the bill is to go beyond merely the transfer of land—the empty transfer in many respects—in order to try and achieve a measurable improvement. I simply ask the minister to indicate whether that was an oversight on his part in telescoping the wording of our amendment, or whether in fact he simply misread the whole amendment to the point where he did not think the need to improve viability was the crucial test.

It is the crucial test, and I am sure that that is what every Aboriginal community will tell him that they want. They want the land so as to improve their viability. They can do that in a variety of ways. They know better than we do, I suspect, what a significant improvement in health, housing, educational and other needs will mean. And it will flow from their acquisition of the land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I respond to some of the more patronising dimensions of that particular contribution from Senator Alston. It is a distinction without a difference that Senator Alston is trying to draw between saying, as I did in capsule summary form, that it requires the ILC to address health, housing and educational needs. What Senator Alston is saying is that it only requires them to have regard to what is necessary to improve the viability of those communities. It is simply getting to the same result by a slightly more circuitous route.

PARA.TAB: We are being asked to look at not just what is the viability, yea or nay, of a particular community; we are being asked to look at what is necessary to improve the viability. How else would one examine the viability of a particular community except by looking at its economic needs as well as some of these other social needs that are here spelt out? One could not sensibly address the question of viability—and in particular the question of what might be necessary to improve viability from whatever level had already been achieved—without having regard to those things. It comes back to the same basic point.

The reason why I squeezed them together was that, in reading this originally, it had seemed to me to be not something that made any difference to the basic analysis. At the end of the day all of this is prefaced by a `must'—the ILC `must' have regard to these various things. What it `must' have regard to, if this amendment is to succeed, is the kind of health, housing, educational and economic needs that are associated with the particular piece of land that it is granting. It is for that reason, as I said before, that we have a situation where either that means something or it means nothing. If it means nothing, it is cosmetic. If it means something, it is potentially quite disruptive in terms of the other objects of the legislation. That is the legal point. Let us get that out of the way; that is boring.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where's the word `must', first?
—It is not in your amendment, you silly character. It is in the stuff on the previous page: `must have the regard to the desirability of the following'.
—`Must give priority to'.

—Yes, the honourable senator is right, but the `must' is in the chapeau, which is not in your amendment but in something which precedes it. If that is the quality of the legal contribution that we are going to get from Senator Campbell, I think he had better defer to Senator Alston, whose own contributions have not been very helpful.

PARA.TAB: Let us get beyond all the legal niceties, because that is essentially a diversion from the main point.
