What Senator Alston is really rather contemptuously saying is: `Look, what is all this stuff about spiritual attachment? Man, even Aboriginal man, cannot live by spiritual attachment alone. What we are talking about is land and the kind of economic base that land potentially involves. It is only through the economic character and the liveability of the land in question and its viability in terms of this legislation that this particular grant of land is going to mean anything at all.'

I do not know how much Senator Alston knows about Aboriginal people, but I do not think he knows very much. Let me tell the committee a little story about an Aboriginal person who used to live with my family. He came down from the Northern Territory and he stayed with us while he was doing a law degree at Melbourne University. I have never talked about this sort of stuff because I have never needed to in the past. I need to talk about it now because I want to say something about that particular guy and what he felt about the absence of access to some land that he could call his own or that he could somehow relate to.

When he was living with us, and a year or two later when he brought his wife and kids down, he had this incredible sense of being crowded when living in Melbourne, or in Victoria. He said, `Look, it is no good me driving up into the country', as I suggested he do. He said, `There are fences everywhere. All this land belongs to someone else. There is nothing I can go on. If I go way, way out into western Victoria, yes, maybe I can find a bit of national park or something and get away for a while.' He said, `I feel just so crowded. What I need to do is get away for a day or two or three or a week every now and again just to have that sense of space, to have that sense of relationship with some land that I can relate to. It is no good to just drive up the road and park and have a billy tea by someone's farm fence. That is not the way it works.' This is 20 years ago, but I remember vividly how much this whole concept mattered to this particular guy.

I know from experience in talking to many people over the years—all my years of association with Aboriginal people, such as in the land rights stuff back in 1972 and with the Aboriginal Legal Service in Victoria, which I founded with some other people in the early 1970s—how much this matters. There is something that is important about this which is separate and distinct and over and above the purely mechanistic, economic, man-oriented approach that Senator Alston has to this question. That is why this is important. That is why this particular piece of legislation is adding some value to all the rest of the things that we do that are helpful in so many ways, we hope, to Aboriginal people. If those opposite do not understand that, then they have not understood the point to this particular legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought Senator Evans was going to respond to the points I made. One point that I did not hear him respond to concerned an explanation as to why it is that his own bill require people to go beyond assistance in acquiring and managing land to actually provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits.

PARA.TAB: The example that Senator Evans gives makes my point. We are talking about people who have the need to relate to land—perhaps on an occasional basis to get away or perhaps so that they have something they can call their own—but it does not, in the end, provide them with subsistence or viability on a permanent basis. We are talking about how we can best assist these people in meeting that paramount need of transferring land. They do not want the land because it is a piece of useless scrub. They are not getting the land only because they have a continuous and spiritual attachment to that particular piece of land. They are wanting land for a purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe the cultural purpose of just relating to it, even though you think it is a useless piece of scrub. You have missed the point!

—The whole point is that the government's own purposes—and that is what I am asking Senator Evans to address—reveal that it sees a need to go beyond the mere spiritual attachment. I am not denying the validity of that; I am saying it is necessary but not sufficient for the long haul. They do not just go to the land on weekends. They do not just like to think it is there if they need to go home occasionally.

PARA.TAB: The government is transferring land, which has cost the ILC money. The government is setting up a fund for the purpose of acquiring and managing land. It is doing it for a purpose. What is its purpose? To provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits. They are all relevant factors. They are all very important in assisting people to have some self-respect at the end of the day—not just on an occasional basis, but on a long-term permanent basis.

When one discusses the issues—as I am sure Senator Evans has at great length; as we all have endeavoured to do, in my case, probably over 15 to 20 years—one understands that one is going beyond that point. The trouble is that in most instances these people have never got to first base. So they regard the land as a fundamental starting point. But they do not say that that is the end of it—`Simply give us the land and we'll then ignore the way in which life is to be lived, the way in which we relate to our communities, our families and ourselves.' They say, `That will enable us to achieve a quality of life that we simply don't have at the present time.' I therefore ask Senator Evans to address himself to why his purposes are expressed in the way they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me just respond to that and then I will leave the debate to others. There is no point in prolonging this argument unmercifully. Our purposes—and Senator Alston asked us to go to that in section 191B, at the top of page 3—are providing economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits. They might be multiple benefits associated with a particular piece of land, but they can be benefits in the alternative. It does not necessarily follow that something which is a social or cultural benefit is going to be of economic benefit. It may be that there is an economic benefit that is important and it may be that that ought to be sought. It may be that there is a social or a cultural benefit that people want to seek in relation to that land.

PARA.TAB: Maybe there is a community with a perfectly viable economic base near a town—somewhere which operates as an effective community base for people to get paid employment and work in a satisfactory environment. But what that community is lacking, maybe in a New South Wales country town, is access to some piece of land as a supplement or satellite to that particular community base which would exist for the purpose of adding an extra dimension—cultural or social—to their lives. The opposition's amendment does not concede that that need for a cultural or social benefit, as I have described it—call it a spiritual benefit if one wants to use different terminology—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a social and cultural need.

—Because the opposition's language is cumulative in character! It is not in the alternative. We have to address people's health, housing, educational, economic, social and cultural needs; whereas, the purposes that we are talking about are economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits.

PARA.TAB: There is a world of difference between that cumulative obligation that is created by the opposition's amendment which is premised on a particular view of why land is necessary, and our proposal. Sure, it might have a cultural benefit, but being economic man, mechanical man or dollars and cents man, those opposite cannot perceive that land might have a sole justification for acquisition which is not linked to all those other sorts of things. I have made the point. I cannot make it any more forcefully by making it any more lengthy. If those opposite do not understand it, I am afraid I will not be able to persuade them. There is a fundamental world of difference between the approach that is encapsulated in the bill as it stands and the approach that is encapsulated in this particular amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell said that the Australian Democrats were relying on some future package to address the disadvantages of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I do not think the argument is about whether this government or any other government will address Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander disadvantages. This debate is about two principles; it is about the fundamental right to land with no strings attached and the fundamental citizenship rights of indigenous Australians as Australians with respect to health, education, housing and the other things that are listed in the amendment. While I agree that the coalition's linkage of these two principles is not ill-intentioned, it is nevertheless still odious.

PARA.TAB: I will quote from a paper from the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, `Land and indigenous health', by Barbara Flick and Brendan Nelson. Under the heading `Rights as entitlements', they make a very telling point. They state:

SPEECH.PARA: When the High Court found that the Meriam people had a right as against the whole world to possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the lands of the Murray Islands, the judges did not qualify this by saying `as long as they could show that recognising this will improve their health'.

One could add `or will improve their housing, their education or their economic, social and cultural needs.' The fundamental point in that judgment, and in other learned writings such as the deaths in custody reports, is that land rights are a collective right inherent to indigenous peoples. We are seeking to impose on them, in our own non-indigenous way, a set of utilitarian criteria. We are saying, `Yes, land rights are a birthright but only under these circumstances.'

PARA.TAB: This is a land fund. It is not a health fund, a housing fund or an education fund. Recognising it as a land fund is recognising that dispossession is at the root of the continuing problems indigenous people face, problems that arise from economic and social disempowerment. The fundamental recognition of indigenous interests in land should not be dependent upon, or in any way turn on, any test of improvements in living conditions or, with respect to one of the amendments we have already passed, degrees of dispossession.

That is the point of the government's framework in this bill. To clutter up the bill with a prescription that the corporation must have regard at all times to improving viability is unnecessary. I ask the opposition: do you have a set of priorities here? We have just changed words to `give priority to'. In the opposition's cumulative list here, what takes priority—acquisition of land for cultural benefit or acquisition of land that might be of economic value?

What measurements does the opposition use for improved viability? The opposition says things such as, `If you give land to someone and there is no improved viability, what have you achieved?' I would suggest that it is possible to achieve empowerment, which is a very important principle and something that goes again to the heart, to the root of dispossession and all that flows from that. So I make the point to the opposition that it is possible to demonstrate viability not only in those tangible, commercial terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by `empowerment'? How does it translate?
—Self-determination and the right to make other decisions that flow from that—to use your example, whether it be to sit under a tree for spiritual purposes or whatever.

PARA.TAB: The linkage is unnecessary and it undermines the very principle of citizenship rights which accrue to all Australians. That is why, having listened to the opposition in the House of Representatives debate and this debate tonight, I still cannot find a justification for supporting this amendment. I do not say it is ill-intentioned. I say that it undermines those fundamental principles, and I do not think we should be doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the opposition could indicate a couple of things to me in response to a couple of questions that I would ask. I underlined the word viability. To me, that meant responsibility. In fact it mean empowerment—the need to ensure that the ILC, in pursuing the policy of acquiring interests in land, granting interests and money et cetera, would look at the question of empowerment. Correct me if I am wrong, but viability seems to say, `You can live on your own.' That is why that appealed to me on the face of it.

PARA.TAB: Is it the opposition's intention, however, to have those particular features of health, housing, education, economic, social and cultural needs considered as a cumulative question? I did not see that that was what the opposition really meant.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is what I said it means.

—But there is a valid point there: it does say `and', and I think Senator Evans had a point there. I did not take it to mean `and' because of the comments Senator Campbell made in presenting the case on behalf of the opposition. Because if it does mean `and', it will place the ILC in a very awkward position indeed with an almost impossible task of deciding which group should perhaps get priority for money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Harradine asks is, of course, an important one and the intention is indeed that these matters are regarded by the ILC in its acquisition policies. As I said in my introductory remarks, the government and the Democrats have been saying, `Here we have this checklist' so that when the ILC goes to look at a bit of land, it has to tick off all of these things.
—But you modified this.
—It has been modified, of course.
—Please acknowledge that.

—It has indeed. We have modified it to ensure very much that it is not a check list. It was never meant to be a check list. I think that Senator Evans is making it appear as though it is a check list because it suits his political purpose. He knows that it is not—
—It's reading your own language.

—Well, Senator Evans can read it that way but it is not the way I think the ILC would read it. I think that Senator Evans has to go back to his own clause in the bill—I think it contains paragraphs 191B(a) and 191B(b). He says, `Well, how do you measure these things?' The bill specifically says, `so as to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits.'
—Or.

—That is right. I am not arguing the `or' and the `and'; I am just arguing the concept. Senator Evans says that it is hard to measure health or housing. It is also equally hard to measure economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits. The same concept survives. During the consideration of the bill by the standing committee, Senator Evans went to that very argument. He said that these economic, environmental, social and cultural benefits—
—Or.
—Or. I am sorry. I am really not facing that argument.
—But that is important.

—It is important, but it is not the argument I am having. During that debate, Senator Evans said that these criteria flowed inherently from the ownership of the land. I think he was drawing a long bow but, when I questioned him at the time, he said that the coalition's objectives were thoroughly worth while. But when Senator Evans was further questioned, he conceded that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . when the corporation—
the ILC—
is faced with competing claims, probably a number of considerations, including perhaps some of the ones that you have identified, will necessarily come into the equation of decision making.

That clearly is what is envisaged. We do not in any way seek to detract from the arguments that Senator Evans very emotionally and eloquently made about Aboriginal attachment to land. I do not think it is fair of Senator Evans—and I do not think he sought to—to say that he has a greater understanding of that sense of attachment than does anyone on this side. Many of us, because of the age difference, have probably not had as much experience in these things as he has had, but we have had experience and relationships with Aboriginal people and we do understand the relationship between Aboriginals and land.

PARA.TAB: We also have had the experience of understanding some of the disadvantages that Aboriginal people suffer. We know that land can help to redress that lack of attachment to land, lack of a place, lack of a sense of belonging and the spiritual need to have contact with land that is special to Aboriginal people. We also know that we, as a nation which seeks to overcome the significant disadvantages through various special measures, need to address these disadvantages.

We went to some length to ensure that there was no way that the wording of this motion could be read as a check list. That is why the words were `have regard to the need to improve viability'. I say to Senator Harradine that the word `viability' is exactly that. It is not as though you put the high bar up and, if you jump over the viability test, you get the land and, if you do not, you do not. As Senator Kernot quite properly says, it is not a thing that can always be judged with foresight. A lot of people go into all sorts of ventures expecting them to be viable and find out that they are not viable. When the ILC seeks to make purchases and acquisitions, it needs to make an assessment of these things and the crucial test is the viability of the community, including addressing these other objectives that have been canvassed ad nauseam.

I say to Senator Evans and the government that of course the land is the primary objective of the fund. That is the first thing. People like Tracker Tilmouth have said, `Look, we've just got to get the land and the other things will flow from the land.' That is quite right and the opposition agrees with that sentiment. We are also saying that the government's bill does not stop at land. It envisages in pages and pages of this legislation land management functions. The land management functions are, of course, crucial to ensuring viability of land. If the government said, `Look, we just want to give Aboriginals land because of spiritual attachment and the need to redress dispossession,' it would not worry about land management at all. It would not go into all of the details of setting out to improve land management and setting up a regime to assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians in improving land management.

So those things are crucial. There is absolute common ground between I think all senators in that regard. What we are saying is that it is important to go further than that and that the ILC should be given a sense of direction. Most Australians would agree that there are a bunch of these fundamental matters and that they should be citizenship rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are; that's right. So the linkage is unnecessary.

—No, it is not. We would not need any Aboriginal legislation, we would not need a Native Title Act, we would not need an ATSIC, we would not need any of this if Aboriginals enjoyed the rights that the rest of Australians enjoy, but they do not.
—You can't have qualified rights of some Australians.

—It does not qualify rights. All of the measures are considered as measures to overcome the disadvantage that so many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders suffer because they do not enjoy the rights that Senator Kernot and I enjoy, and they do not enjoy some of the rights that Aboriginals in urban Australia enjoy. A lot of them just do not have these citizenship rights. They are citizens of our great nation, but it is not that great because they do not enjoy the rights that we enjoy.

PARA.TAB: I do not think any Australian should have to live in a nation where we have thousands of people not enjoying those sorts of rights. I think all of us are trying to address that. This is our way of saying that, if we want to pursue a land acquisition policy to overcome the dispossession and to overcome this disadvantage, the ILC needs to ensure that it has regard to improvements in the viability of these communities and has special regard to these fundamental disadvantages. That is the opposition's view on this matter. I hope that gives Senator Harradine the clear intention of the coalition.

If Senator Gareth Evans has sought to narrowly define the effect of the amendment, that certainly is not the way that I would read it. If it requires some sort of alteration to make that far more clear in a drafting sense, then perhaps that is something that will need to be considered. I do not believe that is necessarily the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address three things. The first is to emphasise that the opposition is presenting a very different amendment from either the one it presented in the House of Representatives, which has been noted, or the kind of interpretations that were made, possibly by members of the opposition but certainly by the government, of the intentions of any amendment that was presented in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: I think it was an error of judgment on Senator Gareth Evans's part to imply that there was anything about this amendment that would divert the funds from land to any other programs of a housing, educational or health kind. It is quite clear if we read the amendment that it relates specifically to land. That is the first point I want to make: it is about the acquisition and management of land and guidelines and the way in which the ILC goes about these things.

The amendments are necessary partly because the original clause simply refers to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporations, and this needs to add wider possibilities or flexibilities. The section that refers to having regard at all times to the need to improve the viability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities is actually addressed to the way in which the ILC pursues its purpose.

That leads me to the second point, which is, I believe, the red herring introduced by the difference between the `or' and the `and'. It does not worry me one bit that this is a list; it does not worry me one bit if it is cumulative because it is essentially addressing the way in which something is being carried out.

What is being carried out? We need to refer not to the performance of the function, which is the amendment we are talking about here, but to the purpose of the Indigenous Land Corporation. As Senator Gareth Evans has pointed out to us, the purpose of it is to acquire land, to assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander persons to acquire land and to manage indigenously held land so as to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders.

Nothing is taken away by the `or' and nothing is made conditional or cumulative in terms of strings being attached. The purpose remains identical to the one that has been specified by the government in the legislation. It clearly has an `or'. That is why the fact that there is a list here that has `and' in it is of no relevance in terms of tying up anything. All it does is expand the degree of factors that the ILC can take into consideration which might be cumulative and which assist it in the very difficult task it is doing. As Senator Gareth Evans said, this is the task of allocating an extremely scarce resource—some money—to cater for the wide demand of many people throughout Australia who have been dispossessed of their lands. So I think it is appropriate to consider whatever factors need to be taken into account. In my view, this is an exhaustive list, but if there were another category, I would be happy to put it in.

The principle that is being made here is that a range of measures will improve the empowerment of Aboriginal people by gaining their land. It underwrites the principle that land and giving Aboriginal people back their land is integral to their wholeness and wellbeing as Aboriginal people and communities. So I do not see anything wrong with including it there.

My third point, which is the reason why the Greens will be supporting this amendment, is that it is very similar to our amendment No. 4. Without this amendment and our amendment No. 4 there is an overwhelming impression that this bill is only about dollars and economic viability. If this amendment and our amendment No. 4 are accepted, there will be only three mentions of social and cultural values in this entire bill.

The one reference that is currently in there is in the clause I read out, namely, the purpose clause 191B. Fortunately, it does mention economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits, and appropriately so. It would be a great shame if it were felt that an economic bill was being produced or that some kind of economic hoop had to be gone through in order for the land to be acquired.
It is appropriate to refer to the social and cultural wellbeing and the values inherent in giving Aboriginal people their land.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of viability.

—It would be if it did not include a whole list of social and cultural variables. Senator Harradine's summing up of `viability' as meaning empowerment is very apt and does not refer to economics. But there is no question of anything beyond economics unless we address the purposes of the bill. That is why the Greens are supporting this amendment. We see it as being a way of underwriting the integral connection of Aboriginal people with their land, the need to give it back to them and the recognition that all those other values will be improved by addressing their need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will go back to the start of this debate and, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) would say, get a clean line of logic.
—Are you implying that nobody else has in the intervening period?

—I think both Senator Kernot and Senator Gareth Evans have missed the point. Aden Ridgeway, the executive director of the New South Wales Land Council, stated before the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the bill does not contain any principles that direct or suggest that the ILC should distribute funds and, most importantly, it does not require that priority be given to those who have been dispossessed and, further, have little to gain under the Native Title Act.
The government and the Australian Democrats might recall that the Greens, Senator Harradine and the coalition supported the preamble that we now have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had one.

—The Democrats had their own preamble, but it was only similar in so far as it referred to that extract of the native title preamble which we thought was so important and which they agreed with. But we then looked at the objects of this bill. This bill was like a rudderless ship, a ship that had nowhere to go. It needed some direction in both the objects and functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation.

PARA.TAB: We provided those objects. Our amendment 191AA(2) states: Therefore, the object of this Part is to assist those dispossessed Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to meet their economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations through the acquisition and management of land.

SPEECH.PARA: That set it out in general terms. The government's equivalent was perhaps clause 191B, which Senator Chamarette has just picked on. It states:
The Indigenous Land Corporation is established:
(a) to assist Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to acquire land; and
(b) to assist Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait islanders to manage indigenous-held land;
so as to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits—

They are what Senator Kernot would class as citizenship rights. What clause 191B says is that we are using the acquisition of land to enhance citizenship rights, because we are talking about economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you pick that up in the first place?

—But Senator Kernot supported that. What we did was to give it much more clarity, because in this amendment we deal with the functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation. That is a more particular aspect. It is more particular in the direction that we are giving to this rudderless ship. This is exactly the point that Senator Chamarette made, that this addresses various aspects which the ILC should bend its mind towards—and if there were others too, I myself would be willing to entertain them.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the amendment, it deals with health, housing, educational, economic, social and cultural needs. There is nothing greatly dissimilar to what the government has in clause 191B. But the government puts those things there as window dressing; they are there merely for the purpose of the establishment of the ILC. What we are proposing by this amendment is to give the objective reader a better understanding of what that Indigenous Land Corporation has to do and what it has to have regard to.

Let us look at how it might go about performing its functions. I would suggest it would do it in the following manner. It would firstly have a look at the community, from Redfern to the Pilbara. Remember, this piece of legislation has to cater not just for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders living in remote areas but also for those dispossessed Aboriginals living in urban Australia. I think that at times that has tended to be forgotten during the course of this debate. Legislation dealing with an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community should address these aspects.

In Redfern, for instance, there might be more accent placed on health, housing, education and the viability of that community within the suburb of Redfern. On the other hand, in the Pilbara we might be dealing with a community of fringe dwellers or Aboriginal people who are perhaps closer in the traditional sense to their heritage than the urban Aboriginals I have just mentioned. There, you

SPEECH.PARA: might place more accent on the cultural or social aspects.

PARA.TAB: But I would suggest to Senator Evans in the strongest possible terms that this is not about good old Anglo-Saxon commercialism. In the criteria that we are addressing we are talking about health, social and cultural needs. They are all pertinent to the viability of a community. I think Senator Harradine has it right. When we look at the viability of a community being able to exist on its own as that entity, we look at it in its environment. We look at those needs and see how they can be addressed in helping it maintain its viability, that is, so that it can remain in the Pilbara or the Kimberley region of Western Australia or Redfern or on the outskirts of Adelaide—wherever. But the fact is that we look at the community in that context. That is how this legislation is to be interpreted. It is not a question of saying, `Well, I am afraid that this grant of land will do well on health, housing, education, but it misses out on one of the others, so therefore we cannot do it.'

We are always going to have a varying degree of accent, and that is left to the discretion of the Indigenous Land Corporation. It makes abundant sense. It is self-evident. We are not tying up the hands of the Indigenous Land Corporation by suggesting that we would necessarily place one over another in a pecking order. But these are matters which have to be addressed so that none of them is overlooked in the performance of this corporation's functions.

Without this amendment, the Indigenous Land Corporation is a rudderless ship. It does not have anything to direct itself to. The only thing it could possibly direct itself to is the purpose of its existence contained in clause 191B, which says that it has to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefit. The difference is that we have particularised the issue in a way that I believe will be clearer to the objective reader, and to the ILC when it comes to perform those functions.

We do not class all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in the same way. We do not put them all in the same basket. We do not expect those in more remote regions to have the terrace style housing that we might find in inner city Sydney. It is quite ludicrous to think that we would look at communities in that manner. We take these communities in the context in which we find them. We address the viability of the community and keeping that community as a whole which can continue to sustain itself and be autonomous and free. We address these issues. We do not necessarily have to say that, because one might have scant weight compared with others, the grant fails. That is not what this amendment says.

That is the thrust of the amendment. There is no commercialism in it. We do mention economics, but then again so does the government. Clause 191B mentions economic benefits. We are not saying that they are the ultimate benefits to be looked at. They are just one of several, as Senator Evans has said himself. We are saying that it is just a question of clarity, function and direction of the Indigenous Land Corporation. As Senator Chamarette said, I believe that the question of `or' is a red herring. Our amendment affords a discretion to the ILC to administer its functions accordingly. During evidence before the standing committee which I have mentioned, Senator Evans conceded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . when the corporation—
meaning the Indigenous Land Corporation—
is faced with competing claims, probably a number of considerations, including perhaps some of the ones that you have identified, will necessarily come into the equation of decision making.

That is on page 48 of the Hansard. That was in answer to a question I put to Senator Evans about this very aspect. The Indigenous Land Corporation will be faced with some very difficult decisions. It needs to have some guidance when it comes to those difficult decisions. That is all we are offering it—some particularity of purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just make one further short comment on this. If we are giving direction or guidance to the rudderless ship, as Senator Ellison puts it, it is very important to give that guidance in a way which is genuinely responsive to perceived needs of Aboriginal people. There are a lot of different kinds of needs which can be satisfied by grants of land. Some needs are essentially economic in character. I suppose some are welfare in character, such as the need for land in order to provide a location for a building of some particular hospital, school or other service. Some needs are cultural, social or, as we have been saying, spiritual in character. It may be that a particular grant of land will be such as to be able to satisfy multiple needs simultaneously, but sometimes it may involve choice.

PARA.TAB: What is important is that the corporation be able to have that choice, that flexibility and that responsiveness and, on some occasions, be able to simply make a grant of land for one kind of reason only, to meet one kind of need—a social or cultural need—and not to have to address these other sorts of needs.

As the legislation stands at the moment, the corporation has that discretion and flexibility without any let, inhibition or hindrance. It can make that judgment because the general guidance that it is given in clause 191B is in terms of meeting `economic, environmental, social or cultural' needs, conferring benefits of one or other of those kinds—maybe multiple, but one or other if it comes to the pinch. So there is ample discretion as it stands at the moment.

Once those opposite start writing in a further set of criteria of this kind to which the corporation must have regard, they have to look very carefully at what those criteria do by way of reducing flexibility and the discretion which would otherwise be there. They are not giving helpful guidance to a rudderless ship if they are locking the corporation in and reducing its discretion. It may be that these amendments are drafted in a way in which, as we have said before, they do not mean anything at all. But if they do mean something—those opposite seem to want them to mean something; and I think that in practice, with the way the courts are interpreting law at the moment, they probably would mean something—they are requiring the corporation, before it makes any grant of land, to look at the grant of land against these cumulative criteria.

The courts have to look at the question of viability, but they are not just making up their own minds on what viability means and whether it means empowerment in some of the senses that Senator Harradine has mentioned; they have to look at what viability means in the way those opposite have drafted it. Viability in the way they have drafted it means looking at viability through a particular set of spectacles. It means looking at viability in a way that takes into account and addresses a whole variety of things—health, housing, education, economic, social and cultural needs—in a cumulative fashion. The cumulative impact of having to look at viability defined in that way by reference to those kinds of criteria is to require the corporation to look at the whole question in a different way from the way it would if its discretion and judgment were unfettered.

What this again fails to appreciate—and I will make the point quickly again—is that land does have a use for Aboriginal people that sometimes is not easily or readily perceived by the rest of us, in circumstances where European-style services are not proposed to be plonked upon it or where it is not proposed to derive formal economic use from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why we have `social' and `cultural'. We could have `spiritual'.

—Sure. But what I am saying is that it is important that those criteria be able to be applied by themselves, without having to be looked at through the other set of spectacles with cumulative criteria. The point is worth making—and I think it is very nicely made by a mob I previously have not heard of called the Independent Council of Aboriginal People and Associates, based in West Wyalong. At one point, in a letter that that group submitted to Robert Tickner recently, they said:

SPEECH.PARA: Where the land use intended by Aboriginal and Islander people does not envisage use of European style services it—
he is referring to the opposition amendment—
judges successful utilisation of land by culturally arrogant, inflexible anglo-saxon standards: thus repeating . . . the underlying insult of Terra Nullias—

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble is that they are referring to the old amendment; let's be honest about it.
—Let me finish the sentence. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: that land use as practised within Aboriginal or Islander custom does not count.

That is an extreme way of making the point—and I am not suggesting that those opposite are being as insensitive in their intentions or motivations as to do that. But I am saying that it is crucially important to give full recognition to that dimension of Aboriginal need for land; a need sometimes, in some circumstances, just to have land for land's sake, just to sit on it or walk across it—scrub land, empty though it may appear to other senators or to me—not to do anything economically viable on it, not to deliver a welfare service or add viability to the community through those other criteria, but just to have it because it is land. It is a very important thing for Aboriginal people to be able to have in some situations.

PARA.TAB: I genuinely think that with the way the legislation is crafted with this amendment, the opposition does not make it readily possible for the corporation to just look at a particular kind of grant of land as being defensible, legitimate and available under the legislation—just for those sorts of reasons. No, the opposition says that viability must be looked at, and it must be looked at by reference to a cumulative set of criteria which go way beyond just that concept. That is the problem we face with this amendment. I will not say anything more; I think I have made the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of additional matters that can usefully be considered. The first thing that I think needs to be kept in mind is that, when we talk about viability, we are talking about the ability to develop and survive independently. As I said earlier, I would be very surprised indeed if the government were arguing that there is merit in transferring land even if the end result was that a person was not viable. In other words, a person can transfer land in order to achieve some other purpose than the simple acquisition of land per se. That is why the purposes part of the bill goes on to specify a number of, let us say, material characteristics.

PARA.TAB: If we get to that point together, then I think the argument simply becomes whether `and' or `or' makes the difference. I think we are in heated agreement in that regard. We are not arguing that the ILC would need to be satisfied on each and every one of those criteria. The legislation says that they must have regard to the need to improve the viability of the land, including by addressing. Addressing does not mean they have to be satisfied that each and every one of those characteristics or criteria has to be satisfied. It simply means that they will look at those criteria.

They will not look at those criteria in some very scientific and quantitative manner. They will have regard to each of those factors because they are in themselves various examples of viability. Having done that, they can then be satisfied that any one of those will improve the viability of the community. What they are doing is simply considering a range of criteria but, at the end of the day, they only have to be satisfied that one at least would achieve or assist in achieving viability.

That is really all the government's purposes argue. It is not sufficient to simply assist in the acquisition of land or to manage land. There have to be economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits. One will do. The government may prefer to say that cultural benefits are the most important because that has a spiritual connotation, but it has to concede logically that there may be circumstances in which it is only the economic benefits that demonstrate results from the transfer. That quite properly reflects the enormous diversity and variations that exist from Carnarvon to Fitzroy. That is what this amendment achieves.

With respect, I do not think that there is at the end of the day a cumulative requirement at all. The language is not expressed in those terms. The term `addressing' I would have thought, to give its proper and natural meaning, means that we simply have to look at things. It does not mean that we have to be satisfied that each of those exist to a sufficient extent. We simply have to look at them. They are the means of satisfying people that they are improving the viability of the community. I would have thought that perhaps where we end up differing is that the government says that viability is not necessary and we do. I do not think we should pretend that somehow we are requiring satisfaction on all of those matters when the government would probably say one is enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does Senator Alston still insist on linking land rights and citizenship rights in a way that he does not apply to non-indigenous Australians?

—We have had this debate to quite some extent. The fact remains that, by merely stating a bill of rights or a charter of citizenship rights, we do not necessarily achieve anything. It is nice and pious and we feel good about it but it does not get us anywhere. That is why the government in its purposes does not simply say that we establish the ILC to acquire and manage land. It says that we do it for a purpose.

PARA.TAB: The purpose, if you like, is non-spiritual. It can be any one of a number of purposes; maybe spiritual is sufficient in itself. But we have an additional dimension simply because in the great majority of cases the people that we are trying to assist lack one or, in many cases, many of what we regard as basic human entitlements or citizenship rights. They are all variations on the theme.

The purpose of this legislation is to get to a point where we are making a difference. With this legislation, making a difference means providing an economic, environmental, social or cultural benefit. It is not a big step from that to saying, `Why are we doing that? Are we doing that simply so people can say they have some right or benefit? Or is it because we want to make a difference to their quality of life?' That is when we get to the point of looking at viability.

I suppose viability is a nebulous concept in some respects. As the dictionary defines it, it is the ability to develop and survive independently. The very least we should expect of citizens of Australia is that they have the ability to survive on their own. If land is a necessary prerequisite, it will lead to an improvement in their viability. All the other things are simply examples of it.

If we take the cultural example, which Senator Evans would define as including the spiritual dimension, that pretty well takes us back to where we want to be: we give people land to which they have a spiritual attachment—not to that particular piece of land, because this fund is for those who are unable to satisfy the other criteria—because it is important to them, because it is empowering, because it has a cultural or spiritual dimension, or, to put it another way, a non-material or non-economic benefit.

But having done that, we have given viability because people then have the ability to develop and survive independently. In other words, they have thrown off the shackles. They have the land—that is the sine qua non—and they can progress from there. So at the end of the day we are not very far apart. We may vary in expression but everyone accepts the very great significance of the land. It is a matter of whether we go beyond that and ask what it will lead to. The government feels the need to say what will follow from the mere acquisition or management of land, and so do we, because—

TALK.START.PARA: —But they also say land in itself is what is required, which you do not.
—The government does not. If it did, the ILC—
—But land meets the purpose.

—If all it was saying was that the ILC is set up to acquire and manage land, full stop, I could understand Senator Kernot's argument. She would be saying that land per se is all that is necessary—we hand it over and that does the trick. But the government is not saying that. It talks about providing social—
—And that includes spiritual and cultural purposes.

—I am defining `cultural' to include spiritual. But on the government's own definition it has to be done for the purpose of at least one of those objects. If one of them is cultural, that is fine by me.
—Exactly, and that is what it means.

—Precisely, there is a purpose to it. Land is being handed over because it satisfies one of those needs. We are therefore making it an objective. In effect, by saying it is the purpose it becomes a requirement. If it is a requirement, that is saying, `We are not giving you land for land's sake; we are giving you land because it makes such a difference to your quality of life that it improves your cultural, spiritual or social condition.'
—Your viability.
—That amounts to viability, yes.
—In your terms.

—Exactly. That is why I do not see that there is a very significant difference between what we are talking about and what the Democrats are talking about, other than, I think, the use of the term `viability'. That is why I ask: would they really be content with an outcome that led to non-viability? I would not have thought they would. So are we not in heated agreement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make an observation. Proposed section 191B states that the ILC is established `so as to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits to Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders'. Here is that second area of rights, if you like, which is envisaged to be the basis for the establishment of the Indigenous Land Corporation.

PARA.TAB: I do not think this is the time to launch into a comparison of the features of the UN Convention on Civil and Political Rights and those of the UN Convention on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. But I think this is interesting. Something is churning around in my mind about it but at this hour of the night it is not coming out very clearly. Maybe when we deal with this matter at some other stage I will be able to say what really is—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope we are going to vote on it tonight.

—Yes. But I think what Senator Alston said is correct. I do not think there is a great deal of difference, but I do feel that the word `or' needs to be there. I still say that. I have been down that track plenty of times. I have written a fair number of rules in my day in the trade union sphere, probably most of which are very impartial and democratic. Those rules contain an objects clause, for example. The TTLC did have an objects clause which is very much similar to that of the ILO. Actually, when I became secretary of the Labour Council I changed the words to read, `to contribute to the economic and social order in which persons can live with freedom and dignity and pursue both their spiritual development and material well-being in conditions of economic security and equal opportunity.' That is the object. Here we have passed an objects clause—not in precisely the same terms—which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this Part is to assist those dispossessed Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to meet their economic, cultural and spiritual aspirations with acquisition and management of land.

That is the object. A lot of things are in the object. It is important to have the policy in the objects clause. But when it gets down to the actual practical clauses, particularly a clause such as this which is really directing the ILC in its acquisition and land management decisions to have regard to certain things, I think the wording is vital. In my view, the word `or' should be there. So I foreshadow an amendment to the second last line of the opposition's amendment to delete the word `and' and insert the word `or'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the committee to amend the motion as follows:

PARA.TAB: Omit "and" (last occurring), substitute "or".

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Chamarette said earlier and as we have said, it is certainly not the intention to make it a cumulative check list. If Senator Harradine believes it can be interpreted that way—certainly Senator Evans seems to—and if the substitution of the word `or' addresses that concern, then we are happy, with leave of the committee, to so change the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not deny leave. Such an amendment is a small and incremental improvement and it partially meets one of the concerns I had. I am glad that Senator Harradine at least understood the point I was making.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of difficulties still remain with the legislation in this form. The mere fact that the ILC has to have regard to this question of viability and has to give some content and meaning to the notion of viability by applying one or other—if not necessarily cumulatively—of these particular criteria seems to us to be an unnecessary restriction. The corporation ought to be able to go straight to one particular kind of need without having to be concerned as to what exactly this word `viability' means in this context.

PARA.TAB: Problems will undoubtedly arise in the interpretation of this clause, even as just amended. There will be potential for disputation about it. We think it is a distraction from the main game of this particular bill, which is to enable the purchase of land and not to address welfare needs—as most of this other language rather implies is part of the process as well.

I am not going to repeat all the points I made earlier. Many of them were applicable to the amendment, even with the further amendment that has just been made. I am indicating that we will divide on this amendment, notwithstanding that particular concession that has been made by the opposition.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Campbell's) be agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: S1.Clause 3, page 4, at the end of section 191D, add the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(4) Before the Indigenous Land Corporation performs a land acquisition function referred to in subsection (1), it must take all reasonable steps to consult the traditional owners of the land in relation to which the function is to be performed.'."

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment follows on from clause 191D that we have just been discussing. I apologise for the lateness of its circulation; it was circulated this afternoon. This amendment adds another section to the end of 191D because, at present, the bill makes no attempt to ensure that the relevant traditional owners are consulted before land is acquired by the ILC.

PARA.TAB: Any government agency, particularly any agency which the government purports to be an indigenous organisation, should be careful to respect the traditional ownership of the land. This is made all the more necessary when the land acquired will be, by definition, freehold title or leases where the native title is therefore very likely to have been extinguished. As such, there will be no claims over the land and therefore no legal signs of continuing connection.

This clause was one of the five consensus issues which we understand were agreed at a meeting of Aboriginal people in Melbourne last week. That is the reason why we have circulated it so late. It was of concern to Queensland members of that group who brought it to our attention. We felt it was an appropriate addition and commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has not been made aware of any consensus position by the Aboriginal representatives to whom Senator Chamarette refers. I am not suggesting there was not, but we have not been formally made aware of it. We would certainly want to discuss that with the people concerned before accepting it because, again, there are a number of problems with the provision. As with so many of these innocuous looking things that are put in, it sounds good. `Consult with traditional owners before exercising any function' and so on—yes, that sounds plausible and credible, but how does it work in practice?

PARA.TAB: In some cases it may not be readily possible to identify any traditional owners of the land in question, but there may be some ambiguity about the possibility of there being traditional owners. There will be a need in at least some situations where the possibility of traditional ownership is real. I am not suggesting that that is very likely in urban Victoria or somewhere like that, but in a lot of other cases it may well be real. Then at least one has to go down a research path in trying to establish who might be traditional owners, which would be the equivalent to the kind of research we have to do and the process we have to follow under the Native Title Act or the Northern Territory land rights act.

We cannot just assume that there is a core of people walking around with placards around their necks saying they are traditional owners for particular pieces of land about whom there will be no difficulty in making an identification and in relation to whom there will not be any potential squabbles. There is all sorts of potential for squabbles in particular indigenous communities where the situation might be thought applicable because of disputes about who are traditional owners. We are all familiar with those.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why can't you consult both claimants?

—Because if we are creating a statutory obligation to consult traditional owners, we have to be in a position of clearly being able to identify who the traditional owners are that we are consulting. Those opposite cannot just make it up as they go along, in the way Senator Alston seems to be making up his response to half the things that he is waxing lyrical about in the course of this debate. If those opposite are writing statutory language, if they are creating obligations, if they are creating justiciable obligations such that mandamus or something will lie at the instance of the disaffected if they do not like what the corporation is doing, they have to be a hell of a lot clearer about what they are doing, why they are doing it and the workability of it than they are being in this particular instance.

PARA.TAB: Again, at the very least we have the prospect of delay, the prospect of inability to deal further with land in question while these processes are working themselves out, additions to administrative costs and additions to the potential for litigation. So bit by bit those opposite make this legislation more impractical, more unworkable. I suggest that this is another example of just that phenomenon at work. Bit by bit they are making more inevitable the utter inability of this legislation, if it is passed by the Senate, to be put into practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bit by bit, Senator Evans is exposing the political motives behind the government's tactic on this bill. He has just impugned the motives of the Greens and of many of the Aboriginal people who met in Melbourne last week, but we will disregard that. I am sure Senator Chamarette will deal with that in her own way. Clearly, this government is trying to create a whole bunch of reasons why it cannot live with this bill.

PARA.TAB: The government has made up its mind already that it will take the bill back to the House of Representatives, chuck it back over here and cause a double dissolution trigger. That was on Four Corners last night. That is his game. Bit by bit, as it gets later in the night, as Senator Evans gets tired and looks forward to jumping on a plane and rushing off to the United Nations to sign another treaty, and as he gets more frustrated and angry, his real motives come out. He has just exposed them.
Only two weeks ago we agreed, in what I thought was a spirit of cooperation, to an amendment that said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Indigenous Land Corporation must take reasonable steps, including, where it deems it appropriate, making a non-claimant application within the meaning of section 67 of the Native Title Act, to inform itself whether any interest to be acquired in land is subject to native title or native title rights and interests. . .

That is very much a process that envisages finding out whether there is a traditional owner, whether there is someone out there who can assert native title rights. The Senate agreed to that agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are you reading from?

—For Senator Kernot's assistance, because this is the quickest way of finding it, I am reading from page 2139 of the Senate Hansard of Thursday, 20 October. That amendment was agreed to by Senator Evans when standing behind the President, scratching on a bit of paper. It sought to achieve the principle that, when the ILC buys some land, it should first ascertain whether or not there is a traditional owner around or someone who might assert native title rights, and not tread on the rights of those people who, Senator Gareth Evans explained so eloquently earlier this evening, required, sought and hungered for some link with their traditional lands.

PARA.TAB: All Senator Chamarette is doing is saying that the ILC, in performing its land acquisition function, must take all reasonable steps to consult with the traditional owners. Again, Senator Evans has gone to his advisers and said, `Let's create all these nasty, technical problems with this set of words to build me some sort of argument to knock over what is otherwise an entirely reasonable and principled amendment to the act.' It is entirely in accordance with the amendment that the Senate passed not two weeks ago—on Thursday, 20 October—saying that the ILC should have regard to the traditional owners of the land.

There may be areas of Australia where they have no requirement whatsoever because the traditional owners have been dispossessed, they have no native title rights, and it is quite clear that the ILC is not required to do that. Where there is any possibility of a traditional owner being associated with the land, it would be an absolute travesty of the rights of those people for the ILC to not consult with them. That is what this amendment is requiring, and that is why the coalition will support it. It reasserts the principle that we have already supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, I want to respond to Senator Evans's comments. Is the minister suggesting that it is not appropriate to consult relevant traditional owners? Is he insisting that the ILC should have the flexibility not to consult the relevant traditional owners? My understanding is that, with the amendment that he devised very quickly, doing a running edit in a way that I think will go down in history, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In performing its land acquisition functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation must take reasonable steps, including. . . to inform itself whether any interest to be acquired in land is not subject to native title or native title rights . . .

We showed the Aboriginal people who came to see us this afternoon the particular amendments that had been agreed so far, and they felt unsure that it covered one of their consensus decisions that came out of the Melbourne meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who were they?
—The people that met in Melbourne.
—All of them?
—Yes, all of them. It was a consensus decision.
—And they agreed to this, did they?

—Yes, they did. I inform Senator Kernot that we had a report from the people who went to that meeting. They are actually up in the gallery. The people who came and told us of that meeting said that there were five consensus decisions and one on which they disagreed. They were all the people who were present.
—I was told that they did not take a vote.
—A vote is not necessary if it is a consensus decision.
—I was told this: they avoided taking a decision, consensus or otherwise.
—Okay. All I know is that it was reported to me that it was one of the five consensus decisions that were reached at that meeting.
—You have not said that there.
—Oh, get on with it; come on!

—Yes, come on. To abbreviate this painful interchange, I should state that at the request of Aboriginal people I have moved this amendment. I felt that the amendment should have been covered somewhere in the bill. It was quite a reasonable request. I am putting it forward and I suggest we vote on it.

—I do not know whether there is a deliberate effort to be a muddle-headed wombat, or whether Senator Chamarette cannot help—along with the opposition—making a reference to the amendment that we passed earlier concerning checking whether or not there might be a native title claim. If Senator Chamarette does not understand the difference between, on the one hand, satisfying oneself as to whether there may be some native title claim or some native title interest in relation to the land in question and, on the other hand, satisfying oneself as to who are the actual traditional owners who can derive the benefit of that native title interest or claim that might be around, then she has not been focusing on what this legislation is all about.

PARA.TAB: It is one thing to have the potential for a native title claim because there is a group of people, at least some of whom have some prima facie continuing attachment to the land in question such as to make likely or possible the probability of the existence of a native title claim; it is quite another matter to move from there to establish who the actual traditional owners are. These things are riddled with a whole heap of potential for argument as to who are going to be the beneficiaries if there is a claim in existence. Who are the traditional owners? This is where we get into intra-communal discussions. That is exactly the sort of thing that is in issue here.

The ILC has an obligation not just to satisfy itself as to whether or not there might be a native title claim, but it has an obligation, first of all, to identify who the actual traditional owners are because unless and until they are identified there is no-one to consult with. In that case we are talking about a potentially onerous obligation.

In an area that has been the subject of its own rapidly evolving litigation culture, with a lot of people who see themselves as standing to gain or lose through these situations, these sorts of arguments are ones that lend themselves to a lot of implications in terms of the workability of the legislation. I am not trying to make this legislation unworkable. I am not trying to create artificial problems where none exist. But, my god, I am trying to identify new problems when they are created for good motives or ill elsewhere around the chamber. One has one's suspicions about the motives of some of the people in this place when it comes to this particular legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Stuff the traditional owners' is what you are saying.

—One has one's suspicions about the hypocrisy of which some people are capable in rhetorical interjections of the kind that Senator Campbell just offered. One also has one's beliefs that other people on all sides of the chamber are genuinely well motivated in trying to do the right thing. But, at the end of the day, one just has to make a judgment as to whether this legislation is going to work. We are going to make that judgment line by line, clause by clause, as we get through it.

PARA.TAB: I have indicated a willingness to compromise where compromise is possible, consistent with the philosophy and the integrity of this legislation. If we compare the nature of the debate that has taken place here with that which has taken place in the House of Representatives, we see that there has been a serious minded attempt to respond to each of the issues that has been raised. There has been no cavalier dismissal of points, no throwaway references. I will fight clause by clause to get a workable piece of legislation. But, if at the end of the day those opposite leave me and the government with a piece of legislation that is not workable, they are going to have to bear the consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that, until this point in time, the debate has generally been carried on on all sides of the chamber with a fair degree of goodwill and determination to exchange sensible differences of opinion and to achieve common ground as much as possible. But what we have just heard shows a very dark side to the government's political agenda. Senator Gareth Evans is essentially trying to argue that in some circumstances the traditional owner cannot readily be identified. That is boiling his point down. Yet, with a very clumsy display of sophistry, he completely and utterly ignores the fact that the amendment says that all reasonable steps must be taken.

PARA.TAB: If, in the odd circumstance, it were not possible to identify the traditional owners, by definition, everything would have been done as could reasonably be expected to have been done and the obligations satisfied. But Senator Evans is trying by device to say, `Because it may just be possible in some circumstances that the traditional owners are not readily apparent, we want to dispose of any obligation to consult with them.' Yet that is what should be at the heart of this legislation. That is what he really should be concerned about above all. If there are traditional owners, surely they have paramount entitlements. They are the ones we need the talk to. They are the ones we need to deal with in the first instance, rather than going through quite unnecessary processes and finding out late in the day that what the ILC seeks to do will be disputed by the traditional owners.

I think it is the low watermark of the night, quite frankly, for Senator Evans to be deliberately ignoring that requirement to take all reasonable steps in an attempt to fabricate some sense of unworkability about a proposition which, on its very face, is designed to allow for situations where it may not be possible to consult the traditional owners but it is still possible to do what should be done. If Senator Evans, by that sort of device, is going to argue that somehow there should be no obligation to consult, that there is no purpose achieved, he is really revealing his political agenda. I think it is a sorry point that we have reached in this debate. I hope that we very quickly start to move upwards from here.

TALK.START.PARA: —One has to ask oneself before voting on this matter whether it is reasonable to expect the Indigenous Land Corporation, before it performs its land acquisition function, to consult the traditional owners of the land where that is possible and where it is reasonable. I thought that is what it was all about—the linkage between the Mabo legislation and this legislation. The point Senator Gareth Evans has been making is, first of all, that the traditional owners have to be identified—
—What if you cannot identify them?
—If they cannot be identified, they are not consulted. There is no problem about that. I believe that this is a reasonable proposition, and I intend to support it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 4, at end of proposed subsection 191D(3), add the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: ";(c)pursuing a policy of not retaining any interest in a parcel of land in which it has granted an interest under paragraph (1)(a)".

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 55 deals with subsection 191D(3) and adds a final paragraph (c). We have dealt with paragraphs (a) and (b). Paragraph (a) was the previous amendment No. 7, paragraph (b) is as it is printed in the bill, and paragraph (c) is the new amendment we are dealing with now.

PARA.TAB: This amendment sets out to add to the policy or purpose of function of the Indigenous Land Corporation, which we debated at length earlier this evening. It states that one of the things the Indigenous Land Corporation should pursue is to avoid retaining any interest in the land which it is supposed to be giving away. This was mentioned in the previous debate. The coalition believes that it is humbug to give land away but then retain an interest in it, possibly in perpetuity, because that is much like being an Indian giver. If land is given, it is given.
Consideration interrupted and progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I raise my concern about yet another example of the recent mismanagement of the ABC by the Minister for Communications and the Arts and the federal government—this time with regard to allegations involving corruption, kickbacks and bribes within our national broadcaster. Some weeks ago I received complaints from a former ABC employee in Adelaide that information which he had forwarded to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee, had not been handled appropriately.

PARA.TAB: It transpired that, as long ago as February this year, this person had made allegations to the minister's office verbally and subsequently in writing that secret financial inducements—bribes—had been given to three ABC managers in Adelaide by private contractors in return for these firms receiving contracts for services required by the ABC. Two Adelaide firms were alleged to be providing these financial kickbacks to senior ABC executives on a regular basis.

A further allegation concerned the provision of free mobile telephones to two senior ABC managers in Adelaide in return for approving the installation of Telecom mobile phone towers on the roof of the ABC building at Collinswood. The source of the allegations contacted my office because of dissatisfaction with the minister's handling of the matter and no-one being brought to justice. Apparently, after repeated contact with the minister's office, my constituent was advised that the matter had been referred to the ABC chairman for investigation, who eventually responded that no evidence of fraud had been found.

Sharing the concerns raised with my office by the constituent, I personally wrote to the minister on 21 September detailing the matters which my constituent had raised with the minister and seeking an urgent assurance that a full and proper investigation had been carried out by the appropriate authorities. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This reply confirmed his awareness of the allegations and his referral of the matter to the ABC chairman on 6 April 1994. Professor Armstrong in turn replied to the minister on 16 May 1994 claiming that the matter had been investigated and that the ABC found no evidence of fraud to support the allegations. What else would we expect when the minister has so grossly mishandled this issue?

PARA.TAB: For a whole month the minister ignored the information provided on several occasions by my constituent in telephone calls to the minister's office from February 1994. Another month went by and the minister again ignored the same information provided to him in writing on 10 March 1994. Then, on 6 April, he asked the chairman of the ABC to investigate and, surprise, surprise, the ABC sent its own investigator to Adelaide to look into the matter. Naturally, he found no evidence of fraud.

Of course he was unable to find anything. As soon as this tame cat internal investigation commenced, those about whom these allegations had been made found out on the ABC internal grapevine and the fraudulent gravy train was stopped dead in its tracks. No wonder no evidence was found! The perpetrators had time to sweep their illegal activities under the carpet. At best, the failure to apprehend the culprits was due to the minister's incompetence in handling the matter. At worst, perhaps he handled it in this way as a means of deliberately avoiding yet another embarrassment at the ABC.

Surely, as these allegations involved possible criminal offences, the minister was duty bound to immediately refer them to the Australian Federal Police instead of sitting on the information for two months before initiating an ineffective, half-hearted internal investigation. The minister stands condemned for failing to take the appropriate action.

In his letter to me, the minister says these allegations must be treated seriously and investigated thoroughly, and yet he has failed to refer the allegations to the most appropriate authority—the Australian Federal Police. One wonders what sort of sideshow this incompetent minister is running, having Caesar investigate Caesar. But this whole sorry saga gets worse.

On 27 October, the Australian Federal Police contacted me and subsequently met me in my Adelaide office to discuss these allegations and to seek my assistance. When they arrived, I assumed that the minister had finally advised the Australian Federal Police to look into the serious allegations of corruption in the ABC. But he still had not. The Federal Police told me that they learned about the complaints from Telstra eight months after the minister had initially been informed of the allegations. It was a full eight months and still the minister had not advised the Federal Police, but the Federal Police in fact found out about this matter, as I said, from Telstra.

The minister's response concerning these serious allegations is transparent. He is really saying, `I told the ABC and they couldn't find anything.' The police regard the minister's failure to refer the investigation to them at the outset as highly irregular. His actions have effectively undermined their capacity to conduct an effective investigation at this late stage. One would at least think that, now that the police are involved, the minister would release to them the many letters, internal investigation files and briefing notes of which his office has possession. But no, when my office contacted the Australian Federal Police in South Australia earlier today, the minister had still not made this information available.

I ask the question again: why has the minister failed to have this matter properly and fully investigated? Of what is he so afraid? The Australian Federal Police have a capable team of investigators to handle such allegations involving Commonwealth officers. In fact, under section 73 of the Crimes Act, the Australian Federal Police are empowered to investigate matters pertaining to corruption and bribery of Commonwealth officers. But the best the minister can do is casually pass the allegations on to the ABC to investigate itself with no outside accountability or scrutiny.

Time and again we have witnessed the appalling manner in which this government has failed to be publicly accountable when it comes to the proper administration of justice in this country. I can only hope that, despite the incompetence of the minister for communications in handling this serious issue, there might still be some hope of success for the recent inquiries commenced by the Australian Federal Police. It remains to be seen what damage the minister's failure to advise the appropriate authorities has done. Whatever the outcome, the minister is guilty of gross mismanagement.

ANSWER.PARA: The numbers of personnel serving in NSW/ACT have fallen primarily due to the closure of HMAS Nirimba and the transfer of some of its functions to HMAS Cerberus in Victoria. Other reasons for the decrease in numbers include the progressive implementation of the Government's two ocean basing policy which will eventually result in half of the destroyer force and the majority of the submarine force being based in Western Australia. These changes have led to associated increases in the number of personnel serving in Victoria and in Western Australia. The decrease in the number of personnel serving in the Northern Territory is due to the rationalisation of functions previously carried out at Shoal Bay.

The significant movements of personnel between States have primarily been a result of changes caused by the Force Structure Review (FSR), Defence Regional Support Review (DRSR) and the Army Personnel In the North initiative. NSW/ACT had a reduction of personnel due to the FSR drawdown and 2 Cavalry Regiment's move to Darwin (which led to an increase in the number of personnel in the Northern Territory). Victoria had a reduction of personnel due to the FSR drawdown, Commercial Support Program (CSP) contracts and DRSR initiatives. Queensland had a reduction of personnel due to 6 Brigade becoming a Ready Reserve force and CSP contract activity.

The decrease of personnel in NSW/ACT has been brought about by reductions in numbers at Stores Depots under the DLRP and commercialisation or civilianisation under CSP. Victoria had a reduction of personnel over the same period, generated by devolution of functions from Headquarters Logistics Command (HQLC) Melbourne to bases and the closure of units. Numbers in Western Australia have declined, principally due to commercialisation under CSP. The increase of personnel in South Australia was caused by functional transfers from HQLC, a build up at the Aircraft Research and Development Unit and the establishment of a new unit.
Changes to Defence civilian personnel relate to restructuring arising from Defence initiatives including the FSR, the DRSR, the CSP and the Defence Logistics Redevelopment Project (DLRP).
